title: Sladek v. Sladek
text:
The South Carolina Court of Appeals


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Suzette Roberts Sladek, Appellant,
v.
Gerard Robert Sladek, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
James A. Spruill, III, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-389
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 5, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James T. McLaren and C. Dixon Lee, III, both of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
Thomas F. McDow, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Suzette Sladek, Wife, appeals the family courtâ€™s denial of her request for alimony, attorneyâ€™s fees, and costs.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Gerard Sladek, age 57, and Wife, age 44, were married for almost eleven years. Â One child, a daughter, was born of the marriage, and Wife had one son from a previous marriage. Â The parties spent much of the marriage living in separate residences. Â Wife had received substantial insurance proceeds from the death of her previous husband and had used those funds to build a home. Â Wife and children lived in the house while Husband occupied a garage apartment adjacent to the main house.Â  Husband was retired from the Internal Revenue Service and received a monthly retirement benefit of $3,727. Â Additionally, Husband was employed by the North Carolina Department of Revenue earning $4,000 per month. Â Wife, a college graduate, worked part-time as a preschool program director earning $583 per month.Â  Wife also received $1,267 per month in dividends on non-marital investments.Â  
At some point in the summer of 2002, while on vacation, Husband and Wifeâ€™s son were involved in an altercation.Â  Wife filed for divorce on July 30, 2002.Â  The family court denied Wifeâ€™s request for alimony, stating she was capable of procuring higher paying, full-time employment.Â  The family court also denied Wifeâ€™s request for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs. Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The decision to grant or deny alimony rests within the discretion of the family court judge.Â  Clardy v. Clardy, 266 S.C. 270, 273, 222 S.E.2d 771, 772 (1976).Â  The judgeâ€™s discretion, when exercised in light of the facts of each particular case, will not be disturbed on appeal absent abuse thereof.Â  Long v. Long, 247 S.C. 250, 252, 146 S.E.2d 873, 875 (1966).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the judge is controlled by some error law or where the order, based upon findings of fact, is without evidentiary support.Â  Stewart v. Floyd, 274 S.C. 437, 440, 265 S.E.2d 254, 255 (1980).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Wife asserts the family court erred in denying her alimony and attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We disagree.Â  On the issue of alimony, she focuses exclusively on and claims error in the following three findings of fact made by the family court:Â  (1) There was no reason Wife could not earn entry-level college graduate income; (2) Husbandâ€™s expenses exceed his income; and (3) Wife did not prove the breakup of the marriage was Husbandâ€™s fault.Â  We shall address those issues seriatim.Â  
Since the parties married, Wife was a stay-at-home mother and later, part-time preschool director. Â Her lack of recent college level employment may make it more difficult to obtain a higher paying position.Â  However, Wife does possess a college degree, and her children are older, attending public school, and arguably require less of her time.Â  Additionally, Wife testified she planned to pursue her teaching certification so that she would â€œhave the same hours as [her] children.â€ Â These additional credentials would enhance her employability.Â  â€œThe burden is upon the appellant to convince this Court that the trial judge erred in his findings of fact.â€Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).Â  Wifeâ€™s assertions that it will be difficult to find suitable employment are not enough to meet this burden.Â  Because there is evidentiary support in the record for the courtâ€™s ruling, we cannot conclude the family courtâ€™s finding was error.
Wife also contends the court erred in concluding Husbandâ€™s expenses exceeded his income.Â  Again, we turn to the record to see if this finding is supported by some evidence.Â  Husbandâ€™s financial declaration states that his net monthly income is $5,001.74, and his monthly expenses are $9,005.Â  According to the declaration, Husband pays $2,000 per month to an adult emancipated daughter. Â He further claims to pay $158 per month in real property taxes[2] and $90 per month in real property insurance, $500 in dental bills and $1,400 in child or spousal support. Â Wife disputes all of these expenses, and Husbandâ€™s own testimony calls the validity of these expenses as monthly obligations into question.[3] Â However, the family court is in the better position to judge the credibility of witnesses and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry at 525, 280 S.E.2d at 541.Â  Moreover, even if we completely remove the items Wife questions, Husbandâ€™s expenses total almost $5,000 per month, primarily due to substantial credit card debt.Â  Based on the evidence in the record, we cannot conclude the family court abused its discretion in finding Husbandâ€™s expenses exceed his income.
Finally, Wife argues the family court erred in determining Husband and Wife were equally responsible for the breakup of the marriage.Â  Wife testified that during the marriage Husband had disfavored her son and was often angry and rough with him. Â In particular, there was an allegedly violent altercation between Husband and Wifeâ€™s son during a family trip to Charleston. Â Wife claims this incident was the â€œstraw that broke the camelâ€™s back.â€Â  Wife further testified Husband had moved out of the bedroom of his own accord because they had a new baby, and eventually moved into the garage apartment because of the childrenâ€™s noise and their early bedtime.Â  Husband testified he initially moved out because Wife had trouble sleeping well with another person in the bed.Â  He made the more permanent move to the garage apartment because Wife put stress on him at the end of the workday, and she wanted quiet for herself and the children to sleep when Husband desired to stay up later.Â  Wife admits the issue of fault raises the classic he said/she said situation.Â  As previously noted, it is for the family court to determine the credibility of the witnesses and make factual determinations based on their testimony.Â  Id.Â  The family court apparently gave more credence to Husbandâ€™s version of events in Charleston, and in addition found that the marriage had essentially been dysfunctional from the beginning with Husband and Wife having separate residences.Â  Based on the foregoing, we cannot conclude the courtâ€™s determination that the parties were equally at fault in disrupting the marriage was error. Â 
With respect to attorneyâ€™s fees, the thrust of Wifeâ€™s argument is that because she should prevail on the issue of alimony, she should, as a matter of course, be entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  As previously discussed, we do not find error in the family courtâ€™s rulings and therefore do not alter the outcome of the case.Â  Wife also asserts that the family court did not consider the Glasscock factors in denying her request.Â  See Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 403 S.E.2d 313 (1991).Â  However, the Glasscock factors are only relevant in determining the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to be awarded.Â  Wife only appeals the fact that she was not awarded attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  â€œIn determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the court should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fee; the beneficial results obtained by the attorney; the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.â€Â 
Griffith v. Griffith, 332 S.C. 630, 645, 506 S.E.2d 526, 534 (Ct. App. 1998) (emphasis in original).Â  Here the record shows the family court considered these factors, and we can ascertain no abuse of discretion in its ruling. Â 
For all of the foregoing reasons, the decision of the trial court is Â 
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â Wifeâ€™s brief states that Husband claimed to pay $715 per month for real property taxes on the residence.Â  However, Husbandâ€™s financial declaration lists an obligation of $158 per month for real property taxes.Â  We use the obligation shown on Husbandâ€™s declaration in our analysis.Â  
[3]Â Husband paid his adult daughter a lump sum of $27,000 at the beginning of 2003 as part of a contempt action and apparently divided that sum into monthly payments over the year for purposes of his financial declaration.Â  Husband testified he paid $500 in January, February, and March of 2003 for dental expenses, and that it would take more work to â€œget [his] mouth straightened out.â€Â  The taxes and insurance claimed related to Wifeâ€™s non-marital home, which she would retain after the divorce.Â

title: State v. Robinson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Scottie Robinson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-390
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 5, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz III, of Columbia, for Appellant
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, of Columbia; John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Scottie Robinson appeals his murder conviction.Â  He argues the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on self-defense.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On September 30, 2001, Aaron Robinson was playing basketball with several other men, including Anthony Bradley, at the Smith Jones Recreation Center (the Center) in Conway, South Carolina.Â  During the basketball game, Robinson and Bradley argued and engaged in a scuffle wherein Bradley grabbed Robinson by the throat and shoved him.Â  After the two men were separated, Robinson went to his car and drove home.Â  
At some point after the incident, Scottie Robinson (Appellant), Aaron Robinsonâ€™s older brother, became aware that an incident had occurred between his brother and another man at the Center.[2]Â  Appellant picked up his cousin Theartis Robinson and drove to the Center.Â  Upon arriving at the Center, Appellant retrieved a handgun from the glove compartment of his vehicle, and he and his cousin approached the men on the basketball court.[3]Â  Bradley attempted to grab the gun from Appellant, and during the struggle, Appellant fatally shot Bradley in the chest.Â  Immediately following the shooting, Appellant walked back to his car and drove home.Â Â Â  
An Horry County grand jury indicted Appellant for murder.Â  At trial, the jury convicted Appellant on all charges, and the trial court sentenced him to thirty years imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appellate court will not reverse the trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding
jury charges absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law or, when grounded in factual conclusions, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Id.Â  If any evidence exists to support a
jury charge, the trial judge should grant the requested charge.Â  State v. Burriss, 334 S.C. 256, 262, 513 S.E.2d 104, 108 (1999).Â  A refusal to grant a requested
jury charge which states a sound principle of law applicable to the case at hand is an error of law.Â  Clark, 339 S.C. at 390, 529 S.E.2d at 539.Â Â  A self-defense jury charge is required only when the evidence presented at trial supports such a charge.Â  State v. Goodson, 312 S.C. 278, 280, 440 S.E.2d 370, 372 (1994).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellant contends the trial court erred in denying his request to charge the jury on self-defense.Â  We disagree.
A defendant is entitled to a self-defense charge only when the following four elements can be established: (1) the defendant was without fault in bringing
on the difficulty; (2) the defendant believed he was in imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury; (3) the defendant had no means of avoiding the danger and was thereby forced to act as he did; and (4) that a reasonably prudent person of ordinary firmness and courage in a similar situation would have entertained the same belief about the danger.Â 
Jackson v. State, 355 S.C. 568, 570-71, 586 S.E.2d 562, 563 (2003).
In this matter, the record fails to establish the necessary elements for a charge of self-defense.Â  There is no evidence in the record to support the notion that Appellant was without fault in bringing about the difficulty.Â  Appellant testified that his intentions in driving to the Center were to confront Bradley and tell him to leave his brother alone.Â  It is undisputed that Appellant, while holding a gun, approached Bradley on the basketball court.Â  In fact, Appellant testified that Bradley specifically instructed him not to come onto the court with the gun.Â  The fact that a struggle over the gun ensued does not allow Appellant to claim self-defense.Â  â€œ[O]ne who provokes or initiates an assault cannot escape criminal
liability by invoking self-defense.â€Â  State v. Slater, 360 S.C. 487, 491, 602 S.E.2d 90, 92-93 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
Further, even if appellant reasonably believed he was in imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury,[4] he certainly had means to avoid the danger.Â  Appellant testified that upon his arriving at the Center, Bradley immediately began yelling â€œviolent wordsâ€ at him.Â  Yet, despite his ability to simply return to his vehicle and leave, Appellant retrieved his gun and approached Bradley on the basketball court.Â  When asked why he did not simply leave the Center, Appellant testified â€œI donâ€™t know how to answer that.â€Â Â  
Neither the first nor the third prongs of self-defense have raised questions of fact for the jury.Â  As a matter of law, these required elements have not been established.Â  â€œBecause the record demonstrates as a matter of law the absence of at least one element of self-defense, the trial judge did not err in refusing to charge self-defense.â€Â  State v. Santiago, 370 S.C. 153, ___, 634 S.E.2d 23, 28Â  (Ct. App. 2006).

    CONCLUSION
We find no error by the trial court in refusing to charge the jury on self-defense.Â  Based on the foregoing, Appellantâ€™s conviction is
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Both Appellant and Aaron Robinson testified that they did not speak with each other following the incident at the recreation center.Â  Therefore, neither the manner in which Appellant came to learn of the events, nor the exact details of which he was made aware are entirely clear.Â  It appears Appellant overheard some neighbors discussing the incident. 
[3] Although through conflicting accounts, all parties agree that through a verbal exchange, Appellant became aware that Bradley was the individual who had tussled with his brother.Â  Appellant testified that Bradley immediately began screaming at him, and other witnesses testified that Appellant asked who â€œwas messing with his brother,â€ and Bradley responded â€œit was me.â€Â  
[4] Bradley had a reputation in the community for being a â€œtough guyâ€ and had participated in several professional boxing matches.Â Â Â

Appellants, Gene Sheryl Nix, Sandra Dianne Nix and Dewayne Nix (hereinafter either referred to individually or jointly asâ€œIntervenorsâ€) appeal the trial courtâ€™s order denying their motion to intervene, arguing that their participation and the relief the

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State Respondent,
v.
Corey McKenzie Shelton Appellant,
      
    
  


Appeal from Laurens County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge 

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-391
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 6, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney Donald J. Zelenka;
Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters; all of Columbia; and Jerry W. Peace, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Corey McKenzie Shelton appeals his convictions for murder and possession of a firearm during commission of a violent crime, for which he received concurrent sentences of life imprisonment and five years, respectively. Â Shelton argues the trial judge erred by refusing to direct a verdict acquitting him of the charges because the State failed to introduce any evidence he committed the crimes.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
This case involves the drive-by shooting of fourteen-year-old Phillip Johnson, Jr. on August 4, 2001.Â  Corey Shelton, Derek Brown, and Ricky Latimore were indicted with murder and possession of a firearm or a knife during commission of a violent crime in connection with this incident.[2]Â  
On the night of the shooting, Johnson, his cousin Xavier Smith, and a number of friends attended a high school football game.Â  After leaving the football game, the boys went to a friendâ€™s house on Pleasant View Drive, and â€œhung outâ€ with ten to twelve boys in the front yard.Â  Smith testified that around 11:00 to 11:30 p.m., a large, dark-colored car, which had been parked nearby when the boys arrived, came down the road with two guns firing out the windows.Â  Someone in the group fired back at the car as it drove away.Â  Johnson was shot in the drive-by. 
Johnson died from his gunshot wound on the way to the hospital.Â  Bullet fragments removed from his body were sent to SLED for testing.Â  At the scene, officers found fifteen 7.62mm casings, seven .45 casings, as well as a 9mm casing.Â  Bullets that penetrated a nearby residence were also sent to SLED for testing.Â  
Smith could not identify the people in the assailantâ€™s car.Â  Directly after the drive-by, he gave the police the names of Terrence Bishop, Darrell Brown, and â€œK,â€ but testified that those were just the names of some boys with whom he had gotten into an argument at the football game.Â  Smith also told the police at the scene that the car was green, while at trial he only remembered that it was dark.Â  
On August 25, 2001, Darryl Mosely was brought to the police station where he provided a statement against the co-defendants, who are his cousins.Â  At trial, Mosely retracted his statement, claiming that he never read the statement, that he was lying because the officers threatened his life, and that they had fed him the details and information in his statement.Â  He did, however, admit on cross-examination that the statement accurately reflected what he told the officer.Â  He also admitted at trial that he had seen the three defendants together before they left the â€œLionâ€™s Den,â€ but that he did not see any of them with a gun.Â  
Moselyâ€™s original statement to police contained more incriminating information.Â  He said that on the night of the incident, he saw Shelton with an SKS rifle and a banana clip strapped around his neck.[3]Â  He stated that the three defendants then got into a green four-door Pontiac Catalina and drove off.Â  
On August 26, 2001, defendant Corey Shelton told Captain Williams where he could locate an AK-47.Â  Officers went to the place he described and found an AK-47, some banana clips for the AK-47, and a .32 caliber revolver.Â  
Defendant Derrick Brown made a statement to Chief Deputy Eddie Smith.Â  In the statement, Brown said that at about 11:00 to 11:30 p.m., on the night of the shooting, he was driving down Pleasant View Drive in his Green Pontiac Catalina and drinking beer when he heard a shot.Â  He said that he thought someone was shooting at him, so he pulled out his .45 caliber pistol and fired it out the window as he drove away.Â  He stated he then hid the gun.Â  Brown claimed he did not know who he was shooting at and did not know Phillip Johnson.Â  After he had made this statement, Brown personally led police to where he hid the .45 caliber pistol.Â  
The SLED examiner found that the bullet fragment taken from Johnson was too damaged to conclusively identify whether it came from Sheltonâ€™s AK-47, but that its characteristics indicated it could have been fired from his weapon.Â  The bullet that killed Johnson was not from a .45 pistol.Â  The fifteen 7.62mm casings found at the scene were the type that could have been fired from Sheltonâ€™s AK-47.Â  All seven of the .45 casings found at the scene were matched to Brownâ€™s .45 caliber pistol.Â  The SLED examiner also conclusively matched the bullet that had penetrated a nearby house to Brownâ€™s pistol.Â  Revolvers like Sheltonâ€™s .32 caliber do not automatically eject casings, which explains why none were found at the scene, but the SLED examiner did conclusively match Sheltonâ€™s revolver to the other bullet that had penetrated a nearby house.Â  
At the end of the Stateâ€™s case and again at the conclusion of the trial, Shelton moved for a directed verdict, arguing the State failed to introduce any evidence he murdered Johnson.Â  The motions were denied, and the jury convicted Shelton of both murder and possession of a firearm during commission of a violent crime.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Shelton challenges the trial judgeâ€™s denial of his motion for a directed verdict.Â  Specifically, he argues that there was not substantial circumstantial evidence that Shelton committed, or aided and abetted the commission of, the murder of Philip Johnson.Â  This argument has no merit.
When reviewing the denial of a directed verdict, a South Carolina appellate court views the evidence in the light most favorable to the State to determine if there is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused.Â  State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 633-34, 591 S.E.2d 600, 605 (2004); State v. Zeigler, 364 S.C. 94, 101-2, 610 S.E.2d 859, 863 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  If there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence which reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused, or from which his guilt can be fairly and logically deduced, then the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  State v. Martin, 340 S.C. 597, 602, 533 S.E.2d 572, 574 (2000); State v. Cooper, 334 S.C. 540, 551-52, 514 S.E.2d 584, 590 (1999).Â  Evidence that merely raises a suspicion the accused is guilty is not sufficient to survive a directed verdict motion.Â  State v. Buckmon, 347 S.C. 316, 321, 555 S.E.2d 402, 404 (2001); State v. Muhammed, 338 S.C. 22, 26, 524 S.E.2d 637, 639 (Ct. App. 1999).Â Â  
Shelton contends that â€œ[a]t best, the State proved that, shortly before Johnson was killed, Shelton was armed with a rifle that could have fired the fatal shot.â€Â  We disagree.
The State introduced substantial circumstantial evidence linking Shelton to Johnsonâ€™s murder. Â The State proved Shelton had an AK-47 with banana clips that fired ammunition consistent with that which killed Johnson, and ejected the same casings as those found in the vicinity of Johnsonâ€™s murder.Â  The State conclusively matched Sheltonâ€™s .32 caliber revolver to a bullet that penetrated a nearby house.Â  The State also introduced a statement from Darryl Mosely that described Shelton on the night of the incident getting into the car, carrying what Mosely described as an SKS rifle with banana clips, along with Brown, who admitted driving the car and firing a pistol at the crime scene.Â  This evidence is sufficient to support submission to the jury.Â  See State v. Weston, 367 S.C 279, 625 S.E.2d 641 (2006)(finding circumstantial evidence sufficient to support conviction for murder where victimâ€™s body was never found but she had mysteriously disappeared,Â  and where physical evidence at the residence defendant and victim shared, alongside defendantâ€™s suspicious behavior indicated a murder might have taken place); State v. Freiburger, 366 S.C. 125, 620 S.E.2d 737 (2005)(finding circumstantial evidence sufficient to support conviction for a cab-driverâ€™sÂ  murder where there was evidence that on the day of the murder, the defendant bought the same type of gun that killed the victim, where two days after the murderÂ  he was staying at a motel close to where the victimâ€™s cab was found, and where the defendant was arrested with the gun that ballistics indicated killed the victim); State v. East, 353 S.C 634, 578 S.E.2d 748, (Ct. App. 2003)(finding defendant not entitled to a directed verdict on one of seven counts of kidnapping where victim of that count did not testify, but other witnesses testified that victim was present at the scene).Â  Given the aforementioned substantial circumstantial evidence linking Brown to the murder, and viewing it in the light most favorable to the State, the circuit courtâ€™s denial of the motion for directed verdict, and submission of the case to the jury, was proper.
CONCLUSION 
Based on the foregoing, the decision of the circuit court is hereby
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215(a), SCACR.Â  
[2] At the conclusion of the Stateâ€™s case, and with the consent of the State, the judge directed a verdict aquitting Latimore. 
[3] An SKS is a Chinese-made rifle very similar to an AK-47, which fires the same ammunition, and the two rifles are commonly referred to by each otherâ€™s names.Â

title: State v. McElveen
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Roy Vance McElveen, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-392
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 6, 2006Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. Mcintosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, Warren Blair Giese, Fifth Circuit Solicitor's Office, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Roy Vance McElveen plead guilty to conspiracy to commit armed robbery and armed robbery.Â  The circuit court sentenced McElveen to five years on the conspiracy charge and twenty years on the armed robbery charge, both sentences to run concurrently.Â  On appeal McElveen argues his plea was not voluntarily and knowingly given, because he was not informed of the maximum or mandatory penalty.Â  We affirm. Â 
FACTS
On June 7, 2004, McElveen and another person attempted to rob Lucille Ogunji.Â  One month later, a Richland County Grand Jury indicted McElveen on one count of conspiracy to commit armed robbery and one count of armed robbery.Â  On May 31, 2005, McElveen, with assistance of counsel, plead guilty to both charges.Â  
Prior to accepting the guilty plea, the circuit court advised McElveen of his constitutional trial rights, including a right to a jury trial, right to counsel, and right to confront and challenge witnesses.Â  However, the circuit court failed to notify McElveen of the maximum or mandatory penalty for each offense.Â  
McElveen now contends his plea was invalid because the circuit court failed to advise him about possible sentences.Â  The State argues McElveen did not challenge the validity of his guilty plea before the circuit court; therefore, the issue is not preserved for appeal. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The State argues the issue of the McElveenâ€™s plea is not preserved for appeal.Â  We agree.
A â€œfailure to object at trial to the involuntary nature of a guilty plea precludes consideration of the issue on appeal.â€Â  State v. McKinney, 278 S.C. 107, 108, 292 S.E.2d 598, 599 (1982); see, e.g., State v. Bradley, 263 S.C. 223, 226, 209 S.E.2d 435, 436 (1974) (failure to assert
at trial a guilty plea was involuntarily entered precludes consideration of such a claim on appeal); In re Arisha K.S., 331 S.C. 288, 293, 501 S.E.2d 128, 131 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œ[C]ounsel [is required] to make an objection to the guilty plea before a defendant is entitled to a review of the voluntariness of his plea on direct appeal.â€).Â  â€œAbsent timely objection at a plea proceeding, the unknowing and involuntary nature of a guilty plea can only be attacked through the more appropriate channel of Post Conviction Relief.â€Â  McKinney, 278 S.C. at 108, 292 S.E.2d at 599.
The record does not indicate McElveen objected to the guilty pleas at the plea proceeding.Â  Therefore, the issue is not preserved for our review.Â  The appropriate means of redress is a post-conviction relief proceeding.Â Â  
 CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.  [1]Â 
ANDERSON, HUFF, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-393
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 6, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Adele Jeffords Pope, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Jan L. Warner and Matthew E. Steinmetz, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: William Graves (â€œSonâ€), as personal representative of the estate of Lawrence Graves (â€œHusbandâ€), appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting Mary Graves (â€œWifeâ€) summary judgment.Â  Son argues the circuit court erred in finding as a matter of law that Wife did not waive her right to an elective share of Husbandâ€™s estate.Â  We affirm.[1]
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Son argues the circuit court erred in refusing to find Wife waived her right to an elective share of Husbandâ€™s estate.Â  â€œIf a married person domiciled in this State dies, the surviving spouse has a right of election to take an elective share of one-third of the decedentâ€™s probate estate . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-2-201(a) (Supp. 2005).Â  â€œThe right of election of a surviving spouse . . . may be waived, wholly or partially, before or after marriage, by a written contract, agreement, or waiver signed by the party waiving after fair disclosure.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-2-204 (1987) (emphasis added); see also Geddings v. Geddings, 319 S.C. 213, 215, 460 S.E.2d 376, 379 (1995) (â€œThe right of election of a surviving spouse may be waived by a written contract signed by the party waiving after fair disclosure.â€ (emphasis added)).Â  Son admits there was no written contract,Â  agreement, or waiver signed by Wife waiving her right to an elective share of Husbandâ€™s estate.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court did not err in granting Wifeâ€™s motion for summary judgment. 
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The remaining issues are affirmed pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities: State v. Rogers, 361 S.C. 178, 183, 603 S.E.2d 910, 912-13 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding that to preserve an issue for appellate review the issue must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge, raised by the appellant, raised in a timely manner, and raised to the trial judge with sufficient specificity); Tallent v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 363 S.C. 160, 165, 609 S.E.2d 544, 546 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œA party cannot use a motion to reconsider, alter or amend a judgment to present an issue that could have been raised prior to the judgment but was not.â€), cert. granted (July 14, 2005); Bodiford v. Spanish Oaks Farms, Inc., 317 S.C. 539, 547, 455 S.E.2d 194, 198-99 (Ct. App. 1995) (noting the appellate court need not address a point that is manifestly without merit). 
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. 

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Knight v. Knight
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Jack (NMN) Knight, Jr., Appellant,
v.
Debra Ann McAbee Knight, Respondent.
In Re:
Debra M. Knight, Plaintiff
v.
Jack Knight, Jr., Defendent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Honorable Brian M. Gibbons, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-394
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 6, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Richard H. Rhodes, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
James C. Cothran, Jr.Â  and Toney J. Lister,Â  both of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Jack Knight (Husband) commenced this action against his ex-wife, Debra Knight (Wife), seeking a termination or reduction in alimony based on the substantial change of circumstances of both Husband and Wife.Â  Wife counterclaimed requesting an increase in alimony as well as attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The family court refused to modify Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation and required each party pay his own attorney fees and costs.Â  Husband appeals, arguing the family court erred by not terminating or reducing his alimony.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities: S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-170 (1985) (authorizing a family court to alter an award of periodic alimony upon a proper showing of changed circumstances); Sharps v. Sharps, 342 S.C. 71, 79, 535 S.E.2d 913, 917 (2000) (finding the modification of alimony is within the sound discretion of the trial court, whose conclusions will not be disturbed absent a showing of abuse of discretion); McKnight v. McKnight, 283 S.C. 540, 324 S.E.2d 91 (Ct. App. 1984) (defining an abuse of discretion as when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of fact is without evidentiary support); Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 486, 477 S.E.2d 727, 729 (Ct. App. 1996) (noting a party seeking a modification of alimony has the burden to show by a preponderance of the evidence that a change has occurred and that the change is either substantial or material and was unanticipated at the time of the divorce decree.); Sharps, 342 S.C. at 76, 535 S.E.2d at 916 (stating that changes in financial status as a result of the property division from a divorce are generally in the contemplation of the parties at the time of the divorce and do not qualify as a substantial change.).
 AFFIRMED
ANDERSON, HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: James v. James
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Stephenson W. James, Respondent,
v.
Ernestine James, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â Wayne M. Creech, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-395
Heard October 12, 2006 â€“ Filed December 6, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Deena Smith McRackan, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Deborah Kay Lewis, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Ernestine James (Wife) appeals the family courtâ€™s order reducing her alimony from $750 per month to $300 per month.Â  She also argues the family court erred in failing to require Stephenson W. James (Husband) to make his future support payments by wage withholding.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
Husband and Wife separated after twenty-five years of marriage. Although Wife sought a divorce on the grounds of adultery, the family court found she had not proven Husband committed adultery and granted a divorce on other grounds.Â  At the time of the divorce, which occurred in 2001, Wife had two jobs: during the day, she worked as a greeter at Wal-Mart, and at night, she worked as a janitor.Â  Husband, who retired from a full career in the military, worked full-time during his retirement as a team leader at Dentyns Shipyards. 
Husbandâ€™s financial declaration reflected a monthly income of only $2,401, although the family court recognized that he made approximately $2,580 per month in 1998, $2,740 per month in 1999, and averaged over $3,700 per month for the first five months of 2000.Â  In contrast, Wifeâ€™s gross monthly income was merely $1,618. The family court ordered Husband to pay Wife alimony in the amount of $750, noting that once the marital home sold, Husband would be relieved of his obligation to pay the $1,100 monthly mortgage.Â  Wife was also awarded 42.5 percent of Husbandâ€™s military retirement benefits.Â  
Four years after alimony was awarded, Husband brought this action seeking a reduction or termination in alimony because his monthly income had been reduced to $2,873.Â  Wife answered the complaint, and by way of counterclaim, requested Husbandâ€™s future alimony payments be paid through wage withholding.Â  A hearing was held on the matter, at which Husband testified that he no longer received an hourly wage and overtime at Dentyns, but instead, received a flat monthly salary of $2,873.[1] Â Husband also argued that Wifeâ€™s monthly income had increased to $2,082.Â  Wife admitted that her income had increased because she was now able to work full-time at Wal-Mart.Â  However, she pointed out that Husbandâ€™s expenses had significantly decreased since the last hearing because he had remarried and was living rent-free in a home owned by his new wife. 
The family court found Husband met his burden of proving a substantial change in circumstances to warrant a reduction in alimony. Accordingly, the court reduced Husbandâ€™s obligation to $300 per month and denied Wifeâ€™s request for wage withholding.Â  Wife filed a Rule 59(e) motion, and Husband filed a return in which he asked for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs for defending the motion for reconsideration.Â  The family court denied Wifeâ€™s motion for reconsideration and ordered her to pay Husband $750 for attorneyâ€™s fees he incurred defending the motion.Â  This appeal followed.[2]
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œQuestions concerning alimony rest with the sound discretion of the trial court, whose conclusions will not be disturbed absent a showing of abuse of discretion.â€Â  Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 485, 477 S.E.2d 727, 729 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of fact, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Wife argues the family court erred in reducing her alimony from $750 per month to $300 per month.Â  We agree.
It is well-settled that ex-spouses may seek modification of alimony based on an unanticipated substantial or material change of either spouseâ€™s circumstances.Â 
Thornton v. Thornton, 328 S.C. 96, 492 S.E.2d 86 (1997); Kelley, 324 S.C. at 485-86, 477 S.E.2d at 729; Calvert v. Calvert, 287 S.C. 130, 138, 336 S.E.2d 884, 888 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  The burden is on the party seeking modification to show by a preponderance of evidence that a material change has occurred.Â  Kelley, 324 S.C. at 486, 477 S.E.2d at 729.Â  â€œThe mere fact that a supporting spouseâ€™s salary or income has been reduced does not of itself require a reduction of . . . alimony[.]â€Â  Calvert, 287 S.C. at 138, 336 S.E.2d at 888-89.Â  â€œA modification [in alimony] is not warranted absent a strong showing by [the paying spouse] that he is no longer in a condition to support his wife . . . as the family court prescribed.â€Â  Id. at 139, 336 S.E.2d at 889.
Initially, we note that the extent to which Husbandâ€™s monthly income declined is difficult to decipher.Â  In the original order setting alimony at $750, the family court never specified the amount of monthly income it was using to determine Husbandâ€™s obligation.Â  Rather, it noted the amount of monthly income Husband declared, $2,400, was lower than the monthly income he had received since 1998.Â  Instead of specifically imputing a monthly income to Husband, the family court acknowledged Husbandâ€™s various incomes since 1998 and, perhaps more importantly, noted that once the marital residence was sold, â€œHusband will be relieved of the obligation of making the mortgage payments for that residence which are now approximately $1,100 per month.â€Â  Additionally, the court explained Husband would no longer have to pay the partiesâ€™ $574 per month consumer credit counseling debt.Â  Based on Husbandâ€™s superior, albeit unspecified, monthly income and the reduction in his expenses, the family court found Husband had the ability to pay Wife $750 per month in alimony.Â  Â Â  
With no specific finding of Husbandâ€™s monthly income in the initial order establishing alimony, Husband cannot contradict his previous financial declaration and argue his former income, which he listed as $2,400 per month, was actually $3,700 per month.Â  See Penny v. Green, 357 S.C. 583, 591, 594 S.E.2d 171, 175 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œA party cannot misrepresent income and expenses on a financial declaration . . . and then refute the accuracy of that document in a subsequent modification action.â€).
Even if we assume the $750 in alimony was based on a monthly income of $3,700, Husband failed to show a material change in circumstances. Â At the modification hearing, Husbandâ€™s gross monthly income still exceeded Wifeâ€™s, and just as the family court had anticipated, Husband shed $1,674 in monthly obligations once the marital residence sold.Â  Despite the purported decline in wages of approximately $800 per month, Husbandâ€™s pension income increased by approximately $100 per month.Â  He has since remarried, and not only enjoys the benefit of his present wifeâ€™s income for sharing household bills, but is also allowed to live rent-free in his present wifeâ€™s home.Â  Thus, even with a $750 per month alimony payment, Husbandâ€™s net income exceeds his expenses by nearly $200. Husband therefore failed to make a strong showing he was no longer in a position to support Wife pursuant to the original order.Â  See Calvert, 287 S.C. at 138, 336 S.E.2d at 889.[3]Â  
Accordingly, we find the family erred in reducing Husbandâ€™s alimony.Â  Instead, we order Husband to continue paying $750 per month to Wife as was originally ordered.Â  Because Wife was entitled to alimony during the pendency of this appeal, we remand this case back to the family court to determine the amount of past alimony due to Wife.
Wife next argues the family court erred in failing to order Husbandâ€™s wages be withheld to meet his monthly alimony obligation.Â  We agree.Â  
In its order reducing alimony, the family court recognized that Husband had sometimes been late in paying Wife her alimony.Â  The family court believed the late payments reflected the difficulty Husband had in meeting his alimony obligation, and in light of its reduction in Husbandâ€™s alimony, the family court declined to impose wage withholding.Â  Because of our reversal of the family courtâ€™s reduction in alimony and Husbandâ€™s history of tardy alimony payments, we find wage withholding appropriate.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find the family court erred in reducing Husbandâ€™s alimony, and we reinstate his obligation to pay Wife $750 per month.Â  In order to determine the amount of past alimony due to Wife, we remand the issue to the family court.Â  Because we reverse the reduction in alimony and in light of Husbandâ€™s history of making late alimony payments to Wife, we order Husbandâ€™s wages be withheld to meet his monthly alimony obligation.Â  Accordingly, the order of the family court is
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and STILWELL and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] Although never mentioned in his complaint, Husband also testified that he had suffered from a partial stroke and was beginning to receive medical bills from his hospital stay.Â  However, Husband also admitted he had returned to work at full capacity, and the family court judge did not mention Husbandâ€™s medical bills as a reason he was reducing alimony.Â  
[2] Wife does not appeal from the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.
[3] We also note that although Husband claims he cannot afford to pay Wife $750 per month, his financial declaration reflects that he pays over $800 per month in car expenses and $50 per month on a loan for his adult daughter.Â  â€œUnwarranted debts, without more, are insufficient to establish changed circumstances or justify [a modification] in alimony.â€Â  Baker v. Baker, 286 S.C. 200, 203, 332 S.E.2d 550, 552 (Ct. App. 1985).

title: Dowd v. Dowd
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
George H. Dowd, III, Respondent,
v.
Ginger W. Dowd, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â  H. T. Abbott, III, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-396
Heard September 27, 2006 â€“ Filed December 6, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Patrick F. Stringer, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Anne Frances Bleecker, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Ginger W. Dowd (Wife) appeals the family courtâ€™s order reducing the alimony she receives from George H. Dowd, III (Husband), to zero based upon a provision in the Final Order and Decree of Divorce.Â  Additionally, Wife maintains the court erred in requiring her to reimburse Husband for alimony paid after the filing of the complaint and pay part of Husbandâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTS
The parties divorced in 1991.Â  The Final Order and Decree of Divorce, dated April 8, 1991, approved and adopted a settlement agreement by the parties.Â  The order provided:Â  

After the marital home is sold, the Husband shall pay seven hundred ($700.00) [d]ollars per month to the Wife as permanent and periodic alimony. . . . If the Wife cohabitates with a man on a continuous and romantic basis, the alimony payment will be reduced to zero (0)[;] however[,] the obligation to pay alimony will not be terminated.Â  

The parties had three daughters during the marriage.Â  Wife was originally granted custody of the children.Â  However, the two older daughters were later allowed to move in with Husband.
In 1990 or 1991 Wife met Skip Joyner at a Parents Without Partners meeting.Â  Wife frequently visited Joynerâ€™s residence and would periodically take the children there for the weekend.Â  Joyner was involved in many activities with the children, including Christmas, vacations, and graduations.Â  In 1992, Joyner adopted a baby girl.Â  Joynerâ€™s daughter was also involved in many of the activities with Wife and her daughters.Â  Wife acted as a mother in helping to raise Joynerâ€™s child.Â  
In 1995, Husband brought an action seeking custody of the partiesâ€™ youngest daughter.Â  A consent order was issued by the court.Â  The parties agreed that Wife would pay no child support and, as a result, the alimony paid by Husband was reduced to $550.00 per month. Â The consent order contained a provision which stated:Â  â€œAll provisions of the Decree of Divorce dated 4-8-91 shall remain in full force and effect except as are expressly modified herein.â€Â  
During the mid 1990â€™s, Wife and Joyner were romantically involved, and, according to Wife, were engaged to be married.Â  Although the engagement ended, the two remained friends.Â  Wife continued to act as a mother figure to Joynerâ€™s child.Â  She was listed as a contact person on the childâ€™s school records and was even listed as the childâ€™s mother on some records.
Wife moved in with Joyner for a period of time in 1999 when she became ill with Reactive Airway Disease.Â  In August of 2000, Husband wrote a letter to Wife seeking to end alimony due to her living with Joyner.Â  Wife subsequently moved in with a roommate and again kept a separate apartment.Â  However, Wife maintained she did not recall receiving a letter from Husband.Â  Â Â 
In 2003, Joyner had a stroke and required care. Â He had a daytime caregiver, and Wife moved in with Joyner in January 2004 to provide his nighttime care.Â  While she received no pay from Joyner for her services as caregiver, she did not have to pay rent to stay at his residence.
Husband brought the instant action on May 27, 2004.Â  The complaint alleged that Wife and Joyner began a relationship in 1990 and â€œbegan living together in approximately 1997.â€ Â In addition, the action asked for reimbursement of attorneyâ€™s fees and all costs.Â  Wife filed an answer and counterclaim, denying the relationship and seeking an increase in alimony.
At the hearing, the partiesâ€™ daughters testified that they spent time at Joynerâ€™s house when they lived with Wife.Â  They testified the easiest way to get in touch with their mother was to call Joynerâ€™s house and leave a message or they would find her already there at all times of day and night.Â  
Husband testified he believed Wife and Joyner lived together from 1997 through at least 2000, when he wrote her the letter seeking to end alimony.Â  Additionally, he testified he did not seek court intervention to reduce the alimony until the partiesâ€™ youngest daughter had graduated college.Â  Finally, he admitted he did not know where Wife was living at the time of the hearing, only that she admitted residing with Joyner for the previous six months.Â  
Wife admitted she and Joyner were previously engaged to be married and that the relationship was more than friends at that time.Â  However, she asserted that she maintained a separate residence for the majority of the time since her divorce.Â  She conceded to living with Joyner during 1999 and again at the time of the filing of the instant action.Â  However, she stated the move in 1999 was due to her illness, and the recent cohabitation was for the purpose of providing Joynerâ€™s care.Â  Wife stated she acted as Joynerâ€™s primary caregiver after his stroke and moved into his residence solely for that reason.Â  Wife testified she slept on his couch or in a spare room, and she and Joyner did not have sex after his stroke.Â  
Joyner also testified that the relationship with Wife was not romantic when she moved in with him after his stroke.Â  While he indicated Wife was the last person with whom he had a sexual relationship before his stroke, he also maintained it was not a recent sexual relationship.Â  Joyner testified Wife slept on his couch or in a spare room rent free.Â  He also admitted to giving her money to pay bills, but denied they had any joint accounts or that they commingled funds.Â  Finally, Joyner stated he was engaged at the time of the hearing to another woman.
The trial court found Wife and Joyner â€œenjoyed a relationship that lasted for 15 or more years.â€Â  The court placed emphasis on the testimony regarding Joynerâ€™s adopted child and the relationship between Wife and the child.Â  Additionally, the court found:Â  

Our laws do not allow a supported spouse to purposefully circumvent the prohibition against romantic cohabitation in order to continue receiving alimony.Â  I find [Wife] cohabitated with a man (Joyner) and, therefore, [Husbandâ€™s] alimony obligation is reduced to zero.

The court then ordered Wife to reimburse Husband for alimony paid from the date he filed the complaint, totaling $7,700.00.Â  Finally, the court ordered Wife to pay $15,000.00 in Husbandâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
The courtâ€™s decision to reduce the alimony to zero was based solely on the provision in the coupleâ€™s agreement and the Divorce Decree.Â  It was not based on a finding of a change in Wifeâ€™s economic condition.Â  However, the family court did not address whether Wifeâ€™s cohabitation with Joyner was romantic at the time the complaint was filed.Â  
Wifeâ€™s motion to alter or amend was denied by the family court.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992); Owens v. Owens, 320 S.C. 543, 546, 466 S.E.2d 373, 375 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981); Miles v. Miles, 355 S.C. 511, 516, 586 S.E.2d 136, 139 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Questions concerning alimony are left to the sound discretion of the trial judge, whose conclusions will not be disturbed absent a showing of abuse of discretion.Â  Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 485, 477 S.E.2d 727, 729 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the court is controlled by some error of law or
where the order, based upon the findings of fact, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Engle v. Engle, 343 S.C. 444, 448-49, 539 S.E.2d 712, 714 (Ct. App. 2000).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Reduction in Alimony
Wife argues the family court erred in reducing her alimony pursuant to the provision in the Final Order and Decree of Divorce.Â  Wife claims, although she had cohabitated in the past with Joyner in a romantic relationship, the court was in error because she was not presently cohabitating in a romantic relationship at the time the underlying action was filed.Â  Further, she contends the court erred in reducing the alimony to zero and requiring her to reimburse Husband for alimony paid after the filing of the complaint.Â  We affirm.
An unambiguous marital agreement incorporated into the partiesâ€™ divorce decree will be enforced according to the terms of the agreement.Â  Heins v. Heins, 344 S.C. 146, 158, 543 S.E.2d 224, 230 (Ct. App. 2001); see also Lindsay v. Lindsay, 328 S.C. 329, 491 S.E.2d 583 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œWhere an agreement is clear and capable of legal construction, the courtâ€™s only function is to interpret its lawful meaning and the intention of the parties as found within the agreement and give effect to it.â€Â  Ebert v. Ebert, 320 S.C. 331, 338, 465 S.E.2d 121, 125 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  
â€œWhen an agreement is unambiguous, effect should be given according to the ordinary and popular sense of the words employed therein.â€Â  Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302, 308, 608 S.E.2d 147, 150 (Ct. App. 2005). Â â€œThe court must enforce an unambiguous contract according to its terms, regardless of the contractâ€™s wisdom or folly, or the partiesâ€™ failure to guard their rights carefully.â€Â  Heins, 344 S.C. at 158, 543 S.E.2d at 230 (citing Ellis v. Taylor, 316 S.C. 245, 449 S.E.2d 487 (1994)).Â  
The relevant provision in this case states:Â  â€œIf the Wife cohabitates with a man on a continuous and romantic basis, the alimony payment will be reduced to zero (0)[;] however[,] the obligation to pay alimony will not be terminated.â€ Â We find the provision is unambiguous and states clearly the conditions required for a reduction of the alimony payment to zero dollars.Â  Accordingly, the family court and this court are required to enforce the agreement pursuant to its terms.
Section 20-3-150 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides insight into the ordinary and popular definition of the terms used in the provision:Â  â€œâ€˜continued cohabitationâ€™ means the supported spouse resides with another person in a romantic relationship for a period of ninety or more consecutive days.â€Â  The key term in this case is romantic which, while not specifically requiring the parties to have sexual relations, does require some level of intimacy and affection beyond that of an ordinary friendship. Â Â 
The family court based its decision on the fact that Wife and Joyner were in a relationship for a period of fifteen years.Â  During that time Wife and Joyner became temporarily engaged and the relationship took on romantic qualities.Â  Also, during the course of their fifteen year relationship, Wife acted as a mother to Joynerâ€™s adopted daughter to the extent that the daughter believed Wife was, in fact, her mother.Â  Eventually, after Joynerâ€™s stroke, Wife moved in with Joyner as his caregiver and, in lieu of pay, lived rent free.Â  Wife also admitted she was living with Joyner when the underlying action was commenced, but maintains the relationship was not sexual.Â  We find there is evidence in the record to support a conclusion that Wifeâ€™s relationship with Joyner was more intimate than one between friends.Â  Therefore, we affirm the reduction of alimony to zero pursuant to the Final Order and Decree of Divorce.Â  We also affirm the courtâ€™s order requiring Wife to reimburse Husband for alimony payments since the filing of the underlying complaint.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Wife contends the court erred in requiring her to pay $15,000 of Husbandâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We agree.
The decision whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees is a matter within the family courtâ€™s sound discretion and will not be overturned absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 415, 368 S.E.2d 901, 903 (1988).Â  In determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the court should consider the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own fees, the beneficial results obtained by the attorney, the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, and the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).
Husband is in a much greater financial position to pay his own attorneyâ€™s fees compared to Wife.Â  According to financial declarations provided by the parties, Husband earns around $6,000 per month more than Wife.Â  In addition, Husband has approximately $350,000 more total property than Wife.Â  After subtracting spousal support pursuant to our holding in this case, Wife has a net monthly income of roughly $1,150.Â  Wifeâ€™s total property is valued at around $30,000.Â  Wife has far fewer assets and earnings than Husband.Â  In addition, Husband has the ability to pay his own fees, while Wifeâ€™s standard of living will be greatly decreased if she is forced to pay Husbandâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees in addition to her own.Â  Accordingly, based on our own review of the factors outlined in E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992), we find both parties shall bear the burden of their own attorneyâ€™s fees in the family court.
CONCLUSION
We find there is evidence in the record to support the family courtâ€™s decision to reduce alimony to zero pursuant to the agreement incorporated into the Final Order and Decree of Divorce.Â  Additionally, we find that, analyzing this case under the factors outlined in E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992), it was error to require Wife to pay $15,000 of Husbandâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Therefore, the family courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART.
HEARN, C.J., WILLIAMS, J., and KEMMERLIN A.J., concur.

title: State v. Donaldson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Antwan L. Donaldson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Barnwell County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-397
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 6, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Antwan L. Donaldson was convicted of armed robbery and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  The trial court sentenced him to concurrent prison terms of twenty-five years for armed robbery and five years for the weapons offense.Â  Donaldson appeals, arguing the trial court erred in refusing to order a competency evaluation.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities:
As to preservation of the issue of competency to stand trial:Â  Monahan v. State, 365 S.C. 130, 133, 616 S.E.2d 422, 423 (2005) (stating competency to stand trial is a distinct issue from criminal responsibility for an offense; competency to stand trial involves the defendantâ€™s mental health at the time of trial, whereas the test for criminal responsibility concerns the defendantâ€™s mental health at the time of the offense); State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 693-94 (2003) (â€œIn order for an
issue to be preserved for appellate review, it must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge.
Â Issues not raised and ruled upon in the trial court will not be considered on
appeal.â€); State v. Richardson, 358 S.C. 586, 595, 595 S.E.2d 858, 862 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding a party may not argue one ground at trial when alleging error and then argue another ground on appeal).
As to the merits:Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-23-410 (2002) (providing a judge shall order an evaluation whenever the judge â€œhas reason to believe that a person on trial before him, charged with the commission of a criminal offense or civil contempt, is not fit to stand trial because the person lacks the capacity to understand the proceedings against him or to assist in his own defense as a result of a lack of mental capacity . . . .â€)[2]; State v. Locklair, 341 S.C. 352, 364, 535 S.E.2d 420, 426 (2000) (â€œDespite the mandatory language of the statute requiring a judge to order a competency examination if there is reason to believe that a person charged with a criminal offense is not fit to stand trial, ordering a competency examination is within the discretion of the trial judge and a refusal to grant an examination will not be disturbed on appeal absent a clear showing of an abuse of discretion.â€); State v. Blair, 275 S.C. 529, 533, 273 S.E.2d 536, 538 (1981) (stating evidence of a defendantâ€™s irrational behavior, his demeanor at trial, and any prior medical opinion as to his competency to stand trial are all relevant in determining whether a defendant is entitled to a hearing on his competency to stand trial); State v. Burgess, 356 S.C. 572, 575, 590 S.E.2d 42, 44 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œBy statute, the question of whether a defendant is fit to stand trial depends upon whether the defendant, because of a lack of mental capacity, cannot â€˜understand the proceedingsâ€™ or â€˜assist in his [or her] own defense.â€™â€ (alteration in original) (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-23-410 (2002))); see also State v. Beckham, 273 S.C. 755, 757, 259 S.E.2d 610, 611 (1979) (â€œThe law is well-settled that a motion for a
continuance is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial judge, and his ruling will not be disturbed by this
court absent a showing of abuse of discretion.â€).
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Section 44-23-410 has recently been amended by 2006 S.C. Acts 400.Â  The relevant language quoted here is not affected by the amendment, but it is now found at section 44-23-410(A).
