title: State v. Houston
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State Respondent,
v.
        James Michael Houston Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-398
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 7, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
W. Douglas Richardson, Jr., of Easley, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman M. Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Â Â James Michael Houston (â€œHoustonâ€) was convicted of third degree burglary and petit larceny.Â  He was sentenced to eighteen months for the burglary charge and thirty days for larceny.Â  Houston appeals, arguing the judge erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On the morning of Sunday, March 7, 2004, police responded to a burglary complaint at ZJâ€™s Mobile Homes, a business involved in the refurbishing and reselling of used mobile homes.Â  The police met with the manager, Brenda Dill, and obtained statements from two eyewitnesses, Frank Barnes and Danny Underwood.Â  The police report indicated â€œa standard mobile home bathtub, white in color, approximately five feet long, and a box containing about six indoor faucetsâ€ were reported stolen from one of the mobile homes and placed in a green Cadillac.
The two witnesses identified Warren Paul Haney (â€œHaneyâ€) and Houston as the perpetrators of the crime.Â  A four-door, green Cadillac was found to be registered to Houston.Â  The police did not obtain search warrants for the homes of the two men.Â  The stolen items were never recovered.Â  The crime scene was not dusted for fingerprints, as police felt there was no good place in the unfurnished mobile home to check for fingerprints and that â€œthe best surface to print was probably the tub itself, which they had carried away . . . .â€ Â Â No other evidence was recovered from the crime scene.Â  
As a result of the witnessesâ€™ reports and police investigation, Houston and Haney were arrested and indicted for third degree burglary and petit larceny.Â  The two men were tried together.
Frank Barnes worked at ZJâ€™s performing general remodeling work for more than two years.Â  Barnes testified that although ZJâ€™s is not open on Sundays, on the day in question, Underwood picked him up and drove to ZJâ€™s so they could â€œget caught upâ€ on some carpet installation they had been asked to perform.Â  
Barnes testified that when he pulled up at the front entrance to the business, he observed Haney and Houston putting a bathtub from one of the mobile homes into the back of a green Cadillac.Â  Barnes recognized Haney, because they had worked together at ZJâ€™s.Â  Barnes and Underwood slowed their vehicle but did not stop.Â  Barnes testified he and Underwood parked near the office and walked back to the mobile home to see the men, but by that point, Haney and Houston were gone.Â  
Barnes recalled he had recently worked in the mobile home and there was a bathtub either installed or sitting inside the mobile home at the time.Â  Barnes testified that he had worked in that same mobile home with Haney. Â He stated the mobile home was not locked after they finished working in it and that most of the mobile homes at ZJâ€™s stayed unlocked.Â  Barnes also recalled that Haney took his tools with him when they finished their work.Â  
Danny Underwood also worked at ZJâ€™s.Â  Underwood testified that he had known Haney for approximately 30 years.Â  Before working at ZJâ€™s, Underwood had worked for Haney for around two years and had previously helped Houston with a few projects.
Underwood testified that as soon as he and Barnes drove into ZJâ€™s lot, Underwood observed what he recognized as Houstonâ€™s Cadillac parked in front of a mobile home in which he had been working.Â  Underwood testified that Houston stood on the steps of the mobile home â€œcoming out the doorâ€ and that Haney â€œwas putting the bathtub in the back seat.â€Â  Underwood observed them for three or four minutes, trying to ascertain what it was Haney and Houston were doing, but by the time he parked his vehicle and walked to the mobile home, Haney and Houston had left.Â  
Underwood explained that the bathtub was approximately fifty-three to fifty-four inches long and twenty-six to twenty-seven inches high.Â  It has only one side, because â€œthe rest of it mounts around the wallâ€ with screws and brackets.Â  The tub was made of thin plastic, not fiberglass, so that â€œ[y]ou can bow that bathtub so it will fit the wall so you ainâ€™t got to tear that wall out of the mobile home.â€Â  Underwood said the tub would buckle and was â€œflexible,â€ but would not fold up.Â  Underwood recalled the bathtub was not â€œhangingâ€ out the window of the car.Â  
Underwood testified that he and Haney put the bathtub in the mobile home a week before the burglary.Â  He said that Haney then quit his job at ZJâ€™s.Â  Underwood said that the bathtub was inside the mobile home on the night before the burglary.Â  He stated, â€œ[W]e set the bathtub in and it was supposed to be installed, but I had to go do something else so I never made it back up there.Â  So I assumed it was installed, but evidently it hadnâ€™t been, because they didnâ€™t tear the wall.Â  He didnâ€™t tear the screws or nothing out.â€Â  Underwood testified that Haney left no tools in the mobile home, but he left a stepladder, which was still there after the burglary. 
Brenda Dill testified that she hired Haney in November 2003.Â  He was paid by the job and allowed to bring a helper (Underwood) with him to work.Â  Dill explained that she and Haney â€œagreed to go separate waysâ€ and that Haney left on â€œdecent terms.â€Â  There was no agreement for Haney to finish any work.Â  She had never before seen Houston at ZJâ€™s.Â  Dill stated that Houston did not have permission to enter the mobile home and that Haney did not have permission to enter the mobile home after he stopped working there.Â  
Dill stated that the stolen bathtub cost about two hundred dollars.Â  The faucets were around thirty-nine dollars.Â  She explained that every evening when she closes the business, she checks all the mobile homes to make sure the windows and doors are shut.Â  Dill went through the mobile home and â€œjust pulled [the door] shut [and] went to the next one.â€Â  She did not lock the door and admitted that all the trailers remain unlocked â€œmost of the time.â€ Â Dill closed ZJâ€™s around four oâ€™clock on Saturday.Â  She was the last person to leave. 
Dill testified that the tub was still in the mobile home when she closed Saturday.Â  She stated, â€œIt was sitting in the slot, in the opening where it belongs, and it was partially in, but not completed . . . .â€Â  No plumbing or other installation had been done.Â  She explained, â€œWe may leave things undone in one we donâ€™t have a deal working on.â€Â  She did not see any tools or a ladder in the mobile home when she walked through it. 
Dill testified that, on past occasions, she had transported these types of bathtubs in the back seat of her mid-sized Chrysler Cirrus.
Houston testified in his own defense.Â  Houston stated that he sold â€œhigh-endâ€ manufactured and modular homes for the Gallery of Homes in Powdersville.Â  Houston testified that he drove to ZJâ€™s with Haney on the Sunday morning in question so Haney could â€œshow [him] the work he had personally done in the kitchen putting the cabinets in this particular home.â€Â  He stated that he and Haney went into the mobile home and that Haney retrieved his triangle and a ladder, which he then put in the back seat of the car. Houston believed they were there for about five minutes.Â  Houston said he saw Barnes and Underwood pull into the lot.Â  Houston claimed that neither he nor Haney went into the bathroom of the mobile home or put a bathtub in his backseat.Â  He said the type of tub stolen would not be used in any of his mobile homes.Â  Houston admitted that he did not have permission to enter the mobile home. 
At trial, Houston moved for a directed verdict in his favor, arguing the evidence did not establish that he intended to commit a crime in the mobile home or that he intended to steal the property.Â  The judge denied this motion.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict against a criminal defendant, an appellate court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 46, 515 S.E.2d 525, 531 (1999).Â  The appellate court may reverse the trial judgeâ€™s denial of a motion for a directed verdict only if there is no evidence to support the judgeâ€™s ruling.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 546, 555, 564 S.E.2d 87, 82 (2002).Â  It is well settled that â€œif there is any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, an appellate court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.â€Â  State v. Lollis, 343 S.C. 580, 584, 541 S.E.2d 254, 256 (2001); see also State v. Horton, 359 S.C. 555, 598 S.E.2d 279 (Ct. App. 2004) (noting a trial judge should deny a motion for a directed verdict if there is any direct of substantial circumstantial evidence which reasonably tends to prove the accusedâ€™s guilt or from which guilt can be fairly and logically deduced).
DISCUSSION
When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial judge is concerned with the existence of evidence, not its weight.Â  Burdette, 335 S.C. at 46, 515 S.E.2d at 531.Â  A defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged or raises a mere suspicion that the defendant is guilty.Â  See State v. Arnold, 361 S.C. 386, 390, 605 S.E.2d 529, 531 (2004); State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 97, 544 S.E.2d 30, 36 (2001).Â  However, a trial judge is not required to find that the evidence infers guilt to the exclusion of any other reasonable hypothesis.Â  State v. Zeigler, 364 S.C. 94, 102-103, 610 S.E.2d 859, 863 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
The offense of third degree burglary requires, among other things, evidence that the defendant entered a building with the intent to commit a crime therein.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-313 (2003).Â  Absent an admission by the defendant, intent may be inferred from his conduct.Â  State v. Haney, 257 S.C. 89, 91-92, 184 S.E.2d 344, 345 (1971).Â  Larceny is the taking and carrying away of the goods of another against the ownerâ€™s will or without his consent and with the felonious intent to permanently deprive the owner of his property and to convert it to the use of the taker.Â  State v. Williams, 237 S.C. 252, 116 S.E.2d 858, (1960); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-30(A) (2003) (proving the statutory maximum value for petit larceny).
It is undisputed that Houston drove Haney to ZJâ€™s on the Sunday morning in question, a time when ZJâ€™s was not open for business.Â  The two men entered the mobile home where Haney had previously been working.Â  Neither Haney nor Houston had permission to be there.Â  Houston was seen coming out of the mobile home while Haney was loading the stolen bathtub into Houstonâ€™s automobile.Â  Considered in the light most favorable to the State, this was more than sufficient evidence that Houston was not only present in the mobile home but was also involved with Haney in the commission of a burglary and larceny of the property in question.Â  State v. Crawford, 362 S.C. 627, 608 S.E.2d 886 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Burdette, 335 S.C. at 45, 515 S.E.2d at 531 (stating when two or more persons aid, abet, and encourage one another in the commission of a crime, all being present, each is guilty as a principal); State v. Chavis, 277 S.C. 521, 522, 290 S.E.2d 412, 412-413 (1982) (holding that when several people pursue a common design to commit an unlawful act, the act of one is the act of all, and all are presumed to be present and guilty); State v. Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 193-95, 562 S.E.2d 320, 324 (Ct. App. 2002) (holding that â€œunder the â€˜hand of one is the hand of allâ€™ theory, one who joins with another to accomplish an illegal purpose is liable criminally for everything done by his confederate incident to the execution of the common design or purposeâ€).
Intent is seldom susceptible to proof by direct evidence and must ordinarily be proven by facts and circumstances from which intent may be inferred.Â  State v. Tuckness, 257 S.C. 295, 185 S.E.2d 607 (1971).Â  The salient circumstances previously noted were more than sufficient to demonstrate Houstonâ€™s intent that morning.Â  Additionally, the intent to commit a crime could be inferred from the breaking and entering into the mobile home.Â  See State v. Perry, 279 S.C. 539, 309 S.E.2d 9 (1983) (holding that where the defendant was apprehended while attempting to flee the grounds of a school which had just recently been broken into, her intent to commit a crime therein was properly left for the jury to decide); Haney, 257 S.C. 89, 184 S.E.2d 344 (holding evidence of the intent to commit a crime was sufficient because the defendant broke into a room where movie projectors and other visual aids were kept and the unexplained breaking and entry was itself evidence of intent to commit larceny); see also State v. Pinckney, 339 S.C. 346, 529 S.E.2d 526 (2000) (stating a personâ€™s actions after entering a house may be evidence of the personâ€™s intent to commit a crime at the time of entry).
Notwithstanding direct evidence of the crimes and Houstonâ€™s participation in them, the lack of any other physical evidence (such as fingerprints inside the mobile home or Houstonâ€™s possession of the stolen property) was a factual issue for the jury to consider and does not undermine the verdict.Â  State v. Davenport, 321 S.C. 134, 137, 467 S.E.2d 258, 260 n.2 (Ct. App. 1995); State v. Smith, 307 S.C. 376, 385, 415 S.E.2d 409, 414 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  The motion for a directed verdict was properly refused.
CONCLUSION 
Accordingly, the trial judge did not err in refusing to direct a verdict in Houstonâ€™s favor and his convictions are
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Cooksey v. Wachovia Bank
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Jean E. Cooksey Appellant,
v.
Wachovia Bank, N.A. Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Roger L. Couch, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-399
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 7, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James J. Raman, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
Thomas E. Lydon, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Jean E. Cooksey (â€œCookseyâ€) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting a directed verdict for Wachovia Bank, N.A. (â€œWachoviaâ€).Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
As early as May 2002, Cooksey maintained a personal checking account with Wachovia.Â  This account was primarily funded through Social Security benefits deposited into the account on a monthly basis via direct deposit.Â  In addition to the Social Security funds, Cooksey occasionally made other deposits into the account.Â  Along with the above-mentioned personal checking account, Cooksey maintained a Wachovia joint checking account with her husband.Â  Overdraft protection was provided to this joint checking account through a â€œReady Reserveâ€ account Wachovia provided the couple. 
The Ready Reserve account was not paid according to its terms and was ultimately charged off by Wachovia.Â  To recover this debt, Wachovia offset Cookseyâ€™s personal checking account by the amount owed.Â  As a consequence of the offset and the resulting lower balance in her personal checking account, several checks written by Cooksey were returned for insufficient funds.Â  These bounced checks caused her to incur various penalties and fees from Wachovia and several of the checksâ€™ named payees.
From May 20, 2002 through June 17, 2004, a total of $18,722.00 in Social Security benefits was deposited into Cookseyâ€™s personal account.Â  Deposits other than Social Security totaled $7,520.52, bringing the total for all deposits to $26,242.52.Â  During this approximately two-year period, Cooksey wrote checks on her Wachovia account totaling $18,805.43, leaving a remaining balance of $7,437.09.Â  
The offset to the Ready Reserve took place on May 19, 2004 and was for the sum of $5,188.76.Â  This amount, which was less than the net remaining balance, was approximately $2,000 less than the non-Social Security deposits made by Cooksey into her personal checking account.Â  Phrased differently, the total of the non-Social Security funds deposited into Cookseyâ€™s checking account during the two years prior to the offset exceeded the amount offset by Wachovia.Â  
Cooksey brought this action alleging wrongful dishonor and wrongful offset.Â  The underlying basis for the claims is that Wachovia did not have the right to offset Cookseyâ€™s account because the funds in the account were received from Social Security benefits.Â  At trial, upon the conclusion of Cookseyâ€™s case, Wachovia moved for a directed verdict, which the judge granted.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œ[O]nly where there is no evidence to support the ruling, or where the ruling in controlled by an error of lawâ€ should an appellate court overturn the grant of a directed verdict.Â  Hinkle v. Natâ€™l Cas. Ins. Co., 354 S.C. 92, 96, 579 S.E.2d 616, 618 (2003).Â  â€œEssentially, our court must resolve whether it would be reasonably conceivable to have a verdict for a party opposing the motion under facts as liberally construed in the opposing partyâ€™s favor.â€ Â Huffines Co., LLC v. Lockhart, 365 S.C. 178, 188-189, 617 S.E.2d 125,130 (Ct. App. 2005) (internal citations omitted).
DISCUSSION
1. The Grant of the Directed Verdict
Cooksey contends that the trial court improperly granted the motion for a directed verdict at the conclusion of Cookseyâ€™s case, because Wachovia had not yet presented evidence of affirmative defenses.Â  However, the trial judgeâ€™s ruling was not in response to any of Wachoviaâ€™s affirmative defenses, but was instead because Cookseyâ€™s legal theory, that the Social Security funds deposited in her checking account were exempt from offset, was incorrect.Â  Additionally, the trial court found the evidence established that, even if such benefits were exempt, there were sufficient non-exempt funds deposited into Cookseyâ€™s account to cover the offset sum.
Furthermore, even if the trial courtâ€™s ruling was based on affirmative defenses, there is nothing that prevents a defendant from proving such defenses through witnesses and evidence presented by the plaintiff.Â  While it is well settled that the party asserting an affirmative defense bears the burden of establishing that defense through a preponderance of the evidence, Lorick & Lowrance, Inc. v. Julius H. Walker & Co., 153 S.C. 309, 318, 150 S.E. 789, 792 (1929); see also 61A Am. Jur. 2d Pleading Â§ 298 (1999), a directed verdict may be granted based on an affirmative defense at the conclusion of the plaintiffâ€™s case without requiring the defendant to prove the defenses through its case-in-chief.Â  See Eargle v. Sumter Lighting Co., 110 S.C. 560, 566, 96 S.E. 909, 911 (1918) (â€œWe have held in numerous cases . . . a nonsuit should have been granted at the conclusion of the plaintiffâ€™s testimony . . . .â€).Â  Evidence of an affirmative defense is not limited to that which is presented by the party asserting the defense.Â  See id. (â€œIt is immaterial from whose witnesses--whether plaintiffâ€™s or defendantâ€™s--the evidence in support of an element of damage or of the cause of action or defense may come.Â  Either party has the right to make out or strengthen its case or defense on the examination of the witness of his adversary.â€).Â  
Accordingly, the trial court properly granted Wachoviaâ€™s motion for a directed verdict at the conclusion of Cookseyâ€™s case, without requiring Wachovia to present its defense.
2. Offset Against Funds
Cookseyâ€™s claim for wrongful dishonor and wrongful offset is predicated on the theory that Social Security benefits are exempt from offset under state and federal law.Â  She contends the funds in her checking account were not subject to offset because they were comprised, at least in part, of her Social Security income.Â  However, the statutes that protect such benefits from attachment, levy and garnishment do not apply to protect these funds from offsets.Â  
South Carolina recognizes a common law right of offset.Â  Lee v. Marion National Bank, 167 S.C. 168, 166 S.E. 148 (1932).Â  If a depositor is indebted to his bank, â€œthe bank has the right to offset the indebtedness by the depositâ€“unless there are conditions or agreements attending the deposit which preclude it.â€Â  Lee, 167 S.C. at 200, 166 S.E. at 160.Â  
With regard to the protection afforded Social Security benefits under federal law, the United States Code provides that the â€œright of any person to any future payment under this subchapter shall not be transferable or assignable, at law or in equity, and none of the moneys paid or payable or rights existing under this subchapter shall be subject to execution, levy attachment, garnishment, or other legal process, or to the operation of any bankruptcy or insolvency law.â€Â  42 U.S.C. Â§ 407(a) (1998).Â  In interpreting the extent of the protection provided by this statute, the United States Supreme Court, in Washington State v. Keffeler, 537 U.S. 371, 123 S.Ct. 1017 (2003), construed this statute very narrowly.Â  
In Keffeler, the state of Washington provided foster care to certain children removed from their parentsâ€™ custody and received Social Security benefits as the representative payee for many of those children.Â  Keffeler filed a class action, alleging, inter alia, that the stateâ€™s use of benefits to reimburse itself for the foster case costs violated 42 U.S.C. Â§ 407(a).Â  The Supreme Court held that attachment, levy, or other legal process contemplates the utilization of some judicial or quasi-judicial mechanism and that neither the stateâ€™s effort to become a representative payee, nor its use of Keffelerâ€™s Social Security benefits when it acted in that capacity, amounted to employing an â€œexecution, levy, attachment, garnishment, or other legal processâ€ under Â§ 407(a).Â  Because the stateâ€™s activities did not involve any of the specified formal procedures, such as execution, attachment, levy, or garnishment, the issue was whether the stateâ€™s actions constituted â€œother legal process.â€Â  The court reasoned that the statute uses that term restrictively, and under the established interpretive canons of noscitur a sociis and ejusdem generis, where general words follow specific words in a statutory enumeration, the general words are construed to embrace only objects similar to those enumerated by the specific words.Â  Keffeler, 537 U.S. 371, 372, 123 S.Ct. 1017, 1019. Â Thus, â€œother legal processâ€ should be understood to be a process much like execution, levy, attachment, and garnishment.Â  At a minimum, it would require utilization of some judicial or quasi-judicial mechanism by which control over property passes from one person to another in order to discharge or secure discharge of an allegedly existing or anticipated liability. 
South Carolina law provides a similar protection for Social Security benefits, stating that Social Security benefits are â€œexempt from attachment, levy, and sale under any mesne or final process issued by any court or bankruptcy proceeding . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-41-30(10)(a) (2005).Â  However, like its federal counterpart, the statute does not provide protection from offset.Â  The reasoning and analysis of the United States Supreme Court in Keffeler can be applied to the South Carolina statute.Â  Nothing in Section 15-41-30 addresses the issue of offsets.Â  Instead, the state makes reference only to a â€œprocess issued by any court or bankruptcy proceeding . . . .â€Â  The law is clearly directed only to judicial mechanisms for the collection of debts.Â  Thus, there is no basis for Cookseyâ€™s contention that Social Security benefits are protected from offset.
Absent a statute or other law or regulation that prohibits offsets against funds received from Social Security, Cookseyâ€™s claims of wrongful setoff and wrongful dishonor fail as a matter of law.
3. Non-Social Security Deposits Exceeded the Amount Offset
The total amount of funds deposited into Cookseyâ€™s checking account from sources other than social security exceeded the amount of offset.Â  As such, Cooksey cannot show the offset that occurred was against the social security benefits and not the funds from other sources.Â  As reflected in the exhibits presented by Cooksey at trial, the total of the non-Social Security funds deposited into her checking account during the approximately two-year period prior to the offset exceeded the amount offset by Wachovia.Â  During this time, a total of $18,722.00 in Social Security benefits was deposited into Cookseyâ€™s account.Â  Deposits other than Social Security totaled $7,520.52, so that the total of all deposits was $26,242.52.Â  
Throughout this two year period, Cooksey wrote checks on her Wachovia account totaling $18,805.43, leaving the remaining balance $7,437.09.Â  The amount of the offset was $5,188.76.Â  This amount was substantially less than the non-Social Security deposits she made and was less than the net balance remaining in her account.Â  Therefore, even if Cookseyâ€™s Social Security benefits were exempt from offset, her checking account contained sufficient deposits from other sources to cover the offset.Â  As a result, Cooksey did not present facts to support her claims of wrongful offset and wrongful dishonor.
CONCLUSION
The evidence presented by Cooksey was insufficient to establish the causes of action alleged and thus supports the directed verdict award.Â  Likewise, Cookseyâ€™s legal theory underlying her claims was incorrect, and the trial judge correctly ruled on the legal issues in granting Wachoviaâ€™s motion. Moreover, the evidence presented at trial established that she deposited funds from sources other than Social Security that exceeded the amount of the offset.Â  Therefore, neither a legal nor factual basis for the claims against Wachovia existed.Â  The trial courtâ€™s ruling correctly granted a directed verdict in favor of Wachovia and accordingly is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

Appellants, Gene Sheryl Nix, Sandra Dianne Nix and Dewayne Nix (hereinafter either referred to individually or jointly asâ€œIntervenorsâ€) appeal the trial courtâ€™s order denying their motion to intervene, arguing that their participation and the relief the


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State Respondent,
v.
Derek J. Brown Appellant,
      
    
  


Appeal from Laurens County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge 

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2006-UP-400
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 7, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney Donald J. Zelenka,Â  Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Jerry W. Peace, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Derek J. Brown appeals his convictions for murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, for which he received concurrent sentences of life imprisonment and five years, respectively. Â Brown argues the trial judge erred by refusing to direct a verdict acquitting him of the charges.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
This case involves the drive-by shooting of fourteen-year-old Phillip Johnson, Jr. on August 4, 2001.Â  Corey Shelton, Derek Brown, and Ricky Latimore were indicted with murder and possession of a firearm or a knife during commission of a violent crime in connection with this incident.[2]Â  
On the night of the shooting, Johnson, his cousin Xavier Smith, and a number of friends attended a high school football game.Â  After leaving the football game, the boys went to a friendâ€™s house on Pleasant View Drive, and â€œhung outâ€ with ten to twelve boys in the front yard.Â  Smith testified that around 11:00 to 11:30 p.m., a large, dark-colored car, which had been parked nearby when the boys arrived, came down the road with two guns firing out the windows.Â  Someone in the group fired back at the car as it drove away.Â  Johnson was shot in the drive-by.Â  
Johnson died from his gunshot wound on the way to the hospital.Â  Bullet fragments removed from his body were sent to SLED for testing.Â  At the scene, officers found fifteen 7.62mm casings, seven .45 casings, as well as a 9mm casing.Â  Bullets that penetrated a nearby residence were also sent to SLED for testing.Â  
Smith could not identify the people in the assailantâ€™s car.Â  Directly after the drive-by, he gave the police the names of Terrence Bishop, Darrell Brown, and â€œK,â€ but testified that those were just the names of some boys with whom he had gotten into an argument at the football game.Â  Smith also told the police at the scene that the car was green, while at trial he only remembered that it was dark.Â  
On August 25, 2001, Darryl Mosely was brought to the police station where he provided a statement against the co-defendants, who are his cousins.Â  At trial, Mosely retracted his statement, claiming that he never read the statement, that he was lying because the officers threatened his life, and that they had fed him the details and information in his statement.Â  He did, however, admit on cross-examination that the statement accurately reflected what he told the officer.Â  He also admitted at trial that he had seen the three defendants together before they left the â€œLionâ€™s Den,â€ but that he did not see any of them with a gun.Â  
Moselyâ€™s original statement to police contained more incriminating information.Â  He said that on the night of the incident, he saw Shelton with an SKS rifle and a banana clip strapped around his neck.[3]Â  He stated that the three defendants then got into a green four-door Pontiac Catalina and drove off.Â  
On August 26, 2001, defendant Corey Shelton told Captain Williams where he could locate an AK-47.Â  Officers went to the place he described and found an AK-47, some banana clips for the AK-47, and a .32 caliber revolver.Â  
Defendant Derrick Brown made a statement to Chief Deputy Eddie Smith.Â  In the statement, Brown said that at about 11:00 to 11:30 p.m., on the night of the shooting, he was driving down Pleasant View Drive in his Green Pontiac Catalina and drinking beer when he heard a shot.Â  He said that he thought someone was shooting at him, so he pulled out his .45 caliber pistol and fired it out the window as he drove away.Â  He stated he then hid the gun.Â  Brown claimed he did not know who he was shooting at and did not know Phillip Johnson.Â  After he had made this statement, Brown personally led police to where he hid the .45 caliber pistol.Â  
The SLED examiner found that the bullet fragment taken from Johnson was too damaged to conclusively identify whether it came from Sheltonâ€™s AK-47, but that its characteristics indicated it could have been fired from his weapon.Â  The bullet that killed Johnson was not from a .45 pistol.Â  The fifteen 7.62mm casings found at the scene were the type that could have been fired from Sheltonâ€™s AK-47.Â  All seven of the .45 casings found at the scene were matched to Brownâ€™s .45 caliber pistol.Â  The SLED examiner also conclusively matched the bullet that had penetrated a nearby house to Brownâ€™s pistol.Â  Revolvers like Sheltonâ€™s .32 caliber do not automatically eject casings, which explains why none were found at the scene, but the SLED examiner did conclusively match Sheltonâ€™s revolver to the other bullet that had penetrated a nearby house.Â  
At the end of the Stateâ€™s case and again at the conclusion of the trial, Brown moved for a directed verdict, arguing the State failed to introduce any evidence he murdered Johnson.Â  The motions were denied, and the jury convicted Brown of both murder and possession of a firearm during commission of a violent crime.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Brown challenges the trial judgeâ€™s denial of his motion for a directed verdict.Â  Specifically, he argues that there was not substantial circumstantial evidence that Brown committed, or aided and abetted the commission of, the murder of Philip Johnson.Â  This argument has no merit.
When reviewing the denial of a directed verdict, a South Carolina appellate court views the evidence in the light most favorable to the State to determine if there is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused.Â  State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 633-34, 591 S.E.2d 600, 605 (2004); State v. Zeigler, 364 S.C. 94, 101-2, 610 S.E.2d 859, 863 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  If there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence which reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused, or from which his guilt can be fairly and logically deduced, then the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  State v. Martin, 340 S.C. 597, 602, 533 S.E.2d 572, 574 (2000); State v. Cooper, 334 S.C. 540, 551-52, 514 S.E.2d 584, 590 (1999).Â  Evidence that merely raises a suspicion the accused is guilty is not sufficient to survive a directed verdict motion.Â  State v. Buckmon, 347 S.C. 316, 321, 555 S.E.2d 402, 404 (2001); State v. Muhammed, 338 S.C. 22, 26, 524 S.E.2d 637, 639 (Ct. App. 1999).Â Â  
Brown contends that â€œ[a]t best, the State proved that Brown fired a forty-five pistol near where Johnson was killed at approximately the same time he was hit by a bullet fired from a different gun.â€ Â We disagree.
The Stateâ€™s case against Brown was based upon the theory that â€œthe hand of one is the hand of all,â€ which does not require that Brownâ€™s gun fired the fatal bullet.Â  Rather, one who joins with another to accomplish an illegal purpose is liable criminally for everything done by his confederate incidental to the execution of the common design and purpose.Â  State v. Langley, 334 S.C. 643, 648, 515 S.E.2d 98, 101 (1999). The State introduced substantial circumstantial evidence to support this theory. Â The State proved that Brown fired his forty-five caliber pistol in the vicinity of Johnson at approximately the same time he was killed; Brown admitted as much with his statements and his testimony.Â  In addition to placing Brown at the scene and firing his weapon at the time of the crime, the State presented substantial circumstantial and direct evidence linking Brown to the car used in the crime, and to Shelton, who was linked to an AK-47 used at the crime scene which fired ammunition consistent with that which killed Johnson.Â  This evidence is sufficient to support submission to the jury.Â  See State v. Weston, 367 S.C 279, 625 S.E.2d 641 (2006)(finding circumstantial evidence sufficient to support conviction for murder where victimâ€™s body was never found but she had mysteriously disappeared, Â and where physical evidence at the residence defendant and victim shared, alongside defendantâ€™s suspicious behavior indicated a murder might have taken place); State v. Freiburger, 366 S.C. 125, 620 S.E.2d 737 (2005)(finding circumstantial evidence sufficient to support conviction for a cab-driverâ€™sÂ  murder where there was evidence that on the day of the murder, the defendant bought the same type of gun that killed the victim, where two days after the murderÂ  he was staying at a motel close to where the victimâ€™s cab was found, and where the defendant was arrested with the gun that ballistics indicated killed the victim); State v. East, 353 S.C 634, 578 S.E.2d 748, (Ct. App. 2003)(finding defendant not entitled to a directed verdict on one of seven counts of kidnapping where victim of that count did not testify, but other witnesses testified that victim was present at the scene).Â  Given the aforementioned substantial circumstantial evidence linking Brown to the murder, and viewing it in the light most favorable to the State, the circuit courtâ€™s denial of the motion for directed verdict, and submission of the case to the jury, was proper.
CONCLUSION 
Based on the foregoing, the decision of the circuit court is hereby
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215(a), SCACR.
[2] At the conclusion of the Stateâ€™s case, and with the consent of the State, the judge directed a verdict aquitting Latimore.
[3] An SKS is a Chinese-made rifle very similar to an AK-47, which fires the same ammunition, and the two rifles are commonly referred to by each otherâ€™s names.Â

title: SCDSS v. Father
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
v.
Father, Appellant.
In the interest of:
Child A, Child J, and Child S,
All minors under the age of 18.
      
    
  


Appeal From Williamsburg County
Â Berry L. Mobley, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-401
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 11, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Hammond A. Beale, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
Stephen Bryan Doby, of Bishopville, for Respondent.
Gregory B. Askins, of Hemingway, and Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Father appeals from a family court order terminating his parental rights to his three minor children.Â  We affirm.[1]
Father and Mother[2] adopted three children in July 1999:Â  Child A, Child J, and Child S.Â  On March 7, 2003, the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS) took the children into emergency protective custody following allegations of abuse.Â  Father and Mother entered negotiated Alford[3] pleas to charges of abuse and neglect in July 2003.
SCDSS initiated the present action to terminate Father and Motherâ€™s parental rights in August 2004.Â  A five-day hearing took place from May 2, 2005 through May 6, 2005.Â  Father testified that he and his wife made the children drink a substance they named â€œliarâ€™s cocktail,â€ a combination of â€œvegetable juice and condiments from the refrigerator, not necessarily harmful but just a little unpleasant combination.â€Â  The children claimed the cocktails would include such substances as hot sauce, fish sauce, and even shampoo.Â  If the children threw up while drinking the cocktail, they were allegedly forced to eat the vomit.Â  
Father also admitted feeding the children baby food and forcing them to exercise.Â  Father repeatedly characterized the abuse as necessary forms of discipline because the children had special needs.Â  Evidence presented at trial indicated that all three children had been severely beaten.Â  Child A and Child J were found with bruises consistent with the pattern of an inflicted injury.Â  All three children developed post-traumatic stress disorder from the abuse.Â  
The childrenâ€™s guardian ad litem testified about her extensive experience with the children, which included weekly visits beginning in July 2003.Â  According to the guardian, the children did not want to return to Father and terminating his parental rights was in their best interests.
At the close of evidence, the parties waived closing arguments.Â  Fatherâ€™s counsel attempted to dismiss the action through a post-trial motion alleging multiple instances of SCDSS non-compliance with hearing requirements.Â  The court reserved ruling on the motion until its final order.
In June 2005, the family court issued an order terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights on the grounds that (1) the children had been harmed and that it was not reasonably likely the home would be made safe within twelve months; (2) Father had not remedied the conditions that caused the childrenâ€™s removal; (3) Father willfully failed to provide support to the children except for medical insurance; (4) the children had been in SCDSS foster care for at least fifteen of the preceding twenty-two months; and finding that the termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights was in the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  The court did not rule on Fatherâ€™s post-trial motion.Â  Father did not make a motion for reconsideration.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a TPR case, the best interest of the child is the paramount consideration.Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003). Â Before parental rights can be forever terminated, the alleged grounds for the termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Richberg v. Dawson, 278 S.C. 356, 357, 296 S.E.2d 338, 339 (1982); South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999). Â On appeal, this court may review the record and make its own determination of whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â 
South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Despite this broad scope of review, however, we should not necessarily disregard the findings of the family court because the family court is in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony.Â 
Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).
DISCUSSION
Father alleges the family court committed several errors in denying his motion to dismiss.Â  Father alleges the family court erred in failing to dismiss the termination of parental rights action because (1) a hearing on the merits was not held within the time mandated by South Carolina Code section 20-7-610(M); (2) SCDSS failed to schedule hearings every twelve months to review whether the conditions requiring removal continued to exist, as required by South Carolina Code section 20-7-762; (3) SCDSSâ€™s noncompliance with subsection C of 20-7-762 deprived the family court of jurisdiction; and (4) SCDSS failed to have the termination hearing within one year from the permanency planning hearing pursuant to South Carolina Code section 20-7-766(I)(2).Â  Father argues the family court was deprived of subject matter jurisdiction due to these four issues.Â  These issues are not preserved.
â€œ[S]ubject matter jurisdiction is the power of a court to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.â€Â  State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 100, 610 S.E.2d 494, 498 (2005).Â  â€œ[T]he family courtâ€™s compliance with the statutory time limits is not an issue of subject matter jurisdiction.â€Â 
South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Meek, 352 S.C. 523, 533 n.3, 575 S.E.2d 846, 851 n.3 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  We held in Meek that â€œthe remedy for the failure to complete the hearing within the specified time limits was . . . to petition for the return of
[the] children or move to vacate the order granting custody to DSS.â€Â  352 S.C. at 532, 575 S.E.2d at 851-52.Â  
Father briefly raised the four issues at the close of all the evidence, but the family court reserved ruling on them.Â  In its final order, the family court did not rule on any of these issues.Â  Father failed to make a motion to alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCACR.Â  Because these issues do not affect the family courtâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction, they are not preserved for appellate review.Â  See McCall v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 359 S.C. 372, 381, 597 S.E.2d 181, 186 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review); Jones v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 364 S.C. 222, 235, 612 S.E.2d 719, 726 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œAn issue is
not preserved where the trial court does not explicitly rule on an argument and the appellant does not make a
Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment.â€).
Next, Father alleges (1) clear and convincing evidence does not exist to support the family courtâ€™s findings that SCDSS made reasonable efforts to reunify the family, and (2) the family court erred in finding no treatment plan was ordered on July 31, 2003.Â  Father does not indicate how these alleged errors mandate reversal.
Regardless, Father does not challenge the family courtâ€™s decision to terminate his parental rights on the grounds that he willfully failed to support the minor children and that the children had been in SCDSS foster care for at least fifteen of the preceding twenty-two months.Â  Moreover, Father does not challenge the family courtâ€™s finding that terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights was in the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  As a result, we are required to affirm the termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights regardless of whether these arguments have merit.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005) (providing that the family court may terminate parental rights if it finds at least one of the nine statutory grounds for termination has been met and that termination is in the
best interests of the child).
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Mother died during the litigation of this case.
[3]Â  North Carolina v. Alford, 400 U.S. 25 (1970).Â

Gerald M. Finkel, Sean A. Oâ€™Connor, Finkel Law Firm LLC, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Michael F. Parrott, Lenise M. Parrott, of Sumter, pro se for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â In this foreclosure action, Mortgage Electronic Registration Systems, Inc., appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s failure to enter a default judgment and order that a note and mortgage were void as against Michael F. Parrott, Lenise M. Parrott, and Regions Bank (Respondents).Â  Mortgage Electronic argues the master erred by (1) denying its motion for default judgment where the Respondents failed to appear, and (2) raising sua sponte affirmative defenses on behalf of the Respondents.Â Â  We reverse and remand, pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities[1]:
Issue 1:Â  As to the masterâ€™s failure to enter a default judgment against the Parrots:Â  Rule 12(a), SCRCP (â€œ[A] defendant shall serve an answer within thirty days after service of the complaint.â€); Rule 55(b)(1), SCRCP (â€œ[T]he judge, upon motion or application of the party seeking default, and upon affidavit of the
amount due, shall enter judgment for that amount and costs against the party against whom judgment by default is sought, if that party has been defaulted for failure to appear. . . .â€).
Issue 2:Â  As to the master raising sua sponte affirmative defenses on behalf of the Respondents: Heins v. Heins, 344 S.C. 146, 152, 543 S.E.2d 224, 227 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œIt is well settled that ordinarily a party may not receive
relief not contemplated in his or her pleadings.â€); Collins Entertainment, Inc. v. White, 363 S.C. 546, 563, 611 S.E.2d 262, 270 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œ[T]he failure to plead an affirmative defense is deemed a waiver of the right to assert it.â€).
 REVERSED and REMANDED with instructions to enter default judgment against the Respondents, foreclosing the note and mortgage, and awarding appropriate damages and costs.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Curtis Jerome Mitchell, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-403
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 11, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, Office of Appellate Offense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., of Columbia; and Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Curtis Jerome Mitchell appeals his conviction for armed robbery.[1]Â  Mitchell argues the trial court erred in two respects: (1) failing to direct a verdict of acquittal on the charge of armed robbery and (2) instructing the jury that a robber need not be armed at all times during the robbery.Â  We affirm.
1.  We find the evidence presented by the State reasonably tends to prove Mitchell committed armed robbery, and thus the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  See State v. Weston, 367 S.C. 279, 292-93, 625 S.E.2d 641, 648 (2006) (â€œIf there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, the court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.â€).Â  The victim testified Mitchell threatened him with a knife while carrying away two cases of chewing tobacco that Mitchell did not pay for.Â  â€œArmed robbery may be proved by showing the defendant became armed before asportation of the stolen property.â€Â  State v. Middleton, 295 S.C. 318, 322, 368 S.E.2d 457, 459 (1988).Â  â€œIt is not necessary that the perpetrator be armed throughout commission of the crime.â€Â  Id.  
2.  We find that the trial court properly instructed the jury that a robber need not be armed at all times to be found guilty of armed robbery as requested by the State.Â  See State v. Santiago, 370 S.C. 153, __, 634 S.E.2d 23, 26 (Ct. App. 2006) (â€œIf there is any evidence to support a jury charge, the trial judge should grant the requested charge.â€).Â Â  One of the key issues at trial was whether Mitchell could be guilty of armed robbery when he was not armed with a deadly weapon for the entirety of the crime.Â  The law of this state is that one need not be armed at all times during a crime to be guilty of armed robbery.Â  See State v. Keith, 283 S.C. 597, 598, 325 S.E.2d 325, 326 (1985) (â€œ[W]hen a defendant commits robbery without a deadly weapon, but becomes armed with a deadly weapon before asportation of the victimâ€™s property, a conviction for armed robbery will stand. Â â€˜[T]he robber need not be armed at all times during the robbery in order to be guilty of (armed robbery).â€™â€) (quoting 77 C.J.S. Robbery, Â§ 25 (1952)).Â  
Accordingly, the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1]
We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
James Floyd, Appellant,
v.
State Budget and Control Board, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Richland County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-405
Submitted November 11, 2006 â€“ Filed December 11, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gloria Y. Leevy, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Edwin E. Evans, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â James Floyd appeals the affirmance of his termination from employment with the South Carolina Budget and Control Board (â€œthe Boardâ€).Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In 2002, Frank Fusco, Executive Director of the Board, received an anonymous letter alleging, among other things, that several of the women working in the custodial area of the Boardâ€™s Division of General Services (â€œGeneral Servicesâ€), were being sexually harassed.Â  During the investigation that followed, several employees made allegations that Floyd sexually harassed and intimidated some custodial workers.Â  Jane,[2] one of Floydâ€™s subordinates, claimed she had a sexual encounter with Floyd at his apartment during her lunch break because he pressured her to have sex in order to preserve her job.Â  Jane described Floyd as living in â€œRutledge Apartments, Apartment 3,â€ a one-bedroom apartment with â€œa colonial style high bedâ€ with a dark-colored floral bedspread, a dresser with a picture of his mother on it, two night stands, and a chest of drawers with a picture of Floydâ€™s daughter on it.Â  Jill, a custodian under Floydâ€™s supervision, claimed Floyd made advances toward her and at one point grabbed and manhandled her.Â  Jill told Wanda Elm, a DSS employee in the building Jill cleaned, about the harassment, and Jill often hid from Floyd behind Elmâ€™s desk.Â Â  
Floyd denied that he sexually harassed anyone and claimed that he was the actual victim of sexual harassment at the hands of Jane, Jill, and Cynthia, another employee under his supervision.Â  Floyd was suspended during the investigation.Â  After conducting interviews with numerous workers, including Floyd, Jane, and Jill, General Services determined Floyd had â€œengaged in a pattern of sexually harassing employees under [his] supervision.â€Â  Floyd was terminated.Â Â  
Floyd, represented by counsel, appealed his termination to the Boardâ€™s Grievance Panel (â€œInternal Panelâ€).Â  After a hearing, the Internal Panel recommended that the termination of Floyd be upheld.Â  Fusco, Director of the Board, reviewed the Internal Panelâ€™s recommendation and upheld Floydâ€™s termination.Â  Floyd appealed to the State Employee Grievance Committee (â€œState Committeeâ€), and a de novo hearing was held.Â  After hearing testimony from thirteen witnesses, including Floyd, the State Committee unanimously upheld Floydâ€™s termination, finding the testimony of Jane and Jill to be more credible than that of Floyd.Â  The State Committee further stated:Â  â€œThe Committee finds [Floyd] failed to establish that the Agencyâ€™s decisions were inappropriate under the requirements of Â§ 8-17-340(E)(2).Â  Therefore, the Committee upholds the decision of the [Board] to terminate [Floyd] and denies the relief sought.â€Â Â  
Floyd appealed his termination to the circuit court, alleging the State Committeeâ€™s decision was based solely on the testimony given by Jane and Jill.Â  Floyd further argued that â€œall the facts and evidence presented on [his] behalf were not given [fair] and proper consideration.â€Â  After a hearing, the circuit court determined there was sufficient evidence to support the State Committeeâ€™s findings and affirmed the final decision of the State Committee.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing a final decision of an administrative agency pursuant to South Carolina Code section 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005), the circuit court sits in an appellate capacity and is limited to considering whether the agency committed any errors.Â  Kiawah Resort Assoc. v. South Carolina Tax Commâ€™n, 318 S.C. 502, 505, 458 S.E.2d 542, 544 (1995).Â  The court â€œshall not substitute its judgment for that of the agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â  The court can reverse or modify the administrative agencyâ€™s decision if the substantive rights of the appellant have been prejudiced because the agencyâ€™s decision was:

  
    
      (a) 
       in violation of constitutional or statutory provisions;
    
    
      (b)
       in excess of the statutory authority of the agency;
    
    
      (c)
       made upon unlawful procedure;
    
    
      (d)
       affected by other error of law;
    
    
      (e) 
       clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantive evidence on the whole record; or
    
    
      (f) 
       arbitrary or capricious or characterized by abuse of discretion or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.
    
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â  The findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct and will only be set aside if not supported by substantial evidence.Â  Rodney v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 519, 466 S.E.2d 357, 359 (1996).Â  The burden is on the appellant to prove that the administrative agencyâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence.Â  Tennis v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 355 S.C. 551, 558, 585 S.E.2d 312, 316 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Substantial Evidence
Floyd argues the circuit court erred in failing to reverse the State Committeeâ€™s affirmance of his termination by the Board because it was â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the record as a whole.â€Â  We disagree.
Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed blindly from one side, but is evidence which, when considering the whole record, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached.Â  Tennis, 355 S.C. at 558, 585 S.E.2d at 316.Â  The possibility of reaching two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not mean the administrative agencyâ€™s findings are not supported by substantial evidence.Â  Id.Â  
Floyd complains that the Board and the State Committee failed to adequately consider:Â  (1) his testimony that he did not sexually harass Jane or Jill; (2) his exemplary twenty-year employment history with the Board; and (3) the fact that Jane could not accurately describe Floydâ€™s apartment number or the furniture in his apartment, despite her allegations that she went to Floydâ€™s apartment for a sexual encounter.Â  Although Floyd states he is not asking this court to weigh the credibility of the witnesses, he is essentially arguing that his testimony was more credible than the other witnesses.Â  Because the weight of the evidence, including the credibility of witnesses, is a determination left solely in the administrative agency, neither the circuit court nor this court can make credibility determinations.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005) (noting that the circuit court cannot substitute its judgment for that of the appellate agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact).Â  Â 
Looking at the evidence before the Board and the State Committee, we find there was substantial evidence to affirm Floydâ€™s termination.Â  Although Floyd claimed Jane and Jill were motivated to fabricate the sexual harassment allegations, the State Committee found their testimony more credible than Floydâ€™s.Â  Further, Wanda Elmâ€™s testimony corroborated Jillâ€™s allegations that Floyd appeared in her building several times to harass her.Â  Because there was substantial evidence to support the State Committeeâ€™s findings, the circuit court did not err in affirming Floydâ€™s termination.
II.Â  Disciplinary Procedures
Floyd argues the Board failed to follow its own disciplinary policy by failing to explore options other than termination.Â  Because of this failure, Floyd argues, the circuit court should have reversed the findings of the Board and the State Committee.Â  Floyd also argues that the Boardâ€™s failure to discipline Cynthia after Floyd complained that she sexually harassed him shows disparity in the implementation of the Boardâ€™s policy, requiring reversal.Â  We disagree.[3]Â  
The Boardâ€™s disciplinary policy provides that founded cases of harassment constitute misconduct subject to appropriate disciplinary action â€œup to and including dismissalâ€ in accordance with the progressive discipline policy.Â  Disciplinary actions range from counseling, an oral reprimand, a written reprimand, suspension, termination, reassignment, and demotion.Â  The disciplinary policy further provides that â€œ[w]hen an offense is of sufficient severity, disciplinary action may begin at a more advanced stage, including termination.â€Â  The following language precedes the section outlining particular punishments for particular offenses: 

The disciplinary actions noted for the personal conduct offenses listed at the end of this section are guidelines and the agency is not bound to them.Â  These guidelines are intended to provide guidance, but the circumstances of the particular situations may warrant disciplinary action outside these Guidelines.Â  Discipline may begin at any step in the procedure depending on the seriousness of the individual offense.

The section further suggests a written reprimand to a suspension for a first occurrence of harassment, suspension to termination for a second occurrence, and termination for a third occurrence.Â Â Â  
Reviewing the Boardâ€™s policy, it is clear the Board had a range of disciplinary options in disciplining Floyd.Â  Although the disciplinary policy suggested a written reprimand to a suspension for a first occurrence of harassment, termination for a serious offense was also one of the options available to the Board.Â  The allegations against Floyd, which the Board and the State Committee found to be credible, included threats of demotion or firing if sexual favors were not given, grabbing an employee, and pressuring an employee to have sex with him.Â  These allegations were very serious.Â  Thus, we find the Board did not violate its progressive discipline policy by terminating Floyd for a â€œfirst occurrence.â€Â  
CONCLUSION
There was substantial evidence to support the Boardâ€™s and the State Committeeâ€™s decision to terminate Floyd for sexual harassment.Â  Further, there is no evidence to support Floydâ€™s argument that the Board failed to follow its progressive disciplinary procedures.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court to uphold Floydâ€™s termination is
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  We have changed the names of Floydâ€™s accusers to protect their identities.Â  
[3] We note this issue may not be preserved for appellate review.Â  Floyd did not complain that the Board failed to follow its progressive disciplinary procedures in his appeal to the State Committee nor did he complain about it in his appeal to the circuit court.Â  Issues not raised to or ruled upon by the administrative agency are generally not preserved for appellate review by the circuit court or this court.Â  Kiawah Resort Assoc. v. South Carolina Tax Commâ€™n, 318 S.C. 502, 505-06, 458 S.E.2d 542, 544 (1995).Â  Despite not raising the issue in his appeals, Floyd argued the issue before the circuit court.Â  After recognizing that the issue was not preserved, the circuit court nevertheless addressed the merits of the issue.Â  Similarly, we will address the merits of Floydâ€™s argument.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
v.
David G., Angela G., Defendants, of whom David G. is Appellant.
Â IN RE:  T.G., D.G., A.G., Minor children under the age of eighteen.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Dorothy Jones, Family Court Judge

REVERSED

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-406
Heard November 7, 2006 â€“ Filed December 12, 2006


  
    
      
Robert E. Horner, of Columbia, for Appellant[1]
Cherolyn Roselle Allen, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  David G. (Father) appeals the family courtâ€™s findings that he abused his son (Child), and that he posed a substantial risk of abuse to his two other children.Â  Father argues the evidence does not support the family courtâ€™s decision.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Child alleged that in an argument over attending church on Sunday March 6, 2005, Father grabbed him around the neck, lifted him off the floor, and held him in the air for â€œabout two minutes.â€Â  Child stated that he couldnâ€™t breathe or talk.Â  Child reported this occurrence to his school on Wednesday March 9, 2005, and the school reported the matter to the Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department (the Police) who referred the matter to the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS).Â  Father admitted arguing over Childâ€™s refusal to attend church, but denied choking Child and presented a different account of the events.Â  Father stated that after Child had slapped away and then grabbed his hand when he tried to present Child with a shirt for church, he put his hand on Childâ€™s chest and held Child against the wall.Â  Father stated that the securing of Child against the wall lasted only long enough for him to inform Child that going to church was not up for debate.Â Â Â Â  
DSS took all three children into emergency protective custody and brought a summons and complaint against Father for his alleged March 6, 2005, abuse of Child.Â  Despite allegedly being lifted off the ground and choked for two minutes, Child suffered no visible physical injuries.Â  As per both the Police and DSS and in contrast to Childâ€™s testimony, there was no bruising or other injuries found on Childâ€™s neck.Â  In fact, the only bruise appeared on Childâ€™s chest below his neck. 
On Â September Â 19, Â 2005, Â Father Â was Â brought Â before Â the Â Richland County Family Court for a determination of physical abuse against Child.[2]Â  In an order filed November 16, 2005, the family court made a finding of abuse against Father regarding Child and further found Father posed a substantial risk of abuse to the two other children.Â  Father now appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  â€œWe are mindful that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  Wynn v. Wynn, 360 S.C. 117, 123, 600 S.E.2d 71, 74 (Ct. App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Father contends the family court erred in finding he abused Child because the testimony supports his version of the events, and Father argues there is no evidence that he poses a substantial risk to his other children.Â  We agree. 
Father and Child were the only viable witnesses to the events of March 6, 2005, and they presented conflicting testimony.Â  Childâ€™s account of the events are somewhat incredible.Â  It is difficult to believe Father could have lifted Child off of the floor by his neck and held him in the air with his feet dangling for almost two minutes.Â  Further, the only Â physical evidence Â was Â a bruise â€œbelow [Childâ€™s] neckâ€ on his chest.Â  This evidence is inconsistent with Childâ€™s testimony and wholly consistent with Fatherâ€™s testimony that Â he put his hand on Childâ€™s chest and secured him against the wall.[3]  
Child testified that he hated his father because of past problems between Father and Mother, and he wanted Father to be in prison for a long time.Â  Child further testified he wanted Mother back and Father gone, and that he knew if he told his school that father choked him that this would happen.[4]
While we are mindful that the family court which saw and heard the witnesses was in a better position to evaluate their credibility, we find that the family court failed to assign credibility to either of the witnesses.Â  At the conclusion of the hearing, the family court stated â€œItâ€™s not so much that I believe or donâ€™t believe what was said here . . .â€Â  If the family court fails to assign credibility to witnessâ€™ testimony, then our deference to its superior position to adjudge the weight of the witnessâ€™ testimony is eliminated, and we must draw our own conclusions based on a preponderance of the evidence. 
We find the preponderance of the evidence supports a finding that Father did not abuse Child.Â  Because we reverse the family courtâ€™s finding of abuse against Child, we also reverse the family courtâ€™s finding that Father poses a substantial risk of abuse to his other two children.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the family courtâ€™s order is
 REVERSED.
 GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We note our appreciation for the able representation provided by appointed counsel.
[2] At a Merits Hearing held prior to this matter, all parties reached an agreement with regards to custody and treatment.Â  The parties agreed custody of all three of the children would be returned to Angela G. (Mother), and that Angela and the children would begin counseling.Â  The only disputed item was the finding of abuse by Father.Â Â  
[3] Section 20-7-490(2)(a) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) excludes from the definition of child abuse â€œcorporal punishment or physical discipline whichâ€ in pertinent part: â€œ(i) is administered by a parent . . . (ii) is perpetrated for the sole purpose of restraining or correcting the child (iii) is reasonable in manner and moderate in degree (iv) has not brought permanent or lasting damage to the child; and (v) is not reckless or grossly negligent behavior by the parents.â€ The actions which Father testified to would fall under this exception and would not constitute abuse.
[4] Mother had left the home after a verbal disagreement with Father.Â
