title: Richardson v. Colliers Keenan
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Marion L. Richardson, Appellant,
v.
Colliers Keenan, Inc., Continental Of South Carolina, Inc., and John Doe,
Defendants,
Of whom Colliers Keenan, Inc. and Continental of South Carolina, Inc. are
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Joseph M. Strickland, Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-407
Heard November 7, 2006 â€“ Filed December 12, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Donald E. Jonas and William Neal Lacy, both of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
Charles E. Carpenter, Jr., Carmen V. Ganjehsani, and W. Cliff Moore, III, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Marion Richardson filed this contract and tort action against Colliers Keenan, Inc. and Continental of South Carolina, Inc.Â  After a bench trial, the master in equity entered judgment for Colliers Keenan and Continental.Â  Richardson appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Richardson and his brother, Robert Richardson, own a twenty-two acre tract of land in Richland County.Â  In 1998, the Riverland Hills Baptist Church approached the Richardsons about purchasing their tract, but ultimately concluded the tract was too small.Â  Therefore, the Richardsons attempted to purchase neighboring land from Continental and sell the combined tract to Riverland Hills.Â  
Continental is a small corporation formed for the sole purpose of acquiring and eventually selling the Continental tract.Â  Colliers Keenan is a real estate agency.Â  On December 23, 1998, Tom Burch of Colliers Keenan, acting on behalf of the Richardsons, delivered a letter of intent to purchase the Continental tract to Dail Longaker, Jr.Â  Longaker is a real estate agent with Colliers Keenan and had previously listed property for Continental. Â In addition, Longakerâ€™s father owns twenty percent of Continentalâ€™s stock.Â  
In September 1999, Richardson, Longaker, and L.C. Howell, president and forty-percent shareholder of Continental, discussed the possibility of Richardson purchasing the Continental tract.Â  Richardson allegedly offered Howell $1.3 million for the Continental tract.Â  However, the parties did not execute a written contract, and the parties disagree on whether a final verbal agreement was reached.
Howell, Longaker, and Richardson met again in early 2000.Â  Howell informed Richardson that with the proxy vote of another shareholder, he had fifty percent of the shares and believed he could obtain a controlling vote.Â  Longaker reiterated to Richardson that any sale would have to be affirmed by the majority of the shareholders.Â  
Continental received the Richardson offer and another offer from East Lake Community Church.Â  On May 31, 2000, the Continental shareholders met to discuss and vote on the offers.Â  Longaker wrote a letter to the shareholders in preparation for the meeting.Â  In the letter, Longaker outlined the two offers and then stated, â€œStrictly from a financial perspective, the sale to East Lake Community Church should be the option to pursue.â€Â  At the meeting, the shareholders voted to pursue the East Lake offer.Â  Howell abstained from the vote, offered his shares to the other shareholders, and resigned as president.Â  Dail Longaker, Sr., was elected the new president.Â  The sale to East Lake was not completed. Â 
Richardson filed this action for specific performance and damages, alleging negligence, interference with prospective business advantage and contractual relations, negligent misrepresentation, constructive fraud, breach accompanied by a fraudulent act, conspiracy, violation of the Unfair Trade Practices Act (UTPA), and professional negligence.Â  The action was referred by consent to the master for a final judgment.Â  Richardsonâ€™s cause of action for specific performance was dismissed by stipulation of the parties.Â  
After a six day trial, the master entered judgment for Continental and Colliers Keenan finding no contract was formed between Continental and Richardson.Â  The master also found no causation to support the various tort actions.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal of an action at law tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the trial court will not be disturbed unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the trial courtâ€™s findings.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  â€œThis scope of review is equally applicable to the factual determinations of a master when, as in the present case, he enters final judgment.â€Â  Wigfall v. Fobbs, 295 S.C. 59, 61, 367 S.E.2d 156, 157 (1988). Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS[1]
I.Â  Formation of Contract
Richardson argues the master erred in finding Richardson and Continental did not form a contract.Â  We disagree.Â  The elements required for formation of a contract are an offer, acceptance, and valuable consideration. Â Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of S.C., 354 S.C. 397, 406, 581 S.E.2d 161, 166 (2003).Â  Furthermore, â€œthere must be a meeting of the minds between the parties with regard to all essential and material terms of the agreement.â€Â  Player v. Chandler, 299 S.C. 101, 105, 382 S.E.2d 891, 893 (1989) (emphasis in original).Â  In this case, Continental never accepted an offer from Richardson.Â  An offer could only be accepted by the majority of the shareholders.Â  Richardson knew that a majority of the shareholders had to vote to accept his offer.Â  Like the master, we find no contract was formed.Â  Rather, Richardson suffered merely the loss of an expectancy.Â  See Collins Music Co. v. Cook, 281 S.C. 580, 583-84, 316 S.E.2d 418, 420 (Ct. App. 1984) (allowing no recovery for mere loss of expectancy).Â  
Further, the Statute of Frauds prohibits the sale of land, absent some exceptions, â€œ[u]nless the agreement . . . be in writing and signed by the party to be charged therewith or some person thereunto by him lawfully authorized.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 32-3-10(4) (1991).Â  In this case, there is no written contract and no applicable exception to the Statute of Frauds.Â  
II.Â  Causation of Contract Rejection
Richardson argues the master erred in failing to find actions of Colliers Keenan and Continental caused the shareholders to reject his offer.Â  We disagree.Â  Ordinarily, the question of proximate cause is one for the finder of fact.Â 
McNair v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 349, 499 S.E.2d 488, 497 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Where the evidence is susceptible of only one inference, however, it becomes a matter of law for the court.Â  Hurd v. Williamsburg County, 353 S.C. 596, 614, 579 S.E.2d 136, 145 (Ct. App. 2003), affâ€™d, 362 S.C. 421, 611 S.E.2d 488 (2005).Â  
Richardson first asserts Colliers Keenanâ€™s failure to have him sign an agency disclosure form caused the failure of the contract. Â The purpose of the disclosure form is to inform a potential buyer or seller of the real estate agentâ€™s relationship to them and the agentâ€™s involvement in representing them in their transaction.Â  The purpose of the disclosure form was met in this case because Richardson knew of the relationship of Longaker, Jr. to Continental and knew of Longaker, Sr.â€™s ownership interest.Â  Furthermore, Richardson admitted Longaker, Jr. had been â€œrepresented to [him] as the agent of his client, Continental.â€Â  
Richardson also asserts Longaker, Jr.â€™s letter advising against the Richardson offer caused the failure of the contract.Â  Richardson expresses the allegations against Colliers Keenan as a breach of duty owed him by Colliers Keenan via the acts of its agent, Longaker, Jr. Â Under the common law, no duty is owed to another unless the duty is created by contract, statute, relationship, status or other special circumstance.Â 
Carson v. Adgar, 326 S.C. 212, 217, 486 S.E.2d 3, 5 (1997).Â  We find no duty breached by Colliers Keenan through its agent Longaker.Â  First, Colliers Keenan did not represent Richardson in this transaction and all previous mutual transactions between Richardson and Colliers Keenan were concluded. Â Also, as previously stated, Richardson knew Longaker, Jr. was a Colliers Keenan agent and represented Continental.Â  
We find evidence to support the judgment.Â  Richardson knew his offer had to be approved by a majority of the shareholders.Â  The shareholders were aware of another, more lucrative, offer from East Lake. Â The failure of the contract formation is directly attributable to the shareholderâ€™s rejection of Richardsonâ€™s offer in favor of the East Lake offer.Â  The record supports a conclusion that neither the failure to execute the disclosure form nor Longaker, Jr.â€™s advisory letter caused the failure of the contract formation.Â  
Richardson next asserts Continental caused the failure of the contract formation through the acts of its agent, Howell.Â  We disagree.Â  It is true that a misrepresentation made by an agent while acting within the scope of his agency is attributable to the principal.Â  West v. Service Life & Health Ins. Co., 220 S.C. 198, 200, 66 S.E.2d 816, 817 (1951).Â  However, there is no evidence to support Richardsonâ€™s allegation of a misrepresentation.Â  Richardson admitted knowledge that a majority of the shareholders had to approve the offer and knowledge that Howell owned only forty percent of Continental.Â  Howellâ€™s statement that he believed he could get a majority to agree was mere puffing.Â  See Satcher v. Berry, 299 S.C. 381, 383, 385 S.E.2d 41, 42 (Ct. App. 1989) (finding sellerâ€™s â€˜puffingâ€™ does not ordinarily constitute misrepresentation).
III.Â  Additional Causes of Action
Richardson finally contends the master failed to make findings on his negligence, civil conspiracy, interference with contract, professional negligence, Unfair Trade Practices Act (UTPA), and fraud-based causes of action.Â  We find no reversible error.Â  Although the master failed to make specific findings on these causes of action, the record supports judgment for the defendants on these causes of action as Richardson cannot prove damages caused by the defendants.Â  See J.T. Baggerly v. CSX Transp., Inc., 370 S.C. 362, ___, 635 S.E.2d 97, 101 (2006) (requiring injuries caused by the defendants to recover on an action for negligence); Pye v. Estate of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, __, 633 S.E.2d 505, 511 (2006) (requiring same for
civil conspiracy); Crandall Corp. v. Navistar Intâ€™l Transp. Corp., 302 S.C. 265, 266, 395 S.E.2d 179, 180 (1990) (requiring same for intentional interference with prospective contractual relations); Lowrance v. Swaffield, 123 S.C. 331, 333, 116 S.E. 278, 278 (1923) (requiring same for professional negligence action against real estate broker); Schnellmann v. Roettger, 368 S.C. 17, 23, 627 S.E.2d 742, 745-46 (Ct. App. 2006) (requiring same for recovery under the UTPA); Armstrong v. Collins, 366 S.C. 204, 218, 621 S.E.2d 368, 375 (Ct. App. 2005) (requiring same for fraud).
Richardson alleged damages of lost profits from combining the Continental tract with the Richardson tract to sell as one tract.Â  The alleged damages arise from the failure of contract formation and, as previously discussed, represent a mere expectancy rather than actual damages. Â The master appropriately found no damages caused by the defendants.Â  The failure of the master to make specific findings on each of these causes of action does not constitute reversible error.Â  See Owners Ins. Co. v. Clayton, 364 S.C. 555, 563, 614 S.E.2d 611, 615 (2005) (stating error without prejudice does not warrant reversal).
Richardson also argues the master erred in failing to make specific findings of fact on his negligent misrepresentation and fraudulent breach of contract causes of action.Â  We likewise find no reversible error as we find evidence to support the judgment.Â  
Negligent misrepresentation requires a duty and a loss due to reliance.Â  See Schnellmann, 368 S.C. at 20-21, 627 S.E.2d at 744 (â€œTo state a claim for
negligent misrepresentation a plaintiff must show (1) the defendant made a false representation to the plaintiff; (2) the defendant had a pecuniary interest
in making the statement; (3) the defendant owed a duty of care to communicate truthful information to the plaintiff; (4) the defendant breached that duty; (5) the plaintiff justifiably relied on the representation; and (6) the plaintiff suffered a pecuniary loss as a result of such reliance.â€).Â  The master found no duty owed to Richardson, and the evidence supports this finding.Â  
Breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act requires a contract.Â  See Armstrong, 366 S.C. at 223, 621 S.E.2d at 377 (â€œHaving a contract is a prerequisite to proving breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act.â€). Â As discussed, there is no contract in this case.Â  
Accordingly, although the master did not specifically address all of Richardsonâ€™s causes of action, we find evidence in the record to support the judgment.
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â Richardson itemizes thirty-two issues but consolidates these issues into three arguments.Â  We likewise consolidate the issues.

title: Schmidt v. Anderson Merchandisers
text:
PREHEARING REPORT


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Jean L. Schmidt Appellant,
v.
Anderson Merchandisers, Employer, and American Home Assurance Company, Carrier
Respondents,
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge 

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-408
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 12, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Dennis R. Toney, Jr., and J. Kevin Holmes, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Stephen L. Brown, F. Drake Rogers, and Matthew K. Mahoney, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Jean L. Schmidt appeals from a circuit court order affirming the order of The South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Appellate Panel), denying Schmidtâ€™s claim for back and neck injuries and awarding permanent partial disability for Schmidtâ€™s carpal tunnel syndrome claim.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Jean L. Schmidt, the fifty-six year old claimant, worked for employer and respondent Anderson Merchandisers as a sales merchandiser for nearly seven years, until May 11, 2001.Â  Schmidt was responsible for the inventory of the book departments and music departments in several Wal-Mart stores.Â  Her job duties consisted of unloading boxes of merchandise from a pallet onto a cart, then using the cart to take the boxes inside the store to be opened and shelved.Â  Schmidtâ€™s job thus entailed regularly moving boxes weighing between five and thirty-five pounds.Â  
Schmidt filed two separate workerâ€™s compensation claims against Anderson Merchandisers: one for carpal tunnel syndrome and the other for neck and back injuries.Â  The record supplies an extensive medical history relevant to these injuries.
Schmidt has a degenerative disc disease that has necessitated surgeries of the cervical and lumbar areas of her spine.Â  Schmidtâ€™s first back strain occurred in 1979, long before she started working for Anderson Merchandisers.Â  Schmidt testified that she had sporadic back problems until 1996, when she began noticing a worsening of her condition when she was required to do lifting.Â  Schmidt testified that the aggravation of her problems resulted in a July 1996 lower spine surgical procedure in Tennessee.Â  , She suffered a low back strain in an early 1997 work-related automobile accident, and a neck strain in another work-related accident in December of 1997. Â She was soon transferred to South Carolina, where she began treatment with a new spine doctor, Dr. Poletti, in November of 1998.Â  Later, on June 14, 1999, she fell at work and injured her lower back and left leg. Â Schmidt continued to have lower back problems, and in October of 1999, she underwent lumbar spine fusion surgery.Â  After this surgery, Dr. Poletti restricted Schmidt from lifting more than ten pounds, and required alternative sitting and standing.Â  Anderson Merchandisers accommodated these restrictions by providing trainees to assist her for several months.Â  
Schmidt was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2000.Â  While undergoing a lumpectomy and chemotherapy treatments, she began having shoulder, arm and hand pain, which eventually made her unable to continue holding objects.Â  A neurologist diagnosed her with bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome in early 2001.Â  Schmidt filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim based upon this condition after her health insurance claim was denied.Â  
Meanwhile, Schmidt testified that in 2000 she began to experience pain in the cervical region of her spine. Â Dr. Poletti advised her to seek short or long-term disability, and suggested she limit her physical activities.Â  Despite this advice, Schmidt wished to continue working.Â  Dr. Poletti thus agreed to perform cervical spine fusion surgery.Â  Schmidt testified that she informed Anderson Merchandisers she would be out of work for six to eight weeks following the surgery.Â  She last worked on May 11, 2001, and underwent the spine fusion surgery on May 14, 2001.Â  On June 5, 2001, Schmidt underwent carpal tunnel surgery on her right arm, and on July 10, 2001, she underwent the same procedure on her left arm.Â  On July 16, 2001, Poletti advised her not to return to work, and Schmidt notified Anderson Merchandisers that she would not.Â  
Schmidt applied and was accepted for social security disability as a result of the severe degenerative disc disease and the surgeries of her lumbar and spine.Â  She then underwent a second cervical fusion procedure in October of 2001.Â  Schmidtâ€™s carpal tunnel surgeon released her to full duty on August 28, 2001, and on November 15, 2001, reported that Schmidt had reached maximum medical improvement, with five percent permanent impairments to each of her arms.Â  
At the hearing before the single commissioner, Schmidt stated she was aware as far back as 1996 that the lifting she performed at work was harming her back.Â  She also admitted knowledge of Anderson Merchandisersâ€™ policy requiring her to notify Steve Cohen, the risk control manager, of any work-related injury.Â  Schmidt had numerous communications with Cohen regarding her health problems and regarding other job incidents, but never reported any work-related injury involving her back and/or neck to him.Â  
Schmidt forwarded to Anderson Merchandisersâ€™ human resource department a letter from Dr. Poletti dated July 16, 2001.Â  The letter stated in pertinent part: â€œMs. Schmidt has pain in her neck and in her low back.Â  There was no specific mechanism of injury that would cause this.Â  Repetitive trauma could theoretically contribute to an aggravation of this, but overall spinal condition is such that it will disable her.â€Â Â Â  Steve Cohen testified that Dr. Polettiâ€™s letter was not sent to his department because nothing in it indicated a work-related claim.Â  He stated that the first notice his risk-management department received of Schmidtâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation claim involving her back was in July of 2002, when her claim was filed.Â  
At the hearing before the single commissioner, Anderson Merchandisers admitted the carpal tunnel claims, but specifically denied the neck and back injury claims.Â  For her carpal tunnel claim, Schmidt submitted a second amended Form 50 with a November 27, 2000, date of injury and a $633.07 weekly wage.Â  In his argument before the single commissioner, Schmidtâ€™s attorney stated: â€œWe contend that the Claimaintâ€™s average weekly wage and compensation rate for the 2000 accident is at a minimal average weekly wage of $633.07 and the compensation rate being $422.07.â€Â  
The single commissioner awarded permanent partial disability for the carpal tunnel claim and awarded the requested amount, but denied the claim for back and neck injuries. The commissioner gave two reasons for denying the back and neck claim: first, the commissioner found Schmidt did not satisfy her burden of proving compensable injury by accident or by repetitive trauma; and second, the commissioner found Schmidt did not give notice to Anderson Merchandisers of her neck and back injuries.Â  Schmidt appealed, arguing that the commissioner erred in finding her neck and back injuries were not work-related, that she had indeed provided proper notice of her back and neck injuries, and that the compensation rate awarded for her carpal tunnel injury was incorrect.Â  The Appellate Panel and circuit court affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s order.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions of the [Appellate Panel].Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  The findings of the Appellate Panel will not be set aside if the findings are supported by substantial evidence and are not controlled by legal error.Â  Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 183, 528 S.E.2d 435, 440 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action.Â  Bass v. Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 468, 617 S.E.2d 369, 376 (2005); Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 622, 594 S.E.2d 272, 274 (2004).Â  Where there is a conflict in the evidence, the findings of fact of the Appellate Panel are conclusive.Â  Glover v. Columbia Hosp. of Richland County, 236 S.C. 410, 114 S.E.2d 565, 569 (1960); Alexander v. Forklifts Unlimited, 365 S.C. 509, 514, 618 S.E.2d 307, 309 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  In an appeal from the Appellate Panel, the appellate court will not substitute its judgment for that of the Panel as to the weight of evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by error of law.Â  White v. Medical Univ. of S.C., 355 S.C. 560, 564, 586 S.E.2d 157, 169 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  However, construction of a statute by an agency charged with its administration will be accorded the most respectful consideration and will not by overruled absent compelling reasons.Â  Glover by Cauthen v. Suitt Const. Co., 318 S.C. 465, 469, 458 S.E.2d 535, 537 (1995).Â  The burden is on appellants to prove the agencyâ€™s decision is unsupported by evidence.Â  Waters v. S.C. Land Res. Conservation Commâ€™n, 321 S.C. 219, 226, 467 S.E.2d 913, 917 (1996); Tennis v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 355 S.C. 551, 558, 585 S.E.2d 312, 316 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Causation
Schmidt argues the Appellate Panel erred in finding there was no medical evidence to show a causal connection between Schmidtâ€™s back and neck problems and her work activities.Â  Specifically, she contends that the Appellate Panel relied on a legally erroneous assumption that medical testimony is required to show a causal-connection, and that absent such medical testimony, there can be no finding of causation.Â  Further, she argues the finding of no medical evidence establishing causation is not supported by substantial evidence.Â  We disagree.
Schmidtâ€™s first argument has no merit.Â  An objective reading of the Appellate Panelâ€™s straightforward finding that â€œthere is no medical evidence in the record that indicates a causal connection between the Claimantâ€™s back and neck problems and her work activitiesâ€ provides no implication of a legal requirement of medical evidence.Â  Review of the record, of the circuit courtâ€™s order, and of the Appellate Panelâ€™s order reveals that all findings were based on consideration of the facts and circumstances of the case as a whole, including the medical evidence and the testimony of both Schmidt and Steve Cohen.
Schmidtâ€™s argument that the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding was not supported by substantial evidence in the record is also unpersuasive.Â  Throughout Schmidtâ€™s years of treatment to her neck and back, no treating physician has ever indicated that Schmidtâ€™s work at Anderson Merchandisers aggravated or worsened a previous condition.Â  The only medical testimony Schmidt relies upon to link her neck and back injuries to her work is found in Dr. Polettiâ€™s letter, which states:Â  â€œThere is no specific mechanism of injury that would cause this. Repetitive trauma could theoretically contribute to an aggravation of this but her overall spinal condition is such that it will disable her.â€Â  Schmidt contends that these statements constituted a â€œcautious opinion that [Schmidtâ€™s] work was contributing to an aggravation of her pre-existing spine condition.â€Â  However Polettiâ€™s letter clearly avoids advancing an opinion of causation by merely stating â€œ[r]epetitive trauma could theoretically contribute to an aggravation.â€ (emphasis added).Â  Further, Poletti never opines that Schmidtâ€™s work regimen entailed such â€œrepetitive trauma.â€ This less presumptuous reading of the letter is buttressed by consideration of the two subsequent letters Dr. Poletti wrote on behalf of Schmidt to the Social Security Administration in which again he mentioned her various problems without ever relating them to her employment.
Therefore, we find there is substantial evidence on the record to support the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding that Schmidtâ€™s back injuries were not caused by her work at Anderson Merchandisers.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Compensation Rate
Schmidt next argues the Appellate Panel erred in the amount it awarded in compensation for her carpal tunnel claim.Â  Schmidt contends that the Appellate Panel should not have calculated her compensation rate based on the November 27, 2000, date of injury she submitted.Â  Rather, Schmidt suggests the calculation should be based on the average weekly wage for the fifty-two weeks prior to her last day of work on May 11, 2001.Â  On appeal, the circuit court held this issue was not preserved.Â  We agree.
We note that it was Schmidt who provided the November 27, 2000 date of injury, the $633.07 average weekly wage, and the $422.07 compensation rate on her filings. Â Furthermore, Schmidt specifically requested the same compensation rate before the single commissioner at the hearing, and conceded the average weekly wage amount from which it was derived.Â  Because Schmidt received the compensation she requested, and conceded the average weekly wage amount from which it is derived, this issue is not preserved for appeal.Â  See TNS Mills, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 617, 503 S.E.2d 471, 474 (1998)(â€œAn issue conceded in a lower court may not be argued on appeal.â€); Erickson v. Jones Street Publishers, LLC, 368 S.C. 444, 476, 629 S.E.2d 653, 670 (2006)(A party may not complain on appeal of error or object to a trial procedure which his own conduct has induced); and Harrison v. Bevilacqua, 354 S.C. 129, 139, 580 S.C. 109, 115 (2003)(Petitioner cannot now complain the trial court erred when it took her own suggestion).Â  Therefore, we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s compensation award of $422.07 per week. 
CONCLUSION 
Based on the foregoing, the decision of the circuit court is hereby
AFFIRMED.[2]
HEARN, C.J., and STILWELL and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] In light of our disposition of Schmidtâ€™s back and neck claim based on the causation issue, we need not address Schmidtâ€™s arguments relating to notice.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (stating the appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of a prior issue is dispositive).

title: SCDSS v. Charmaine H.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
v.
        Charmaine H. and John Doe, whose true name is unknown, Defendants,
        Of whom Charmaine H. is Appellant.
        In the interests of: Charnell N. T. (dob:02/27/05), a minor under the age of 18.
      
    
  


Appeal from Lancaster County
Â Roger E. Henderson, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-409
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 13, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Samuel R. Chandler, Jr., of Lancaster, for Appellant.
Angela M. Killian, of Lancaster, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â This is an appeal from the termination of Charmaine Hâ€™s[1] (Motherâ€™s) parental rights with respect to her infant daughter (Child).Â  Mother argues the family court erred in failing to place Child with Angelia M., the childâ€™s maternal grandmother (Grandmother).[2]Â  We affirm.[3]
FACTS
Mother gave birth to Child on February 27, 2005.Â  Because both Mother and Child tested positive for cocaine at the time, South Carolina Department of Social Services (the Department) removed Child from Motherâ€™s custody on March 1, 2005.Â  Mother admitted using cocaine the day before giving birth to Child.Â  On March 4, the family court held a probable cause hearing and determined probable cause existed for the Department to take emergency custody of Child.Â  Subsequently, the family court held a merits and permanency planning hearing.Â  On April 1, the family court approved the Departmentâ€™s plan of â€œtermination of parental rights and adoption concurrent with plans for custody to a suitable, fit and willing relative.â€[4]Â  
On November 1, the family court held a termination of parental rights (TPR) hearing.Â  Initially, the Department interpreted the April 1 order as one in which the judge ordered TPR and adoption, but â€œin the event that T.P.R. and adoption falls through,â€ the concurrent plan would be placement with a fit and willing relative.Â  Mother objected to this characterization of the April 1 order, arguing it called for a hearing to determine whether TPR and adoption or placement with a fit and willing relative would be in the best interests of Child. Â 
The Department presented evidence that Mother had used cocaine and crack cocaine for eleven years; failed to complete the treatment plan recommended by the Department with regard to the removal of two other children the year prior to Childâ€™s birth, including failing to participate in the outpatient drug treatment plan; tested positive in an exit drug screen from the inpatient drug treatment plan; and suffered from psychotic disorder, depressive disorder, anxiety disorder, and polysubstance dependence on cocaine, alcohol, and marijuana.Â  The Department presented evidence that Motherâ€™s condition was unlikely to change in the future.Â Â  
Evidence was also presented regarding whether Grandmother, who was caring for two of Motherâ€™s other children, would be a fit and willing custodian.Â  Because Grandmother lived in North Carolina, the Department submitted a home study conducted by the Union County, North Carolina, Department of Social Services (Union County). Â Although Union County characterized the home study as favorable, the Department had several concerns.Â  The Department noted: (1) the household would be crowded, with Grandmother, her husband, her adult son, and two of Motherâ€™s other children already residing in the home; (2) Grandmotherâ€™s husband (Husband) initially opposed the custodianship; (3) Husband had a drinking problem that caused Grandmother and the other children in the house to leave on occasion; (4) Grandmother was unemployed; (5) the household income did not appear to be enough to support the whole family; and (6) a previous home study on Grandmother had been unfavorable. 
On cross-examination, Motherâ€™s counsel showed Husband agreed to the custodianship and only had one drinking-related offense, a twelve-year-old DUI.Â  Moreover, the home study indicated Child would have her own bed and closet space in Grandmotherâ€™s custody.Â  Additionally, the prior home study had been unfavorable due to Motherâ€™s failure to submit a required verification and Husbandâ€™s refusal to allow more children to live in the home.Â  Both of these problems had been cured at the time of the second home study.Â  Furthermore, the more recent home study noted that Motherâ€™s two other children residing with Grandmother were well-adjusted and respectful.Â  One of the children received an academic scholarship to college while still in middle school.Â  Further, Grandmother had prior experience working with young children as a former teacher in the HeadStart program.Â  
On November 21, the family court issued an order terminating Motherâ€™s parental rights, finding that Mother had abused cocaine and crack cocaine for eleven years, rendering her unlikely to provide minimally acceptable care for Child, and that it was in Childâ€™s best interest for Motherâ€™s rights to be terminated.Â  The court also considered Motherâ€™s request to give custody to Grandmother.Â  The court reviewed the evidence presented for and against granting custody to Grandmother and determined Childâ€™s best interests would be served by terminating Motherâ€™s parental rights and preparing Child for adoption.Â  However, the court held â€œshould [Grandmother] qualify for adoption of the child, preference should be given to [Grandmother] since she is a blood relative.â€Â Â  
Pursuant to Ex Parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354 S.E.2d 381 (1987), Motherâ€™s counsel attached a petition to be relieved stating he reviewed the record and found no issues meriting appeal.Â  Mother did not file a pro se brief.Â  This court conducted its review in accord with Cauthen and ordered the parties to brief the following issue:

Whether the family court erred in denying Motherâ€™s request that Grandmother be granted custody of Child?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Generally, â€œ[i]n appeals from the family court, the appellate court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 61, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006).Â  This is also true in termination of parental rights cases.Â 
Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Jackson, 368 S.C. 87, 95, 627 S.E.2d 765, 770 (Ct. App. 2006) (holding that in an appeal from the termination of parental rights, an appellate court may review the record and make its own determination whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence).Â  Despite this broad scope of review, however, the appellate court should not necessarily disregard the findings of the family court because the family court is in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Id.Â  â€œThis degree of deference is especially true in cases involving the welfare and best interests of a minor child.â€Â 
Ex parte Morris, at 62, 624 S.E.2d at 652.
â€œCustody decisions are matters left largely to the discretion of the family courtâ€.Â  Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 330, 536 S.E.2d 427, 430 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œFurthermore, the appellate court should be reluctant to substitute its own evaluation of the evidence on child custody for that of the family court.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mother contends the family court erred by failing to place Child with Grandmother.[5]Â  She argues that, pursuant to the permanency planning statute, the family court should have given â€œcompelling reasonsâ€ for failing to place Child with Grandmother.Â  We disagree.Â 
As with all custody determinations, the best interest of the child is paramount in termination of parental rights cases.Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œIn a termination of parental rights . . . case, the best interests of the children are the paramount consideration.â€). Â The purpose of the termination of parental rights statute is â€œto establish procedures for the reasonable and compassionate termination of parental rights where children are abused, neglected, or abandoned . . .â€ in order to protect children and to make them eligible for adoption by â€œpersons who will provide a suitable home environment and the love and care necessary for a happy, healthful, and productive life.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1560 (Supp. 2005).
In the permanency planning stage prior to termination of parental rights, the Department may recommend several alternatives for placement of the child, including custody with a fit and willing relative.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-766(A) (Supp. 2005).Â  Mother relies heavily on section 20-7-766(C), which provides:

At the permanency planning hearing, the court shall review the departmentâ€™s plan for achieving permanence for the child.Â  If the departmentâ€™s plan is not reunification with the parents, custody or guardianship with a fit and willing relative, or termination of parental rights, the department must show compelling reasons for the selection of another permanent plan.Â  If the court approves a plan that is not reunification with the parents, custody with a fit and willing relative, or termination of parental rights, the court must find compelling reasons for approval of the plan and that the plan is in the childâ€™s best interests.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-766(C) (Supp. 2005) (emphasis added).Â  Further, our Supreme Court, in dicta, has interpreted section 20-7-766(G): Â â€œ[The] family court at the permanency planning stage for a child removed from his home may award custody or legal guardianship to a â€˜suitable, fit, and willing relative or nonrelative.â€™â€Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 63, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006) (interpreting section 20-7-766(G) in a parenthetical to show the Legislature contemplates non-relatives may play an important role in a childâ€™s life).
Mother argues the family court erred by failing to place Child with Grandmother because, as a â€œfit and willing relative,â€ the court has to give compelling reasons to place Child someplace else.Â  Mother has misapprehended the permanency planning statute.Â  Although the General Assembly has provided that fit and willing relatives should be considered, the statute provides that the family court must only give â€œcompelling reasonsâ€ when it approves a plan that is something other than â€œreunification with the parents, custody or guardianship with a fit and willing relative, or termination of parental rights.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-766(C) (Supp. 2005).Â  Because the court approved of termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights, one of the options in the statute, the court did not err by failing to give â€œcompelling reasonsâ€ for failing to place Child with Grandmother.Â  Further, section 20-7-766 does not address whether the Department or the family court must consider placement with a fit and willing relative before or after TPR.[6]Â  Â Â 
Moreover, the family courtâ€™s order does not preclude Grandmother from adopting Child.Â  The family court anticipated Grandmotherâ€™s involvement in Childâ€™s adoption proceedings.Â  Although the family court did not expressly rule on whether Grandmother was a â€œfit and willing relative,â€ the court ordered the Department to give preference to Grandmother in the event she is found fit and willing.Â Â  
Although the family court approved of a permanent plan for termination of parental rights concurrent with placement with a fit and willing relative, we find the family court did not err in terminating Motherâ€™s parental rights.Â  Under these circumstances, we hold Childâ€™s best interests would be served by allowing the Department to complete its investigation of Grandmotherâ€™s status as a fit and willing relative of Child.Â  See Joiner v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 107, 536 S.E.2d 372, 374 (2000) (affirming the Court of Appealsâ€™ finding that â€œprocedural rules are subservient to the courtâ€™s
duty to zealously guard the rights of minorsâ€); Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. at 579, 578 S.E.2d at 735 (holding the best interests of the child is paramount in termination of parental rights cases); Ex parte Dibble, 279 S.C. 592, 595, 310 S.E.2d 440, 442 (Ct. App. 1983) (â€œCourts
have the inherent power to do all things reasonably necessary
to insure that just results are reached to the fullest extent possible.â€).Â  This procedure allows Grandmother to assert any rights she claims as a relative of Child.Â  
CONCLUSION
The family court properly terminated the parental rights of Mother.Â  In doing so, the court denied placement of Child with Grandmother.Â  However, the court did not foreclose the possibility of Grandmother adopting Child.Â  Because the court considered Childâ€™s best interest in its ruling, the family courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.

 HEARN, C.J., BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] In order to protect the identities of the parties, we refer to them only by their first names and the last initial.
[2] Childâ€™s father is unknown.Â  The unknown father was served by publication, and the family court terminated his parental rights.Â  He is not a party to this appeal.
[3] Â Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[4] This order is not included in the record.Â  However, both the attorney for Mother and the family court paraphrased the April 1 order in almost identical language.Â  
[5]Â  Mother does not challenge the family courtâ€™s decision to terminate her parental rights, and the record clearly supports the family courtâ€™s decision.Â  As Mother does not appeal the termination of her parental rights, it is the law of the case.Â 
South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Seegars, 367 S.C. 623, 628 n.3, 627 S.E.2d 718, 721 n.3 (2006) (holding that failure to appeal a family court ruling renders it the law of the case).
[6] In addition, we note Grandmother has not been made a party to the family courtâ€™s proceedings.Â  Furthermore, we express our concern that Mother may not have standing to assert Grandmotherâ€™s rights to receive custody of Child.

title: State v. Whitmire
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Travis Whitmire, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-410
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 13, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott; Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, of Columbia; Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville; for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant, Travis Whitmire, was indicted and tried for first-degree burglary, conspiracy, and three counts of armed robbery.Â  Whitmire was convicted of the conspiracy and burglary charges, as well as two of the armed robbery charges, and the trial court sentenced him to concurrent sentences of twenty-five years on the burglary and armed robbery convictions, and five years for conspiracy. Whitmire appeals, asserting the trial court erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On the night of November 8, 2001, Corey Bagwell and his girlfriend Kami Johnson were in their bedroom in the trailer they shared with Coreyâ€™s brother, Jonathan.Â  Around 10:00 p.m., Corey was falling asleep and Kami was watching television when a black male with a rifle quickly pushed open their bedroom door.Â  This man alerted another that there was â€œsomebody else in here,â€ and a second black male entered the room with a pistol grip shotgun.Â  The two men told Corey to give them all his money.Â  When Corey reached for his wallet one of the men hit him in the head with a gun.Â  Corey gave them his wallet, which contained approximately $50.Â  The two men grabbed a DVD player and began â€œtearing [the bedroom] apart,â€ pulling things out of a closet, a trunk and some drawers.Â  The men were â€œyelling for more money,â€ and Corey told them to look in his entertainment center, where there was $2,800 in cash. Â The $2,800 was money borrowed for the purpose of Kamiâ€™s school tuition.Â  During this ordeal, Corey could hear someone else yelling like the two men in his room had been, and he assumed it was someone talking to his brother, Jonathan.Â  
After the men finished ransacking the bedroom and collecting the money, they made Corey and Kami crawl on their hands and knees into the living room.Â  Once in the living room, Corey saw his brother, as well as his brotherâ€™s friend who was being dragged across the floor by another male.Â  The intruders screamed â€œthat it wasnâ€™t a game,â€ and two of the men ran out while the third man with the pistol grip shotgun made the victims crawl into the kitchen.Â  The third man stood on the back porch waiting for a car.Â  When Corey heard tires squealing, he looked up to make sure they were gone and went next door to check on his parents.Â  Corey stated he had never seen the three men that came into his home before that night.Â  When he and Kami were driven to a location by officers to view some suspects, both told the officers that the two men at the location were two of the men that had robbed them that night.Â  They later learned that one of the men was not ultimately charged in the case.Â  
Jonathan testified that on the night of November 8, 2001, his friend Ray Godfrey was visiting him at his home.Â  An acquaintance of his, Amber Nalley, called and indicated she and a friend wanted to come over to his home.Â  Jonathan had never met Amberâ€™s friend, but had spoken to her on the phone that night.Â  When the girls arrived, they walked back to Jonathanâ€™s bedroom where Ray was.Â  They planned to watch a movie and â€œchill with the girls.â€Â  At some point, both girls left the room to go to the bathroom.Â  Jonathan thought the two would come walking back into the bedroom, but instead a man appeared with a shotgun.Â  The man asked where a key was to a filing cabinet and demanded money. Â Another man appeared and began ripping things off of Jonathanâ€™s entertainment center, and going through his jewelry and closet.Â  Jonathan saw two guns, a long one and a short pistol grip.Â  The second man did not stay in his room very long, but left and went through the house to another room.Â  The men were asking Jonathan for money and when he did not respond quickly, one of them hit Jonathan in the back of the head with the longer shotgun.Â  Jonathan stated he blacked out after he was hit, and when he came to, he and Ray were instructed to go toward the kitchen.Â  Ray was being kicked and drug across the floor into the other room while Jonathan was forced to crawl in there on his hands and knees.Â  He was on one side of the bar in the kitchen when he saw Corey and Kami brought out there and placed on the other side of the bar.Â  The intruders took Jonathanâ€™s watches and some money, including $160 from his filing cabinet and between $50 and $70 from his pocket.Â  They also took some money and some drugs from Ray.Â  Jonathan stated he had never seen any of these men before that night.Â  After the intruders left, Jonathan called the police.Â  When they arrived, he gave them Amber Nalleyâ€™s name and told them where she lived.Â  
Officers Ridgeway and Weiner with the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Office received information over their radios concerning Amber Nalley as a suspect in this matter.Â  Officer Weiner knew Amber from previous dealings and knew where she lived.Â  The two officers therefore responded to the location of Amberâ€™s address.Â  As Officer Weiner spoke to Amberâ€™s grandmother in the home, Officer Ridgeway remained on the street.Â  While standing near his vehicle, Officer Ridgeway observed a car matching the description of the suspectsâ€™ vehicle about a block away.Â  The car stopped, turned, and went up a street.Â  The officer noticed the car was traveling at a low rate of speed and without any lights.Â  He then saw it being driven at a high rate of speed at which time Officer Ridgeway pursued the vehicle until it eventually stopped in a driveway.Â  Officer Ridgeway observed two females in the front seat, and two black males in the back seat.Â  The males were shoving the seats onto the females, attempting to get out of the car.Â  When the males did finally exit the car, they ran off in different directions.Â  The two females in the car were Lauren Revelle and Amber Nalley.Â  Amber and Lauren were arrested and transported to the law enforcement center.Â  The two males, who were caught a short time later in the area, were Frederick Harris (Fred) and Shamar Harris.Â  At the time of his apprehension, Fred had $457.26 in his possession. Â Officers also recovered Jonathanâ€™s two watches in the area where Fred was hiding.Â  Fred was arrested in regard to this matter.Â  Shamar was also arrested, but his arrest was based on a warrant unrelated to this matter.Â  
Based on statements made by Lauren and Amber, the officers executed a search warrant at the home of Fred.Â  There they recovered a pistol grip shotgun and a long rifle shotgun that Corey testified looked like the guns he observed in the home invasion.Â  Officers also searched room 106 at the best Way Motel after receiving consent from Lauren Revelle.Â  There they collected a handwritten note with a message in parentheses in the top corner of â€œIâ€™m getting some cardsâ€ and the following main notation on that side:Â  â€œFred, call me at the house.Â  I called a cab to take the yamean to the house.Â  I left at 11:10 p.m., me and Mark together.Â  Call me, man, I want to come back.â€Â  The reverse side of the note stated, â€œI will be back, went home.â€Â  An expert in the area of handwriting analysis determined appellant had written the front side of the note referring to calling a cab to take the â€œyameanâ€ to the house.Â  She concluded the reverse side of the note was written by someone named Mark Johnson.Â  
Lauren Revelle testified on behalf of the State.Â  She stated that at the time of the incident, Fred was her boyfriend. Â She had never met Amber Nalley prior to that day, but did know Mark Johnson and appellant through Fred.Â  The afternoon of the robbery, she received a call from appellant and Mark.Â  The three of them then picked up Amber, who showed them how to get to the targeted house.Â  At that time, no one had any guns with them.Â  From that location, they drove to Amberâ€™s house and dropped her off.Â  Appellant, Mark and Lauren then went to appellantâ€™s apartment, where appellant called Fred and told him they had seen the house and that Amber had recommended the robbery take place that evening.Â  After running some errands, they went back to appellantâ€™s apartment and waited for Fred to call.Â  Appellant eventually called Fred, at which time they decided to meet at a Hardeeâ€™s.Â  From there, Lauren, Fred, Mark and appellant went to Fredâ€™s apartment.Â  Fred and Mark came out with two bags with guns in them.Â  From there, the four went to the targeted location.Â  They had planned for Lauren to drop the three men off and wait on them while they robbed the people inside.Â  Fred, Mark and appellant exited the car with the guns, but came back to the car about two minutes later because they did not have a means of getting into the house and they were concerned about some dogs.Â  They drove to a gas station where Fred called Amber, and then subsequently drove to Amberâ€™s house where Mark, Fred, Amber and appellant discussed a new plan.Â  Amber was to arrange a visit to the house on the pretense of buying drugs and then let the others into the house.Â  
Amber stated she called Jonathan as planned and Jonathan said they could come over and â€œdo some stuff for free.â€Â  They all then went over to the location, where Lauren and Amber dropped Fred, Mark and appellant off with the guns about one hundred feet from the house.Â  The plan was for Mark to â€œget the stuffâ€ and appellant and Fred to have the guns.Â  Amber and Lauren were let into the house and went back to the bedroom where they watched TV and talked to Jonathan and his friend.Â  Amber and Lauren left the room to go to the bathroom.Â  At that time, Lauren signaled Fred, Mark and appellant by opening the blinds on the door.Â  Within a minute, the door opened and Fred, Mark and appellant came into the house.Â  The bedroom door opened and Lauren heard yelling and saw guns being pointed.Â  She testified it was Fred and appellant who had gone into the bedroom.Â  The intruding men were loud and mean, demanding things and cussing.Â  Lauren and Amber ran out to the car and drove a little bit up the road.Â  Fred, Mark and appellant came back to the car with the guns, a DVD player, bags of jewelry, drugs and money.Â  The five then went to Best Way Motel, where Lauren got them a room, and they counted up the money and split everything three ways. Â Lauren, Fred and Amber left Mark and appellant at the hotel because Fred wanted to take the guns back to the apartment and Amber wanted to get her things from her house.Â  They planned to meet Mark and appellant back at the hotel.Â  The three went to Fredâ€™s apartment, where Fred took the guns inside and brought his cousin, Shamar Harris, back out with him.Â  They headed to Amberâ€™s house, where they saw the police cars and attempted to avoid them.Â  When they subsequently stopped, Fred and Shamar ran from the car and Lauren and Amber were arrested.Â  
Amber testified she signed a release for them to search the hotel room.Â  She stated the word â€œyameanâ€ on the note found in the hotel room was slang for â€œyou know what I meanâ€ and referred to â€œthe stuff.â€Â  In exchange for her cooperation, Lauren was offered a plea bargain where the State would recommend probation for her.Â  She pled guilty to conspiracy and received a probationary sentence.Â  
After the State rested, appellant moved for a directed verdict as to the robbery of Kami asserting there was â€œno theft of her propertyâ€ since the money taken was obtained by Corey.Â  He further asserted he was entitled to â€œa directed verdict on the entire caseâ€ because the State did not â€œhave enough to move forward.â€Â  The trial court denied both motions.Â  Following their presentation of alibi evidence, the defense rested and renewed its previous motions, which the trial court denied.Â  The jury found appellant guilty of conspiracy, burglary in the first degree, and two counts of armed robbery involving Corey and Jonathan.Â  Appellant was acquitted of armed robbery of Kami.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, appellant contends the trial court erred in denying his motion for directed verdict because â€œno probative evidence placed appellant at the scene of the crime.â€Â  He argues the only evidence placing him at the scene was the â€œwholly unreliable testimony of Lauren Revelle,â€ who received a reduced sentence in exchange for her testimony. He maintains Laurenâ€™s testimony was â€œextortedâ€ by the Stateâ€™s promises and it should not qualify as substantial probative evidence, particularly in light of the facts that the victims identified another man and there was no physical evidence to implicate him.Â  
It is questionable whether appellant has preserved this argument for our review.Â  Although he did generally argue the evidence was insufficient in his directed verdict motion, he never argued below, as he does now, that the evidence was insufficient because there was no probative evidence of his presence at the scene of the crime.Â  See State v. Freiburger, 366 S.C. 125, 135, 620 S.E.2d 737, 742 (2005) (â€œThe rule is well established that if asserted errors are not presented to the lower Court, the question cannot be raised for the first time on appeal.â€);Â  State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 53, 58-59, 609 S.E.2d 520, 523 (2005) (an objection should be addressed to the trial court in a sufficiently specific manner that brings attention to the exact error and if Â a party fails to properly object, the party is procedurally barred from raising the issue on appeal);Â  State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 634, 591 S.E.2d 600, 606 (2004) (appellant, who argued at trial only that he was entitled to a directed verdict on the basis that he was not directly involved in the sale of urine kits and that there was no evidence the individual who purchased his urine kits had any intent to defraud a drug test, failed to preserve for appellate review his claim on appeal that he was entitled to a directed verdict on the ground there was no evidence the kits were sold with the intent to defraud);Â  State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 120-21, 481 S.E.2d 118, 123 (1997)Â  (â€œAn issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€)Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
Even if this general objection is deemed sufficient to preserve the specific grounds now argued on appeal, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s denial of the motion.Â  In ruling on a motion for directed verdict in a criminal case, a trial court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the
State. Â State v. Wakefield, 323 S.C. 189, 196, 473 S.E.2d 831, 835 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight.
Â State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 555, 564 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2002). â€œA defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the
State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.â€ Â State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 97, 544 S.E.2d 30, 36 (2001).Â  Furthermore, the trial court should not refuse to grant the directed verdict motion when the evidence merely raises a suspicion that the accused is guilty.
Â State v. Mitchell, 341 S.C. 406, 409, 535 S.E.2d 126, 127 (2000).
When reviewing a denial of a directed verdict, this court, as well, must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the
State. State v. Weston, 367 S.C. 279, 292, 625 S.E.2d 641, 648 (2006).Â  If there is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, we must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.
Â State v. McCombs, 368 S.C. 489, 493, 629 S.E.2d 361, 363 (2006).Â  
Here, the State presented sufficient evidence of appellantâ€™s participation in the crimes to support the trial courtâ€™s denial of the directed verdict motion.Â  Lauren testified appellant participated in the planning of the crime, and was one of the three men who entered the home with guns that evening.Â  She specifically pointed appellant out as having entered Jonathanâ€™s bedroom, demanding things and cussing in a loud manner. Â The fact that appellant asserts Laurenâ€™s testimony should not be believed is not a basis for a directed verdict.Â  Instead, appellantsâ€™ argument creates a credibility issue to be resolved by the jury.Â  See State v. Ham, 268 S.C. 340, 342, 233 S.E.2d 698, 698 (1997) (â€œWhere the determination of guilt is dependant upon the credibility of the witnesses, a motion for a directed verdict is properly refused.â€) Â Additionally, the testimony from the victims corroborates that three men were involved in the home invasion, along with Lauren and Amber.Â  Laurenâ€™s testimony also explains how Shamar, who was not arrested in this matter, came to be with her, Amber and Fred when they were stopped by the police, and Mark and appellant were not. Â Finally, appellantâ€™s presence at the hotel room, which Lauren indicated she registered for after the home invasion, was corroborated through testimony from the handwriting expert linking the note found in the room that night to appellant. 
For the foregoing reasons, appellantâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Rhodes v. Eadon
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Samuel W. Rhodes, Jr. and Piedmont Promotions, Inc.,
Respondents,
v.
Marion L. Eadon, d/b/a C&B Fabrication, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Fairfield County
Â Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-413
Heard November 9, 2006 â€“ Filed December 15, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Catharine Garbee Griffin, Charles E. Carpenter, Jr., Carmen V. Ganjehsani, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Creighton B. Coleman, of Winnsboro; Hoover C. Blanton, of Columbia; for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Marion L. Eadon appeals the jury award of $5,000 for breach of contract, $5,000 for breach of implied warranty, $3,000,000 for negligence, and $3,500,000 in punitive damages to Samuel W. Rhodes, Jr.Â  Eadon argues the trial court erred in (1) denying his motion to transfer venue; (2) allowing a verdict against him as an individual; (3) excluding evidence; (4) allowing a punitive damages award; and (5) denying his post-trial motions for a new trial absolute, or, in the alternative, a new trial nisi remittitur.Â  We reverse and remand.Â  
FACTS
In September 1998, Eadon formed C&B Fabricators, Inc., a statutory close corporation.Â  C&B Fabricatorsâ€™ principal business was manufacturing and erecting outdoor signs.Â  Eadon hired Chuck Benenhaley to be manager of the company.Â  
Sometime in 1999, Rhodes, representing Piedmont Promotions, Inc. (Piedmont),[1] contacted Eadon and Benenhaley about building and erecting three outdoor advertising signs on property in Fairfield County.Â  Rhodes received a proposal from â€œC&B Fabricationâ€ for the fabrication, building, and installation of the three signs.Â  Rhodes accepted the proposal in August 1999.Â  
The South Carolina Department of Transportation (SCDOT) had issued Piedmont permits to construct and maintain the three outdoor advertising signs upon the property in Fairfield County.[2]Â  Piedmont represented to SCDOT that the property would be the future sight of a car business, Interstate Auto Sales (Interstate), owned by Rhodesâ€™ wife. Â The property was located within an unzoned commercial or industrial area.[3]Â  
Subsequently, three signs were built and erected. Â Rhodes tendered full payment, in three installments, for the signs.Â  Payment was made by check from Piedmont Promotions.Â  The first payment was made to â€œC&B Fabrication;â€ the other payments were made to â€œC&B Fabricators.â€Â  
In December 2000, Rhodes noticed his middle sign was leaning.Â  Rhodes called Eadon several times about fixing the sign. Â Rhodes also faxed Eadon about the sign; the faxes were addressed to â€œMr. Marion Eadon, C&B Fabricators.â€Â  Eadon informed Rhodes â€œC&B Fabricationâ€ went out of business.Â  Nevertheless, Eadon sent a crew to fix the sign.Â  A few days later, a different sign fell onto I-77.Â  
SCDOT deemed all three signs unsafe and ordered Rhodes to remove the signs.Â  Thereafter, SCDOT cancelled Rhodesâ€™s billboard permits because the signs were â€œunsafe and present a hazard to the motoring public.â€Â  Rhodes submitted an application for new permits which SCDOT denied finding that Interstate was not a qualifying commercial business, but was being operated as a sham.[4]Â  Rhodes appealed to the Administrative Law Judge. Â The ALJ affirmed SCDOTâ€™s decision holding Rhodesâ€™s business was a sham activity,[5] not a commercial activity, and therefore the refusal to grant permits for re-erection of the outdoor signs was justified. 
In December 2001, Rhodes and Piedmont filed an action against Eadon, d/b/a C&B Fabrication, in Fairfield County.Â  The complaint alleged causes of action for breach of contract, breach of warranty, strict liability, fraudulent breach of contract, fraud, constructive fraud, negligent misrepresentation, negligence, bad faith, nuisance, and violation of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act.Â  
Eadon filed a motion to transfer venue to Clarendon County, the county of his residence.Â  The trial court denied the motion pursuant to section 15-7-10 of the South Carolina Code (2005).Â  Specifically, the trial court held the action arises out of â€œinjuries to real propertyâ€ and â€œmust be tried in the county in which the subject of the action or some part thereof is situated.â€Â  
A jury trial was held in Fairfield County.Â  At the trialâ€™s conclusion, the only causes of action submitted to the jury were for breach of contract, breach of warranty, and negligence.Â  The jury returned a verdict of $5,000 for breach of contract; $5,000 in actual damages for breach of an implied warranty; and $3,000,000 in actual damages for negligence, and $3,500,000 in punitive damages.Â  
Eadon filed post-trial motions for judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV), a new trial, a new trial nisi remittitur, and a post-trial review of the punitive damages award.Â  After hearing arguments, the trial court denied all of Eadonâ€™s post-trial motions.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Eadon argues the trial court erred in denying his motion to transfer venue.Â  We agree.
Motions to change the venue of a trial are addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Garrett v. Packet Motor Express Co., 263 S.C. 463, 465, 210 S.E.2d 912, 912 (1975).Â  The trial courtâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed unless it appears a manifest legal error was committed.Â  Turner v. Santee Cement Carriers, Inc., 277 S.C. 91, 94, 282 S.E.2d 858, 859 (1981).
Unless provided for in sections 15-7-10 or 15-7-20 of the South Carolina Code (2005), all actions â€œshall be tried in the county in which the defendant resides at the time of the commencement of the action.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-7-30 (2005);[6] see also Jeter v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 369 S.C. 433, ___, 633 S.E.2d 143, 147 (2006) (interpreting section 15-7-30 to mean all cases not falling within sections 15-7-10 or 15-7-20 must be tried in the county of defendantâ€™s residence).Â  Section 15-7-10 provides that actions â€œ[f]or the recovery of real property or of an estate or interest therein or for the determination in any form of such right or interest and for injuries to real property,â€ must be tried in the county in which the â€œsubject of the actionâ€ or some part thereof is situated.[7]Â  Â Â Â Â 
In Coastal Mall, Inc. v. Askins, 265 S.C. 307, 217 S.E.2d 725 (1975), the Supreme Court of South Carolina analyzed the rule fixing venue of actions for injuries to real property.Â  The court noted â€œthe term â€˜injuryâ€™ is used in a technical sense and as meaning every wrong which in legal contemplation is an injury to real property, and the rule is not limited to actions for physical injury to realty, or to physical interference therewith . . .â€Â  Id. at 310, 217 S.E.2d at 726 (citation omitted).Â  The court also noted a statute relating to actions for injuries to real property does not apply â€œwhere an action for certain relief is essentially one to enforce a personal obligation.â€Â  Id. at 310, 217 S.E.2d at 727 (citation omitted).Â  The court found the pivotal question at hand was not whether there was any remote or incidental injury to real property, but rather what is â€œthe subject of the action.â€Â  Id. at 311, 217 S.E.2d at 727.Â  The court interpreted â€œsubject of the actionâ€ to mean â€œthe plaintiffâ€™s primary right.â€Â  Id. at 311-12, 217 S.E.2d at 727.
In Coastal Mall, the defendant, Askins, agreed to construct a business mall, including a pre-designed canopy structure, for Coastal Mall.Â  When a portion of the canopy collapsed rendering it useless, Coastal Mall filed an action alleging Askins negligently installed the canopy structure.Â  The court found the â€œsubject of the actionâ€ was Coastal Mallâ€™s right to have a construction contract properly performed.Â  Id. at 312, 217 S.E.2d at 727.Â  Thus, the court held venue was not proper in the county of Coastal Mallâ€™s property and should have been transferred to the county of Askinsâ€™s residence.Â  Id. at 312, 217 S.E.2d at 727-28.Â  
Similarly, in Friarsgate, Inc. v. Irmo, 281 S.C. 588, 589, 316 S.E.2d 423, 424 (Ct. App. 1984), this court held section 15-7-10 was inapplicable.Â  In Friarsgate, the court found no injury to real property because the suit was not filed to â€œrecover an estate or interest in real property,â€ or â€œfor a determination that it has an estate or interest in real property.â€Â  Id.  
Thus, in order to find venue is proper under section 15-7-30, the court must find the â€œplaintiffâ€™s primary rightâ€ arises from an injury to real property; it is not sufficient to find an injury to real property has resulted from the actions of the defendant.Â  In this case, the main impetus behind the lawsuit is the alleged breach of contract and/or negligence in constructing the outdoor signs by Eadon.Â  Indeed, as in Coastal Mall, â€œif there be any â€˜injury to real propertyâ€™ involved in this case such was only to that which became realty upon being constructed by the defendant under his contract.â€Â  265 S.C. at 311, 217 S.E.2d at 727. Â Accordingly, we find venue was not proper in Fairfield County and the trial court erred in failing to grant Eadonâ€™s motion to transfer venue to Clarendon County.Â  Because the trial court had no jurisdiction to do anything but grant a change in venue, we reverse and remand for entry of an order changing the venue to Clarendon County.[8]  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing we hold the trial court erred in denying the motion to transfer venue.Â  In view of our disposition of this case, we need not address Appellantâ€™s remaining issues. Â See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (stating appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive). Â The decision of the circuit court is accordingly
 REVERSED and REMANDED. 
 ANDERSON, HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] 
Rhodes is President and sole owner of Piedmont. 
[2]  Under the Highway Advertising Control Act, the General Assembly granted SCDOT the authority to issue permits for the erection and maintenance of commercial outdoor signs and to promulgate regulations governing the issuance of permits.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§57-25-150(A) (Supp. 2001).Â  The Act generally limits the placement of commercial outdoor advertising signs to zoned industrial areas, zoned commercial areas, unzoned commercial areas, or unzoned industrial areas.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§57-25-140(7) & (8) (Supp. 2001).Â  
[3]  According to S.C. Code Ann Â§ 57-25-120(4) (Supp. 2000) an unzoned commercial or industrial area is â€œthe land occupied by the regularly used building, parking lot, and storage and processing area of a commercial business or industrial activity and land within six hundred feet of it on both sides of the highway.â€
[4] 
A sham activity is defined as, â€œany activity that is seemingly a commercial or industrial activity but which was created primarily or exclusively to qualify an area as an unzoned commercial or industrial area and which does not conduct any meaningful business at the activity site.â€Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 63-342 (U) (Supp. 2000).Â Â Â Â Â  
[5] 
The ALJ acknowledged that Piedmont initially qualified for the permits by proposing to conduct a commercial business within six hundred feet of the highway.Â  However, the ALJ found Interstate failed to maintain the standards established to constitute qualifying commercial activity, citing that the water service was cut off, there was no operable restroom, the cars onsite were vandalized and had not been repaired and that two or three cars were inoperable. 
[6]  The 2005 amendments to 15-7-30 are not applicable to this case. Â See 15-7-30 (Supp. 2005) (providing amendments are applicable to causes of action arising on or after July 1, 2005).
[7]  The 2006 amendments to 15-7-10 are not applicable to this case. Â See Act No. 354, 2006 S.C. Acts 2779, 2780 (providing amendment does not affect pending actions).Â  Â 
[8]  We note the unchallenged ruling by the trial court that the signs were fixtures on Rhodesâ€™s property does not affect our decision.Â  The fact the signs were fixtures is irrelevant for determining whether the â€œsubject of the actionâ€ involves an injury to real estate.Â
