title: State v. Jenkins
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Walter Jenkins, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-414
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 15, 2006Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia, and Solicitor I. McDuffie Stone, III, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Walter Jenkins was indicted for distribution of crack cocaine and distribution of crack cocaine within a half mile of a school. Â He was convicted as charged and the trial court sentenced him to ten years imprisonment on each charge, the sentences to run concurrently.Â  Jenkins appeals, arguing the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on the defense of entrapment.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On April 14, 2004, officers with the Beaufort County Drug Task Force set up a controlled buy using a confidential informant (hereinafter informant) to purchase drugs.Â  The informant was searched, equipped with audio and video recording devices, given $40 of prerecorded money, and dropped off in close proximity to the targeted location, a well known drug house and the home of Walter Jenkins.Â  
The informant testified that on April 14, 2004, he made a drug buy for the Drug Task Force.Â  On that day, Walter Jenkins was the target of the controlled buy.[2]Â  Prior to going to the targeted location, the informant told the officer the target in this case may want to be paid in drugs and asked what he should do if the target asked for a portion of the crack instead of money for payment.Â  The officer instructed the informant not to distribute the drugs himself, but it was okay if the target â€œpinchedâ€ out of the bag, taking part of the crack himself.Â  The informant testified that a â€œpinching paymentâ€ is considered a standard custom.Â  
When the informant arrived at Jenkinsâ€™ home, Jenkinsâ€™ nephew directed him to the bedroom.Â  The informant approached Jenkins and told him that he wanted to â€œget something for forty.â€Â  Jenkins responded by asking the informant where he was going to get it.Â  The informant suggested a man who lived around the corner named Henry may have something.Â  Jenkins then picked up the phone and dialed a number.Â  While talking on the phone, Jenkins stated he would â€œpick them up at the gate within two minutes.â€ Â The informant stated he did not hand Jenkins the phone or give him any information other than suggesting Henry as a possible source.Â  The informant did not know who Jenkins talked to on the phone.Â  The informant gave Jenkins $40, Jenkins left, and the informant remained in the room waiting for him.Â  When Jenkins retuned, he had a plastic bag containing crack in his hand.Â  Jenkins told the informant to give him a portion of the crack in payment, and the informant instructed Jenkins to take what he thought he deserved.Â  Once Jenkins took a portion, he handed the bag with the remainder of the crack to the informant and the informant left.Â  In response to a question on cross-examination, the informant stated the reason he chose to â€œgo thereâ€ was because he had â€œpurchased drugs from Mr. Walter Jenkins in the past.â€Â  
At the close of the Stateâ€™s case, Jenkins moved for a directed verdict arguing, in part, that the facts showed he was â€œentrapped in the sale of cocaine.â€Â  The court denied the motion.Â  The defense then rested without presenting any evidence.Â  Thereafter, Jenkins requested the court charge the jury on the defense of entrapment.Â  The State opposed the charge.Â  The trial court determined there was evidence of record that the informant had purchased drugs from Jenkins in the past, and declined to charge the law on entrapment.Â  The jury found Jenkins guilty on both the distribution and proximity charge and the court sentenced him to concurrent ten year sentences.Â  This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Jenkins argues the trial court erred in refusing to instruct the jury on the defense of entrapment. Â We disagree.
â€œ[E]ntrapment occurs: â€˜(W)here one is instigated, induced or lured by an officer of the law or other person for the purpose of prosecution into the commission of a crime which he had otherwise no intention of committing.â€™â€Â  State v. Hayden, 268 S.C. 214, 219, 232 S.E.2d 889, 891 (1977) (quoting State v. Haulcomb, 260 S.C. 260, 195 S.E.2d 601 (1973)).Â  â€œThe affirmative defense of entrapment is available where there is the â€˜conception and planning of an offense by an officer, and his procurement of its commission by one who would not have perpetrated it except for trickery, persuasion, or fraud of the officer.â€™â€Â  State v. Johnson, 295 S.C. 215, 216, 367 S.E.2d 700, 701 (1988) (quoting State v. Jacobs, 238 S.C. 234, 244, 119 S.E.2d 735, 740 (1961)) (emphasis added).Â  â€œIt is a well settled principle of law that the defense of entrapment is not available to a defendant exhibiting a predisposition to commit a crime independent of governmental inducement and influence.â€Â  Id. at 217, 367 S.E.2d at 701. Although a confidential informant is not a law enforcement officer, where he acts at the behest of an officer, his actions may amount to governmental trickery or persuasion.Â  Id.Â  at 216 n.1, 367 S.E. 2d at 701 n.1.Â  One who pleads entrapment has the burden of showing that he was induced, tricked or incited to commit a crime, which he would not otherwise have committed.Â Â Â  Id. at 217, 367 S.E.2d at 701.Â  â€œThe fact that a government official â€˜merely afford[s] opportunities or facilities for the commission of the offense does not constitute entrapment.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting Sherman v. United States, 356 U.S. 369, 372, 78 S.Ct. 819, 821, 2 L.Ed.2d 848 (1958)).Â  See also, State v. Haulcomb, 260 S.C. 260, 269, 195 S.E.2d 601, 605 (1973) (â€œWhen a law enforcement officer merely provides an opportunity for crime, no entrapment is envolved.â€).Â  The entrapment defense consists of the following two elements:Â  (1) government inducement, and (2) lack of predisposition.Â  State v. Brown, 362 S.C. 258, 262, 607 S.E.2d 93, 95 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Matthews v. United States, 485 U.S. 58, 63, 108 S.Ct. 883, 99 L.Ed.2d 54 (1988)).Â  â€œThus, â€˜[t]he court may find as a matter of law that no entrapment existed, when there is no evidence in the record that, if believed by the jury, would show that the governmentâ€™s conduct created a substantial risk that the offense would be committed by a person other than one ready and willing to commit it.â€™â€Â  Id. at 263, 607 S.E.2d at 95 (quoting United States v. Osborne, 935 F.2d 32, 38 (4th Cir.1991)).
In State v. Brown, 362 S.C. 258, 607 S.E.2d 93 (Ct. App. 2004), this court found the defendant was entitled to a jury charge on the law of entrapment.Â  However, in Brown, we noted there was no evidence of any prior drug transactions between the confidential informant and Brown.Â  Id. at 264, 607 S.E.2d at 96. Â Nor was there any evidence of record that Brown had a history of drug dealing.Â  Id. at 261 n.1, 607 S.E.2d at 94 n.1.Â  We further found there was evidence of record of Brownâ€™s lack of predisposition to commit the offense of distribution of cocaine.Â  Id. at 264-65, 607 S.E.2d at 96. 
Unlike Brown, the evidence in the case at hand shows Jenkinsâ€™ predisposition to participate in illegal drug activity.Â  After the informant told Jenkins he wanted to â€œget something for fortyâ€ and suggested Henry may have something, Jenkins, on his own, picked up the phone, dialed a number, and spoke with someone, stating to that party he would â€œpick them up at the gate within two minutes.â€Â  When the informant gave Jenkins $40, Jenkins left and shortly thereafter retuned with crack cocaine. Â Jenkins then gave the crack cocaine to the informant and received a portion of the drug in payment.Â  Further, the record contains undisputed evidence the informant had purchased drugs from Jenkins in the past.Â  
This case is more in line with this courtâ€™s decision in State v. Cooper, 302 S.C. 184, 394 S.E.2d 717 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  There, we found no error in the trial courtâ€™s refusal to charge the jury on the defense of entrapment.Â  Id. at 185, 394 S.E.2d at 718. Â Cooperâ€™s conviction arose out of her delivery of drugs to an undercover agent, which she purchased from a dealer with money supplied by the undercover agent. Â Id. Â Noting evidence that Cooper was an â€œadmitted purchaserâ€ of crack cocaine, that she participated in the drug buy expecting to share in the purchase, and did in fact receive a portion of crack cocaine in payment, we determined the evidence showed Cooper engaged in illegal activity because of her own preexisting readiness to do so.Â  Id. at 186, 394 S.E.2d at 718.Â  
As in Cooper, the evidence shows Jenkins engaged in the drug deal, not because of any governmental inducement, but because he was ready and willing to engage in the illegal activity and was predisposed to commit the crime.Â  We therefore find no error in the trial courtâ€™s refusal to charge the jury on the defense of entrapment.Â  Accordingly, Jenkinsâ€™ convictions are Â 
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] While Jenkins was the target that day, the case officer on this matter testified the target location was a well known drug house and anyone at the house could have sold the drugs and that would have â€œconstituted our buy.â€Â

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

        Jessie Van Hoose, Scotty Smith, Mitchell Jones,

        of whom Jessie Van Hoose is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â R. Kinard Johnson, Jr., Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 2006-UP-415
Submitted December 15, 2006 â€“ Filed December 18, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Donald E. Kamb, Jr., and Jessie Van Hoose, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Danielle M. Mitchell, of Greenville, for Respondent.
Robert A. Clark, of Greenville, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: This appeal arises from the termination of parental rights (TPR) of Jessie Van Hoose (Mother) to her minor child.Â Â  The court found Motherâ€™s parental rights should be terminated because: 1) the child has been harmed as defined in section 20-7-490, and because of the severity or repetition of abuse or neglect, it is not reasonably likely that the home can be made safe within twelve months; 2) Mother has failed to remedy the conditions which required removal; 3) Mother has willfully failed to visit the child for a period of six months; 4) Mother has willfully failed to support the child for a period of six months; 5) Mother has a diagnosable condition of drug addiction which is unlikely to change within a reasonable period of time, and the condition makes her unlikely to provide minimally acceptable care; and 6) the minor child has been in the custody of DSS for greater than fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (1)-(4), (6), & (8) (Supp. 2005).Â  Additionally, the court found termination was in the best interest of the child. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005).Â  After a thorough review of the record pursuant to Ex Parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354 S.E.2d 381 (1987), we affirm[1] the family courtâ€™s ruling and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: State v. Mayzes and Manley
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Appellant,
v.
Kimberly Salters Mayzes and Charles T. Manley, III,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-uP-416
Heard November 9, 2006 â€“ Filed December 18, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Appellant.
Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The State appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision to suppress evidence based on a violation of Kimberly Mayzesâ€™ Fourth Amendment rights.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
On October 25, 2002, while at Lizardâ€™s Thicket Restaurant, Kimberly Mayzes phoned the Springdale Police Department to report someone had stolen her pocketbook.Â  Officer Charles Flenniken responded and proceeded to interview Mayzes about the contents of the pocketbook.Â 
Rather than describing the normal contents of a pocketbook to Flenniken, such as a driverâ€™s license, credit cards, or a social security card, Mayzes informed Flenniken a prescription of Xanax was in the stolen pocketbook.Â  Flenniken noted Mayzes seemed anxious and more concerned about this prescription than the other contents.Â  
Flenniken questioned the manager and the waitress about the stolen pocketbook.Â  The waitress did not remember seeing Mayzes with the pocketbook in Lizardâ€™s Thicket.Â  At this point, Flenniken told Mayzes to sit in a car driven by Lori Young.[1]Â  Flenniken admitted, at this time, he did not have a reasonable basis to believe a crime had been committed.Â  Based on Mayzesâ€™ behavior, he merely believed â€œsomething didnâ€™t appear to be right . . . .â€
Afterward, Flenniken phoned Dr. Counts, whom Mayzes said wrote the Xanax prescription.Â  Dr. Counts explained Mayzes had called several times to obtain additional prescriptions of Xanax.Â  
Subsequently, Flenniken exited the restaurant and walked towards Youngâ€™s vehicle.Â  After obtaining Youngâ€™s consent to search the automobile, Flenniken explained to Mayzes it was in her interest to search the vehicle to ensure the pocketbook was not there.Â  Mayzes exited the vehicle and went directly to the trunk, without searching anywhere else, and found her pocketbook.Â  
Mayzes thanked Flenniken for his help and was about to leave, but Flenniken insisted she accompany him back into the restaurant.Â  Flenniken testified that when they walked back into the restaurant, Mayzes was not free to leave.Â  The State conceded when Flenniken and Mayzes returned inside Lizardâ€™s Thicket, Flenniken did not know if any criminal charges could be pressed against Mayzes.[2]Â Â Â  
Shortly thereafter, Flennikenâ€™s supervisor, Corporal Matt Johnson, arrived at the scene.Â  While Johnson and Flenniken were discussing the situation, Mayzes walked away from the officers and towards a restaurant employee who was using a pay telephone.Â  Flenniken observed the employee yell out and raise his arms in the air.Â  Flenniken and Johnson walked towards the telephone to discover the source of the employeeâ€™s reaction. 
As the officers approached, they saw a bag of marijuana and arrested Mayzes.Â  After reading Mayzes her Miranda[3] rights the officers questioned Mayzes.Â  She revealed that Young also had marijuana.Â  Mayzes, Johnson, and Flenniken walked outside, and Flenniken asked Young if she had any drugs in her possession.Â  Young admitted to having marijuana in her pocket.Â  Consequently, Flenniken placed Young under arrest and transported Young and Mayzes to Lexington County jail.Â  
After the police booked Mayzes, she was held in a temporary holding area where she made a phone call.Â  Flenniken, also in the booking area waiting for paper work, overheard Mayzes state: â€œPriscilla get Tommy to go to Lizardâ€™s Thicket on 302 to pick up a package.Â  He would know what it was when he got there.Â  He would know what it was when he saw it.Â  Hurry up and get there in the next half hour.Â  It was (sic) stuck on the floor between the paper machines.â€[4]Â  
Flenniken questioned her about this conversation, Mayzes replied the package was a gold necklace that was a birthday present for her son.Â  Flenniken did not believe Mayzes, so he requested Officer Bouknight to investigate the contents of the package.Â  Instead of finding a gold necklace in the package, Bouknight found a baseball-sized red and white substance, later determined to be crystal methamphetamine.Â  
Consequently, Mayzes was charged with possession with intent to distribute marijuana, possession with intent to distribute marijuana within proximity of a school, and trafficking methamphetamines.Â  Co-defendant Charles Manley was charged with trafficking methamphetamine.Â  The defense made a motion to the circuit court to suppress all evidence on the basis of a violation of the Fourth Amendment and the â€œfruit of the poisonous treeâ€ doctrine.Â  
The circuit court found: (1) Flenniken seized or detained Mayzes when he told her to sit in the car while he called Dr. Counts; (2) the seizure occurred even though no reasonable suspicion existed; and (3) as a result of the unlawful seizure Mayzesâ€™ Fourth Amendment rights were violated.Â  Additionally, the circuit court suppressed all the evidence procured subsequent to Flennikenâ€™s seizure of Mayzes, based upon the fruit of the poisonous tree doctrine.
The State contends the circuit court erred in suppressing the evidence because Mayzes was not seized within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment when Flenniken told her to sit in Youngâ€™s car.Â  In the alternative, the State asserts even if Mayzes was seized, a reasonable basis for the detention existed.Â Â  This appeal follows.[5]
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing a Fourth Amendment search and seizure case, we do not review the circuit judgeâ€™s ultimate determination de novo, rather we apply a deferential standard.Â 
State v. Khingratsaiphon, 352 S.C. 62, 70, 572 S.E.2d 456, 459-60 (2002).Â  This Court reviews the circuit judgeâ€™s ruling like any other factual finding, and we will reverse only if there is clear error.Â  Id.Â  Therefore, we will affirm if any evidence exists to support the circuit courtâ€™s ruling.Â  Id.; see, e.g., State v. Missouri, 361 S.C. 107, 111, 603 S.E. 2d 594, 596 (2004) (â€œWhen reviewing a Fourth Amendment search and seizure case, an appellate court must affirm the trial judgeâ€™s ruling if there is any evidence to support the ruling. The appellate court will reverse only when there is clear error.â€) (emphasis in original) (internal citation omitted); State v. Brockman, 339 S.C. 57, 66, 528 S.E.2d 661, 666 (2000) (explaining an appellate court reviews the circuit courtâ€™s Fourth Amendment ruling like any other factual finding and reverses if there is clear error but affirms if there is any evidence to support the circuit court).
LAW/ANALYSIS
A. Mayzesâ€™ seizure under the Fourth Amendment 
The Fourth Amendment provides â€œThe right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated . . . .â€Â  U.S. Const. amend. IV.Â  The right of an individual not to be arbitrarily seized by the government is one of our most important rights, and this right will be carefully guarded.Â  State v. Rodriquez, 323 S.C. 484, 490, 476 S.E.2d 161, 164-65 Â (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Any evidence seized in violation of the Fourth Amendment must be excluded.Â  Mapp v. Ohio, 367 U.S. 643, 655 (1961).
It is well established that warrantless searches and seizures by the police are per se unreasonable unless they fall within one of several recognized exceptions.Â  Katz v. United States, 389 U.S. 347, 357 (1967).Â  However, Fourth Amendment protection applies if there has been a search or seizure by the government.Â 
United States v. Jacobsen, 466 U.S. 109, 113-14 (1984).Â  Â Not all personal encounters with the police can be characterized as seizures.Â  Terry v. Ohio, 392 U.S. 1, 19-20 (1968).Â  
Whenever a police officer, by means of force or authority, has in some way restrained the liberty of a citizen, a â€œseizureâ€ has occurred.Â  Id.Â  In other words, a person has been seized within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment â€œwhenever a police officer accosts [the] individual and restrains his freedom to walk away . . . .â€ Â Â Id. at 16.Â  E.g., Sikes v. State, 323 S.C. 28, 30, 448 S.E.2d 560, 562 (1994) (â€œAn individual is â€˜seizedâ€™ when an officer restrains his freedom, even if the detention is brief and falls short of arrest.â€).Â  
In determining whether a seizure has occurred, the correct inquiry is whether, considering all the circumstances surrounding the encounter, a reasonable person would have believed she was not free to leave.Â 
United States v. Mendenhall, 446 U.S. 544, 553-54 (1980).Â  If the person approached and questioned is free to ignore the policeâ€™s questions and walk away, there has been no intrusion upon that personâ€™s liberty or privacy.Â  Id. Â Â Â Â Â  
The State argues a seizure did not arise until Mayzes recovered her pocketbook and Flenniken told Mayzes she was not free to leave.Â  Conversely, Mayzes argues a seizure occurred when she was told by Flenniken to sit in Youngâ€™s car while he called Dr. Counts.Â  We agree with
Mayzes.
At the time of the encounter with Mayzes, Flenniken was wearing a police uniform and had a badge; thus, Flenniken was acting with the authority of a police officer.Â  By means of this authority, Flenniken restrained and intruded on Mayzesâ€™ liberty because he told her to sit in Youngâ€™s car without having a reasonable belief a crime had been committed.Â  Flennikenâ€™s statement to Mayzes, telling her to go and wait in the car, was not a request, rather it was an order.Â  Flenniken did not hint or suggest that Mayzes should wait in the car.Â  Instead, he â€œtold her to sit in the car . . . .â€Â  (emphasis added).
A reasonable person would feel she was not free to leave when a police officer tells her â€œto sit in a car.â€Â  A reasonable person would feel if she disobeyed the policeâ€™s order to go where directed, she would get into more trouble.Â  Therefore, a reasonable person would not feel she was free to ignore Flenniken and simply walk away.Â  Mayzesâ€™ testimony confirms this conclusion.
Mayzes testified it was apparent to her that Flenniken was a police officer because he wore a police uniform and had a badge.Â  She further testified when Flenniken told her to sit and wait, she believed she was not free to leave.Â  Additionally, when asked what she thought would happen if she attempted to leave the scene, Mayzes responded Flenniken would pursue her.Â  
Based on the foregoing, we cannot say the circuit court committed clear error in determining a seizure occurred when Flenniken told Mayzes to go and wait in Youngâ€™s car.Â  
B. Mayzesâ€™ seizure was unreasonable 
Having determined to uphold the circuit courtâ€™s ruling that Mayzes was seized, we must decide whether her Fourth Amendment rights were thereby violated.Â  The United States Constitution does not prohibit all searches and seizures but only unreasonable searches and seizures.Â  Elkins v. United States, 364 U.S. 206, 222 (1960).Â  It is well known the police may stop and briefly detain and question a person, even if no probable cause exists.Â  Terry, 392 U.S. at 20.Â  However, there must be a reasonable suspicion supported by specific and articulable facts, and any rational inferences drawn therefrom, that the person is involved in criminal activity.Â  Id. at 21.Â  
Flennikenâ€™s testimony shows he had no reasonable suspicion to believe a crime had been committed; at most, he merely â€œhad a hunch.â€Â  The following is an excerpt from Flennikenâ€™s cross-examination by Mayzesâ€™ trial counsel:

  
    
      Q: 
       Iâ€™m going to repeat the question.Â  The question is at the point in time that you had a hunch that a red flag was raised, thatâ€™s the point in time that you told her
        [Mayzes] to go sit in the vehicle.
        
        
    
    
      A:
       Correct.
        
        
    
    
      Q:
       And at that point in time, itâ€™s nothing but a mere hunch.
        
        
    
    
      A:
       Correct.
        
        
    
    
      Q:
       Because you told the court that you had no reasonable basis at that time to believe that a crime was being committed.
        
        
    
    
      A:
       Correct.
        
        
    
    
      Q: 
       Nevertheless, you told her that she needed to go sit in the vehicle.
        
        
    
    
      A:
       Correct.
    
  

Intrusions upon constitutionally guaranteed rights must be based on more than inarticulable hunches.Â  Terry, 392 U.S. at 22.Â  Additionally, United States v. Burton, 228 F.3d 526 (4th Cir. 2002), supports the circuit courtâ€™s conclusion.Â  
On the afternoon of March 4, 1998, while at a payphone in Laurens, South Carolina, four police officers approached Kenneth Burton.Â 
United States v. Burton, 228 F.3d 524, 526 (4th Cir. 2000).Â  Officer Tracy Burke identified himself as a police officer and requested Burton provide him with identification.Â  Id.Â  Rather than complying with the request, Burton did not respond.Â  Id.Â  The officers repeated the request for identification several times, but Burton remained silent.Â  Id.Â  Thereafter, the officers asked Burton to remove his right hand from his coat pocket, but Burton failed to comply with the request.Â  Id.Â  The officers repeated their request, however Burton did not respond.Â  Id.
Office Burke positioned himself behind Burton and plunged his hand into Burtonâ€™s coat.Â  Id.Â  Burton opposed, and a struggle followed, during which the remaining three officers wrestled Burton to the ground.Â  Id.Â  Burton pointed a gun at Officer Burke and tried to fire, but the gun was jammed and did not fire.Â  Id.Â  Burton was indicted for violation of state[6] and federal[7] law.Â  Id.Â  
At the federal district court, Burton moved to suppress the firearm as fruit of an illegal search.Â  Id.Â  At the evidentiary hearing, Officer Burke testified that â€œat the time he approached Burton, he had no reason to suspect that Burton was engaged in criminal activity . . . .â€Â  Id.Â  The federal court denied Burtonâ€™s motion; subsequently, Burton was convicted and sentenced to 115 months imprisonment.Â  Id.Â  Burton appealed to the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals.Â  Id.
The Fourth Circuit reversed the district court and concluded Officer Burke did not have reasonable suspicion for the search; therefore, Officer Burkeâ€™s actions constituted an illegal search.Â  Id.Â  In reaching this conclusion, the Fourth Circuit recognized Officer Burkeâ€™s testimony confirmed he had no objective facts that would justify reasonable suspicion.Â  Id.Â  at 528. 
As mentioned above, in addition to the federal charges, Burton was indicted on state charges.Â  Burton, 356 S.C. at 263, 589 S.E.2d at 8.Â  Burton unsuccessfully made a motion to the circuit court to grant a directed verdict in his favor because the search was not supported by reasonable suspicion.Â  Id. at 265, 589 S.E.2d at 9.Â  On appeal, this Court reversed the circuit court, concluding the search was not supported by reasonable suspicion and was based on â€œan inchoate and unparticularized suspicion or hunch.â€Â  State v. Burton, 349 S.C. 430, 438, 562 S.E.2d 668, 672 (Ct. App. 2002) (internal quotations omitted) overruled on other grounds by State v. Burton, 356 S.C. 263, 589 S.E.2d 8 (2003).Â  
The South Carolina Supreme Court overruled this Court because the illegal search issue was not preserved.Â Â  Burton, 356 S.C. at 265, 589 S.E.2d at 9.Â  However, the Supreme Court agreed with this Court on the ruling regarding the illegality of search and seizure.Â  Id.Â  (â€œWe agree with the Court of Appeals that the search and seizure of Burton was illegal and we look with disapproval on the officersâ€™ conduct leading up to the seizure.â€)Â  
Just as in the Burton case, Flenniken testified he had no reasonable suspicion that criminal activity was afoot when he told Mayzes to sit in the car.Â  As such we hold some evidence exists to uphold the circuit courtâ€™s determination that Mayzesâ€™ Fourth Amendment rights were violated when Flenniken told Mayzes to wait in Youngâ€™s car.
C. Exclusion of evidence as a result of Mayzesâ€™ illegal seizure
In addition to holding Mayzesâ€™ Fourth Amendment rights were violated, the circuit court used the fruit of the poisonous tree doctrine to suppress all the evidence procured from Flennikenâ€™s seizure of
Mayzes.  
The fruit of the poisonous tree doctrine, most often associated with violations of the Fourth Amendmentâ€™s prohibition of unreasonable searches and seizures, prohibits the use of evidence obtained directly or indirectly through an unlawful search or seizure.Â  Wong Sun v. United States, 371 U.S. 471, 484 (1963).Â  
In this case, the circuit court concluded Mayzesâ€™ Fourth Amendment rights were violated when she was seized, and any evidence obtained from that unlawful seizure was excluded.Â  This evidence included: the bag of marijuana found at Lizardâ€™s Thicket; the statements made by Mayzes while she was in the holding area, which were overheard by officers Flenniken and Kelly; and the baseball-sized crystal methamphetamine.Â  
The circuit court did not commit clear error in using the fruit of the poisonous tree doctrine to exclude the evidence obtained as a result of Mayzesâ€™ unlawful seizure. 
CONCLUSION
Although this Court in no way condones Mayzesâ€™ possession of illegal substances, and we recognize the State makes a compelling argument, we must uphold the circuit courtâ€™s ruling because we are constrained by the Fourth Amendment and the applicable standard of review. Â Â 
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Apparently, Young and Mayzes came in the same car to Lizardâ€™s Thicket. 
[2] Flenniken gave contradictory testimony as to whether he thought a crime had or was being committed at this time.Â  For example, at one point he testified: â€œI did not know if I had a charge at that point to press charges against her for trying to obtain a controlled substance by fraud.â€Â  Conversely, he also stated: â€œAt that point, I believed that a crime had been committed and that she [Mayzes] had committed it.â€ 
[3] Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966). 
[4] In addition to Flenniken, Officer Kelly overheard Mayzesâ€™ conversation.Â  
[5] A pre-trial order granting the suppression of evidence, which significantly impairs the prosecution of a criminal case, is directly appealable.Â  State v. McKnight, 287 S.C. 167, 168, 337 S.E.2d 208, 209 (1985); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330(2)(a) (1976).Â  
[6] Burtonâ€™s state violations included two counts of assault while resisting arrest and two counts of assault with intent to kill.Â  State v. Burton, 356 S.C. 259, 263, 589 S.E.2d 6, 8 (2003).
[7] Burtonâ€™s federal violation was unlawful possession of a firearm by a felon.Â  18 U.S.C. Â§ 922(g) (West 2006).Â

title: Mitchell v. Florence County School District #1
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Delphine Mitchell, Appellant,
v.
Florence County School District #1, Employer, and South Carolina School Board Insurance Trust, Carrier,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Florence County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-417
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 18, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Stephen J. Wukela, of Florence, for Appellant.
Kay G. Crowe and Adrianne L. Turner, both of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Delphine Mitchell (Claimant) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the denial of workerâ€™s compensation benefits.Â  Claimant argues the circuit courtâ€™s decision was erroneous and should be reversed because: Â (1) the First Appellate Panel failed to comply with section 1-23-350 of the South Carolina Code (2005); (2) the First Appellate Panel erred in finding she did not suffer an occupational disease; (3) the Second Appellate Panel lacked jurisdiction to find chemicals at her work did not cause her asthma; and (4) the Second Appellate Panel erred in finding chemicals at work did not cause her asthma.[1] Â We affirm.[2]
FACTS
On August 1, 1999, Claimant began working as a custodian for Florence County School District #1 (Employer).Â  As part of her duties, she worked with various cleaning chemicals.Â  On March 25, 2001, Claimant admitted herself into Carolinas Hospital System because she had problems breathing.Â  Dr. Robert Richey, a physician specializing in internal medicine, diagnosed Claimant with asthma. Â Dr. Richey also consulted Dr. Mark Bernard, a pulmonologist.Â  Dr. Bernard concurred with Dr. Richeyâ€™s diagnosis of asthma.Â Â Â  
Claimant applied for temporary total disability benefits, arguing the cleaning chemicals caused her asthma.Â  Employer and the South Carolina School Board Insurance Trust (Carrier) contested coverage.Â  Commissioner Sherry Shealy Martschink heard the case, made detailed findings of fact, and determined the asthma was an occupational disease.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-11-10 (1985) (defining occupational disease). Â The First Appellate Panel reversed, simply stating â€œ[b]ased on the evidence in the record and the medical evidence, Claimant has failed to prove an occupational disease.â€Â  The First Appellate Panel remanded the case â€œto the jurisdictional commissioner for a hearing on the merits of whether this is an injury by accident.â€Â  Claimant appealed to the circuit court.Â  The Honorable James E. Brogdon, Jr., held the First Appellate Panelâ€™s order was not immediately appealable and remanded the case to the commissioner.
On remand, Commissioner J. Michelle Childs took evidence and held the asthma was an injury by accident.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2005) (defining injury by accident).Â  The Second Appellate Panel reversed, holding â€œ[t]here is no evidence in the record that the Claimantâ€™s asthmas [sic] was caused by the inhalation of any chemicals at work.Â  There is no evidence that Claimantâ€™s asthma arose out of the course and scope of her employment.â€Â  Claimant appealed the First Appellate Panelâ€™s and Second Appellate Panelâ€™s orders to the circuit court.Â  The Honorable B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., affirmed both appellate panels, and this appeal followed.Â  
DISCUSSION
I.
Claimant contends the circuit court erred in affirming the denial of workerâ€™s compensation benefits because the First Appellate Panel failed to comply with section 1-23-350 of the South Carolina Code (2005). Â Although we agree with Claimantâ€™s contention, we find any error to be harmless.Â  
The relevant part of section 1-23-350 provides:

A final decision or order adverse to a party in a contested case shall be in writing or stated in the record. Â A final decision shall include findings of fact and conclusions of law, separately stated. Â Findings of fact, if set forth in statutory language, shall be accompanied by a concise and explicit statement of the underlying facts supporting the findings.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-350 (2005).
Judge Harwell held section 1-23-350 did not apply to the First Appellate Panelâ€™s order because that order was not final.Â  Alternatively, Judge Harwell held Judge Brogdon ruled the order was not final, and this ruling is the law of the case.
We do not believe Judge Brogdonâ€™s ruling is dispositive of this issue.Â  Judge Brogdon clearly contemplated the First Appellate Panelâ€™s order would become final, and thus appealable, after remand.Â  He held â€œthe finding of this Court [is] that the Order of the [First Appellate Panel] is not appealable at this time to the Circuit Court.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  He further noted â€œthe remand for a hearing on the issue of injury by accident must occur before there is a final decision on the meritsâ€ and â€œ[t]his Order in no way prejudices the Claimantâ€™s right to appeal to this Court on both the issue of whether the Claimant has sustained an occupational disease . . . .â€Â  Under these circumstances, the First Appellate Panelâ€™s order became a final order subject to section 1-23-350 after the Second Appellate Panel issued its order.Â  Therefore, we address the merits of this issue.Â  
In analyzing this issue, we are guided by our supreme courtâ€™s decision in Fox v. Newberry County Memâ€™l Hosp., 319 S.C. 278, 279, 461 S.E.2d 392, 393 (1995).Â  In that case, Fox sought workerâ€™s compensation benefits from her employer, claiming she contracted herpetic whitlow.Â  On appeal to the circuit court, the employer and insurance carrier argued the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (the Commission) erred in failing to make specific findings of fact with respect to each of the elements comprising an occupational disease.Â 
Id. at 280, 461 S.E.2d at 393.Â  Our supreme court agreed, remanding the case to the Commission for an order addressing each of these elements.Â  Id. at 282, 461 S.E.2d at 395.
Turning to the instant case, the First Appellate Panel summarily held Claimant failed to prove an occupational disease.Â  Even though it cited Fox and listed the six elements of an occupational disease, it did not make findings of fact sufficient to allow this court to determine which of the elements the First Appellate Panel relied upon in reversing Commissioner Martschinkâ€™s decision.Â  
Despite the First Appellate Panelâ€™s failure to strictly comply with the mandate of Fox, we find, as will be evident from later discussion, that this error did not affect our final analysis and provides no basis for reversal.Â  Accordingly, we find the alleged error to be harmless.
II.
A. 
Clamant argues the circuit court erred in affirming the order of the Second Appellate Panel because the Second Appellate Panel lacked jurisdiction to determine whether the cleaning chemicals caused Claimantâ€™s asthma.Â  Claimant interprets the First Appellate Panelâ€™s order as a limitation on the jurisdiction of Commissioner Childs and, consequentially, the Second Appellate Panel.Â  Specifically, Claimant maintains the First Appellate Panelâ€™s order adopted the findings of fact of Commissioner Martschink and reversed only her finding Claimantâ€™s asthma was an occupational disease.Â  We disagree.Â  
In construing an order, the determinative factor is the intent of the judge who wrote it, as gathered not from an isolated part of the order, but from all parts thereof.Â  Whiteâ€™s Mill Colony, Inc. v. Williams, 363 S.C. 117, 124 n.1, 609 S.E.2d 811, 815 n.1 (Ct. App. 2005); Oâ€™Banner v. Westinghouse Elec. Corp., 319 S.C. 24, 29, 459 S.E.2d 324, 327 (Ct. App. 1995).
Here, the First Appellate Panel clearly reversed Commissioner Martschinkâ€™s decision and substituted its own findings of fact and conclusions of law.Â  This order cannot be read to adopt any of Commissioner Martschinkâ€™s findings.Â  While Claimant relies on 25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-707 (Supp. 2005), for the proposition Commissioner Childs could only make legal conclusions on remand, we note this regulation only applies when the appellate panel requires additional evidence to complete its review or a party requests newly-discovered evidence be admitted.[3]Â  We hold the First Appellate Panelâ€™s order did not limit Commissioner Childsâ€™ ability to make findings of fact in ruling on whether Claimantâ€™s asthma was an injury by accident.Â  A fortiori, the Second Appellate Panel also had jurisdiction to rule on this issue.
B.
Claimant argues that, even if the Second Appellate Panel had jurisdiction, the circuit court erred in affirming the Second Appellate Panelâ€™s decision that the cleaning chemicals did not cause Claimantâ€™s asthma.Â  We disagree.
Section 1-23-380(A)(6) of the South Carolina Code (2005)[4] governs our review of workersâ€™ compensation decisions.Â  Baxter v. Martin Bros., Inc., 368 S.C. 510, 513, 630 S.E.2d 42, 43 (2006).Â  This courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the appellate panelâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  Gadson v. Mikasa Corp., 368 S.C. 214, 221, 628 S.E.2d 262, 266 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Accordingly, a reviewing court may not substitute its judgment for that of the appellate panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  Clark v. Aiken County Govâ€™t, 366 S.C. 102, 107, 620 S.E.2d 99, 101 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  We further note the final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the appellate panel.Â  Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 160, 519 S.E.2d 102, 105 (1999). 
In order to receive workersâ€™ compensation benefits, Claimant must prove that she sustained an â€œinjury by accident arising out of and in the course of the employment.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2005).Â  â€œThe term â€˜arose out ofâ€™ refers to the origin of the cause of the accident, while the term â€˜in the course ofâ€™ refers to the time, place, and circumstances under which the accident occurred.â€ Â Howell v. Pac. Columbia Mills, 291 S.C. 469, 471, 354 S.E.2d 384, 385 (1987).
â€œWhether there is any causal connection between employment and an injury is a question of fact for the Commission.â€Â  Sharpe, 336 S.C. at 159, 519 S.E.2d at 105.Â  â€œBecause causation is a question of fact, the full commissionâ€™s decision on the issue must be affirmed if it is supported by substantial evidence in the record.â€ Shuler v. Gregory Elec., 366 S.C. 435, 440, 622 S.E.2d 569, 571 (Ct. App. 2005).
Therefore, we must affirm the Second Appellate Panelâ€™s ruling unless it is clearly erroneous in view of the substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Nettles v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. #7, 341 S.C. 580, 586, 535 S.E.2d 146, 149 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is â€˜not a mere scintilla of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached or must have reached in order to justify its action.â€™â€Â  Miller by Miller v. State Roofing Co., 312 S.C. 452, 454, 441 S.E.2d 323, 324-25 (1994) (quoting Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981)).Â  â€œThe substantial evidence rule does not allow judicial fact-finding, or the substitution of judicial judgment for agency judgment.Â  A judgment upon which reasonable men might differ will not be set aside.â€Â  Toddâ€™s Ice Cream, Inc. v. South Carolina Employment Sec. Commâ€™n, 281 S.C. 254, 258, 315 S.E.2d 373, 375 (Ct. App. 1984).
Dr. Richey and Dr. Bernard saw Claimant several times from March 2001 to November 2001.Â  During this time, Claimant alternatively blamed steam from a dishwasher at her second job, dust from moving books at her custodial job, rain, and the cleaning chemicals for her asthma. Â In addition, medical charts predating her custodial job indicate she experienced â€œbronchospasmsâ€ before working for Employer.Â  Furthermore, Dr. Richey testified he believed the asthma â€œmore than likelyâ€ came from a virus and could have been triggered by cigarettes.Â  Claimant admitted to smoking.Â  
Both Dr. Richey and Dr. Bernard recommended Claimant not return to work because of the chemicals.Â  However, both later testified they made this recommendation out of an abundance of caution and not because they thought the chemicals caused or aggravated the asthma. Â Moreover, the two doctors agreed almost anything could have caused the asthma. Â Additionally, both testified the only way to tell the chemicals caused the asthma would be a pre-exposure and post-exposure test, which Claimant avoided taking.Â  Dr. Bernard testified he found no evidence the chemicals caused Claimantâ€™s asthma.Â  However, Employer asked Claimant to see Dr. Steven Sahn, who testified the chemicals caused or worsened Claimantâ€™s asthma.Â  
Although a contrary inference can be made, substantial evidence supports the Second Appellate Panelâ€™s conclusion the cleaning chemicals did not cause Claimantâ€™s asthma.Â  See Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr. of Sumter, 334 S.C. 333, 338, 513 S.E.2d 843, 845 (1999) (â€œWhere there is a conflict in the evidence, either by different witnesses or in the testimony of the same witness, the findings of fact of the Commission are conclusive.â€).Â  Moreover, this conclusion prevents Claimantâ€™s recovery of temporary total disability benefits under either a theory of injury by accident or occupational disease.[5]Â  See Grady L. Beard et al., The Law of Workersâ€™ Compensation Insurance in South Carolina 7-4 (4th ed. 2005) (â€œLike the injuries by accident, occupational diseases must â€˜arise out ofâ€™ and arise â€˜in the course ofâ€™ claimantsâ€™ employment.Â  These phrases carry the same significance for occupational diseases as they do when they refer to injuries by accident.â€).Â  Therefore, we hold Claimant cannot recover on her theory of injury by accident or occupational disease.Â  See Rule 220(c), SCACR (â€œThe appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, or judgment upon any ground appearing in the Record on Appeal.â€); Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 418, 526 S.E.2d 716, 722 (2000) (noting the appellate court may affirm the trial court based on any ground found in the record).Â  
CONCLUSION
Although the First Appellate Panelâ€™s order did not strictly comply with the requirements of section 1-23-350 of the South Carolina Code, we find any error to be harmless.Â  We hold the Second Appellate Panel had jurisdiction to determine cleaning chemicals did not cause Claimantâ€™s asthma.Â  In addition, we find substantial evidence supports this finding.Â  Moreover, this finding prevents Claimant from recovering under theories of injury by accident or occupational disease.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order is 
 AFFIRMED.
 ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  As will be evident from the discussion of these issues, we have addressed them in a different order in the interest of clarity and brevity.
[2] Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3]Â  The regulation relied on by Claimant provides:

A. When additional evidence is necessary for the completion of the record in a case on review the Commission may, in its discretion, order such evidence taken before a Commissioner.
    
B. When a party seeks to introduce new evidence into the record on a case on review, the party shall file a motion and affidavit with the Commissionâ€™s
Judicial Department.
    
C. The moving party must establish the new evidence is of the same nature and character required for granting a new trial and show:
(1) The evidence sought to be introduced is not evidence of a cumulative or impeaching character but would likely have produced a different result had the evidence been procurable at the first hearing; and
 (2) The evidence was not known to the moving party at the time of the first hearing, by reasonable diligence the new evidence could not have been secured, and the discovery of the new evidence is being brought to the attention of the Commission immediately upon its discovery.
  
 (a) File the motion and affidavit with proof of service as soon as the new evidence is discovered. The motion and affidavit may be filed with the Form 30.
(b) Serve the opposing party pursuant to R.67-215.
 (c) Oral argument will not be heard on the motion. The Commission will act upon the motion and issue an order
before the review hearing is held.
 (d) If the Commission grants the motion, the review hearing is stayed. The case will be remanded to the original Hearing Commissioner who may, unless otherwise provided, reconvene the hearing or admit the deposition of a witness into the record.
 (e) The original Hearing Commissioner will issue his or her findings and recommendations in the form of an order to the Commission and the parties.
 (f) Upon the receipt of the Commissionerâ€™s order, the Judicial Department will reset the case on the review hearing docket.
 (g) If the Commission denies the motion, the case may remain on the review hearing docket unless otherwise provided.
  

25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-707 (Supp. 2005).
[4] Section 2 of Act No. 387, 2006 S.C. Acts 387 (the Act) amends section 1-23-380(A).Â  This amendment became effective on July 1, 2006.Â  However, this amendment does not substantively change our standard of review.
[5] Section 42-11-10 of the South Carolina Code defines occupational disease as follows:

The words â€œoccupational diseaseâ€ mean a disease arising out of and in the course of employment which is due to hazards in excess of those ordinarily incident to employment and is peculiar to the occupation in which the employee is engaged. A disease shall be deemed an occupational disease only if caused by a hazard recognized as peculiar to a particular trade, process, occupation or employment as a direct result of continuous exposure to the normal working conditions thereof.
    
  No disease shall be deemed an occupational disease when:
(1) It does not result directly and naturally from exposure in this State to the hazards peculiar to the particular employment;
(2) It results from exposure to outside climatic conditions;
(3) It is a contagious disease resulting from exposure to fellow employees or from a hazard to which the workman would have been equally exposed outside of his employment;
(4) It is one of the ordinary diseases of life to which the general public is equally exposed, unless such disease follows as a complication and a natural incident of an occupational disease or unless there is a constant exposure peculiar to the occupation itself which makes such disease a hazard inherent in such occupation;
(5) It is any disease of the cardiac, pulmonary or circulatory system not resulting directly from abnormal external gaseous pressure exerted upon the body or the natural entrance into the body through the skin or natural orifices thereof of foreign organic or inorganic matter under circumstances peculiar to the employment and the processes utilized therein; or
(6) It is any chronic disease of the skeletal joints.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-11-10 (1985).
In order to receive workerâ€™s compensation benefits for having contracted an occupational disease, Claimant must have proven the following six elements:Â  

1. A disease;

    2. The disease must arise out of and in the course of the claimantâ€™s employment;
    
  3. The disease must be due to hazards in excess of those hazards that are ordinarily incident to employment;
  
  4. The disease must be peculiar to the occupation in which the claimant was engaged;
  
  5. The hazard causing the disease must be one recognized as peculiar to a particular trade, process, occupation, or employment; and
  
  6. The disease must directly result from the claimantâ€™s continuous exposure to the normal working conditions of the particular trade, process, occupation, or employment.

Fox v. Newberry County Memâ€™l Hosp., 319 S.C. 278, 281, 461 S.E.2d 392, 394 (1995).

title: State v. Singletary
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State Respondent,
v.
Willie Singletary Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lee County
Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-418
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 18, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellant Defender Aileen P. Clare, South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, and Solicitor C. Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  A Lee County jury convicted Willie Singletary (Singletary) of criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the first degree.Â  Singletary appeals his conviction, claiming the trial court committed reversible error when it improperly admitted his custodial statement.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Singletary committed sexual misconduct against the victim, S.S., at some point on December 6th or 7th, 2003.[1] Â At the time of the assault, the nine-year-old victim lived with her mother and three siblings in Singletaryâ€™s mobile home.Â  Â Â 
S.S. testified that on December 7, 2003, she was in the kitchen of Singletaryâ€™s mobile home when he grabbed her and pulled her into his bedroom.Â  Once inside Singletaryâ€™s bedroom, S.S. testified that he shut the door and pulled down both of their pants.Â  With his hands over her mouth, he raped her digitally, anally, and vaginally.Â  Conversely, in Singletaryâ€™s confession, he claimed the incident occurred at the instigation of the victim outside of his mobile home on December 6, 2003.
On December 8, 2003, S.S.â€™s school teacher noticed that S.S. was frequently visiting the restroom, so she took S.S. to the school nurse.Â  Â School officials contacted DSS, and further medical examination revealed that S.S. had recently contracted Chlamydia, a sexually-transmitted disease. Â In addition, the examination showed S.S. experienced external injury as well as recent penetration to her anus but no conclusive penetration to her vagina. 
Based on the victimâ€™s report of the incident, the police contacted Singletary, and he voluntarily came to the police station.Â  Once inside the police station, the investigating police officer testified that he read Singletary his Miranda[2] rights and explained those rights to him in lay terms. Â According to the officer, Singletary never requested further explanation regarding any of his rights, but he signed the portion of the form acknowledging that he understood his rights. Â The officer testified that after he read Singletary his rights, he proceeded to read a waiver of rights form, which Singletary also signed.Â  
Singletary, however, testified that the police never read him his Miranda rights. Â Singletary also stated that the acknowledgement and waiver of rights form was never read or presented to him, and he signed it without knowledge of the formâ€™s contents.Â  
Furthermore, Singletary denied that the police ever showed him his custodial statement or read it to him, but he admitted to signing the custodial statement and to initialing it four times in the corners of the document. Â He also claimed he told the police he did not sexually assault S.S., and only the part about S.S. rubbing his back outside his mobile home was accurate. Â The custodial statement reads:

On Saturday December 6, 2003[,] I Willie was outside working on my car[,] a 1995 Chevy Silver in color.Â  [S.S.] came outside where I was.Â  I was on my knees unlocking my hood because itâ€™s chained down.Â  While I was on my knees, [S.S.] jump [sic] on my back and started working up on me.Â  [S.S.] also started touching my penis.Â  [S.S.] grab [sic] my hand and put it on her vagina.Â  I started touching her back.Â  She got my penis hard.Â  She also put my hands through the leg part of her pants.Â  She try [sic] to put my hands inside her vagina.Â  

When asked why he would sign a confession without reading it or having it read to him, Singletary stated he â€œdidnâ€™t really read itâ€; rather, he â€œread across [it]â€ but â€œdidnâ€™t read it word for word.â€Â  When further questioned as to whether he would be concerned about what he signed, given that he did not read its contents, Singletary said he was not worried until afterwards when the police told him that he was under arrest. 
Conversely, the investigating police officers testified that they read Singletaryâ€™s confession back to him.Â  Moreover, they stated Singletary was allowed to read the statement, and he was in no way prohibited from altering or changing it if he wanted.Â  
Based on this evidence, the jury found Singletary guilty of first degree criminal sexual misconduct with a minor, and the trial court sentenced him to ten years in prison.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Singletary argues the trial court erred when it admitted his custodial statement because it was involuntary and irrelevant.Â  We disagree.
I.  Voluntariness of the Custodial Statement 
Singletary first claims that his custodial statement is inadmissible because it was not freely and voluntarily given.Â  We disagree.
A statement obtained as a result of custodial interrogation is inadmissible unless the person was advised of and voluntarily waived his rights under Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966). Â See also Dickerson v. U.S., 530 U.S. 428 (2000).Â  The purpose of Miranda rights is to prevent government officials from using the coercive nature of confinement to extract confessions that would not be given in an unrestrained environment.Â 
Arizona v. Mauro, 481 U.S. 520, 529-30 (1987).Â  Therefore, the State must prove by a preponderance of the evidence that a statement is voluntary.Â  Lego v. Twomey, 404 U.S. 477, 486 (1972); State v. Neeley, 271 S.C. 33, 40, 244 S.E.2d 522, 526 (1978).Â  
The trial courtâ€™s determination of the voluntariness of a statement must be based on the totality of the circumstances and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion by the trial court.Â  Â State v. Rochester, 301 S.C. 196, 200, 391 S.E.2d 244, 247 (1990).Â  When reviewing a trial courtâ€™s ruling concerning voluntariness, this Court does not reevaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence, but we simply determine whether the trial courtâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence. Â State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 136, 551 S.E.2d 240, 252 (2001).
The trial court found that Singletaryâ€™s custodial statement was freely and voluntarily given, that the police afforded Singletary the proper procedural safeguards, and that Singletary knowingly and intelligently waived his rights.Â  Singletary signed both the waiver of rights form and his confession.Â  Two investigating officers, who were present during this time, corroborated that Singletary signed both forms.Â  Further, they testified that Singletary was afforded all the procedural safeguards required by law, and at no time did they prohibit Singletary from altering or changing his confession.Â  
Although Singletary testified in court that the police did not read his Miranda rights to him and that he did not knowingly and intelligently waive his rights, there is ample evidence to the contrary.Â  Â As such, we find the trial court did not err in admitting Singletaryâ€™s 
statement.Â  
II.  Relevance of Custodial Statement 
Singletary also contends that the trial court committed reversible error when it admitted his custodial statement because it was irrelevant to the crime charged.Â  We disagree.
The trial court is given broad discretion in ruling on questions concerning the relevancy of evidence, and this decision will be reversed only if there is a clear abuse of discretion. Â State v. Alexander, 303 S.C. 377, 380, 401 S.E.2d 146, 148 (1991).Â  Evidence is relevant if it tends to establish or make more or less probable some matter which is in issue upon which it directly or indirectly bears.Â  State v. Schmidt, 288 S.C. 301, 303, 342 S.E.2d 401, 403 (1986).Â  A trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding the comparative probative value and prejudicial effect of evidence should be reversed only in â€œexceptional circumstances.â€ Â State v. Sweat, 362 S.C. 117, 129, 606 S.E.2d 508, 514 (Ct. App. 2004).Â Â Â  
Singletary attempts to argue that the introduction of his custodial statement is prior bad act evidence as it â€œpertained to an uncharged act, and not the act described by the victim.â€ Â While prior bad act evidence is generally inadmissible because its probative value is outweighed by its prejudicial impact, this statement does not fall within the ambit of a prior bad act. Â See State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 416, 118 S.E. 803, 807 (1923); Rule 404(b), SCRE (Evidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts is not admissible to prove the character of a person in order to show action in conformity therewith. It may, however, be admissible to show motive, identity, the existence of a common scheme or plan, the absence of mistake or accident, or intent.).Â  
Singletaryâ€™s statement is sufficiently related to the charged sexual misconduct to fall within the realm of evidence that is both relevant and probative to the juryâ€™s determination of his culpability.Â  The State misspoke when, as one of several reasons for the custodial statementâ€™s relevance, it said the statement showed his â€œpropensity to engageâ€ in sexual misconduct. Â The State did not offer and the trial court did not use the statement to establish Singletaryâ€™s proclivity to commit this type of crime.Â  Rather, the statement was offered as substantive evidence of Singletaryâ€™s version of the incident.Â  While it differed from the victimâ€™s version, his custodial statement was sufficiently related to the crime charged to support the inference that Singletary committed a crime against the victim some time during the weekend of December 6th and 7th, as stated in the indictment.Â  See State v. Tufts, 355 S.C. 493, 498-99, 585 S.E.2d 523, 526 (Ct. App. 2003) (holding defendantâ€™s statement regarding his sexual desires, although not a direct acknowledgement of guilt, was properly admissible as a confession to the charge of criminal sexual conduct as defendant chose to convey his confession in that manner rather than a more traditional confession such as nodding affirmatively or recounting the entire crime).Â  
Moreover, evidence is relevant if it tends to establish or make more or less probable some matter in issue upon which it directly or indirectly bears.Â  State v. Benjamin, 345 S.C. 470, 480, 549 S.E.2d 258, 264 n.8 (2001) (internal citation omitted). Â It is not required that the inference sought should necessarily follow from the fact proved. Â Id.Â  
The admission of the custodial statement was proper because it tended to make Singletaryâ€™s testimony at trial less plausible.Â  At trial, Singletary denied the sexual assault and contradicted the officersâ€™ testimony and his previous written confession.Â  As such, introduction of the custodial statement into evidence was proper for the jury to consider in determining Singletaryâ€™s veracity and ultimately his guilt.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we hold the trial court did not abuse its discretion in admitting Singletaryâ€™s custodial statement.
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.[3]Â 
Anderson, Huff, and Williams, J.J., concur. 

[1] As stated below, Singletaryâ€™s confession and the victimâ€™s testimony conflict regarding the day and location of the sexual misconduct, which is reflected in Singletaryâ€™s indictment (charging Singletary with sexual misconduct â€œon or between December 6, 2003[] and December 7, 2003â€).Â  
[2] Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966).
[3] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Timothy E. Finley, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-419
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Orin Gail Briggs, of Lexington, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â By this appeal Timothy E. Finley challenges his convictions for unlawful use of a telephone and impersonating a police officer, offenses created by S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 16-17-430, -720 (2003), respectively.Â  He does not challenge his conviction for criminal contempt.Â  The jury failed to convict Finley of unlawful use of a 911 emergency telephone system, an offense created by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-47-80 (Supp. 2005).Â  We affirm.[1]
Finley, a registered, licensed security guard, worked at a bowling alley in Greenville, South Carolina.Â  The series of events that led to his arrest and convictions began when his girlfriend, Maureen Charping, came to visit him at his house.Â  Because he appeared drunk and verbally abused her, Charping left and went to her parentsâ€™ home.Â  While there, Finley telephoned Charping and told her that he could hunt her down and, because of his weapons training, could kill her.Â  Finley also spoke to Charpingâ€™s father, mentioning a sniper rifle and being able to pick a person off from 250 yards.Â  The Charpings telephoned the police, who advised them to leave the house.Â  They did so and, after giving the police a statement, secured a room at a motel.
Finley twice telephoned 911 operators from his residence, seeking privileged information about a possible 911 call concerning the report of a crime.Â  He claimed to be a police officer with the City of Greenville.Â  Civilians may not access information about calls made to 911 because they are deemed confidential.Â  At trial, Charping identified a voice captured on a 911 tape as Finleyâ€™s.
1.Â  The denial by the trial court of Finleyâ€™s motion for a directed verdict provides no basis for a reversal of Finleyâ€™s conviction and sentence.Â  The only arguments Finley made at trial in support of his motion as it related to the charges of unlawful use of a telephone and to impersonating a police officer were that the State failed to prove identity and that Charping signed an affidavit agreeing not to prosecute Finley.Â  Here, Finley does not advance either ground as a basis on which to overturn the trial courtâ€™s ruling on his motion for a directed verdict, although he does summarily note in his brief, when arguing the State failed to prove the elements of the offense of impersonating a police officer, an argument not preserved for our review, that Charping signed an affidavit in which she stated she did not want â€œto go forward with the prosecution.â€Â  See State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989) (noting a party cannot argue one ground for directed verdict at trial and argue another ground on appeal); State v. Russell, 345 S.C. 128, 132, 546 S.E.2d 202, 204 (Ct. App. 2001) (remarking that issues not raised to the trial judge in support of a motion for directed verdict afford no basis for appellate review); cf. State v. Jones, 344 S.C. 48, 58, 543 S.E.2d 541, 546 (2001) (finding the defendantâ€™s â€œargument is so conclusory that it has been abandonedâ€ and declining to address the merits of the issue for that reason).
2.Â Â The trial court committed no abuse of discretion in having Finley removed from the courtroom for disruptive, insolent behavior, behavior that also formed the basis for his unappealed contempt conviction.Â  The trial court found Finley delayed the start of court by failing to cooperate with detention officers regarding his changing from his jail uniform into street clothes, intentionally dropped his pants in the courtroom, continued to speak to and shout down the trial court when the trial court tried to address him, kept interrupting the trial court as the trial court attempted to warn Finley that he would be ejected from the courtroom if he continued his interruptions, and resisted the officers when the trial court ordered Finley removed from the courtroom.Â  (The trial court further found Finley engaged in such loud and disruptive behavior after officers placed him in a courthouse holding cell that it necessitated his removal to another building.)Â  See State v. Logan, 279 S.C. 345, 348, 306 S.E.2d 622, 624 (1983) (holding an appellant cannot take advantage of an error he contributed to at trial); State v. Bell, 293 S.C. 391, 401, 360 S.E.2d 706, 711 (1987) (holding a defendant can waive his right to be present in the courtroom where the defendant engaged in disruptive conduct or interfered with the progress of the trial); see also North Carolina v. Rowe, 235 S.E.2d 873, 875 (N.C. Ct. App. 1977) (â€œOrdinarily the trial judge should give a defendant an opportunity to correct his conduct before removal from the courtroom.Â  Obviously, however, that can only be done if the defendant gives the trial judge a reasonable opportunity. . . . The trial judge is not . . . required to engage in a shouting contest in order to warn a defendant that he will be removed from the courtroom if he does not desist [being disruptive].â€).
3.Â The trial court did not abuse its discretion by not allowing Finley to waive his right to counsel and to assert his right to represent himself.Â  Once Finleyâ€™s unruly conduct prompted the trial court to remove Finley from the courtroom, he forfeited his right to a hearing pursuant to Faretta v. California, 422 U.S. 806 (1975) and waived his right to represent himself.Â  See State v. Cash, 309 S.C. 40, 43, 419 S.E.2d 811, 813 (Ct. App. 1992) (holding one factor a court may consider in determining whether to allow the accused to engage in self-representation is whether the accused is attempting to delay or manipulate the proceedings); Lopez v. Delaware, 861 A.2d 1245, 1250 (Del. 2004) (finding no error in refusing the defendantâ€™s request to represent himself where he became disruptive and refused to follow the procedures for waiving his right to counsel); Connecticut v. Rose, 809 A.2d 534, 539 (Conn. App. Ct. 2002) (â€œ[I]t was the defendant himself, through his disruptive behavior, who forfeited his right to self-representation.â€).
4.Â Â We need not address Finleyâ€™s complaint concerning the trial courtâ€™s charge to the jury on the elements of impersonating a law enforcement officer.Â  Finley argues â€œthe second element of the crime was not . . . properly charged by the court.â€Â  As we read section 16-17-720, the second element of the offense consists of a person â€œacting uponâ€ a â€œrepresentationâ€ that he or she is a law-enforcement officer by â€œarrest[ing] or detain[ing] any person, search[ing] any building or automobile or in any way impersonat[ing] a law-enforcement officer or act[ing] in accordance with the authority commonly given to such officers.â€Â  This issue is not preserved for appellate review, there being no objection by Finleyâ€™s counsel to the charge on this ground.Â  See Rule 20(b), SCRCrimP (â€œ[T]he parties shall be given the opportunity to object to the giving or failure to give an instruction. . . . Failure to object in accordance with this rule shall constitute a waiver of objection.â€).[2]
5.Â Â We likewise find no error in the trial courtâ€™s denial of Finleyâ€™s motion to quash the indictment that accused Finley of impersonation of a law-enforcement officer in violation of section 16-17-720.Â  The indictment at issue here provided adequate notice to Finley of the offense that he was charged with because it expressly references the statute that created the offense and uses substantially the same language found in the statute.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-20 (2003); State v. Reddick, 348 S.C. 631, 560 S.E.2d 441 (Ct. App. 2002); see also State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 649, 552 S.E.2d 745, 751 (2001) (holding an indictment will be deemed sufficient when it includes a statutory reference that gives notice of the elements of the offense), overruled on other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005).
6.Â Â We do not address the issue raised by Finley regarding the trial courtâ€™s charge on reasonable doubt.Â  The issue is not preserved for our review, there being no objection by Finley to the charge below.Â  See Rule 20(b), SCRCrimP (stating the failure to make an objection constitutes a waiver).
7.Â Â We also do not address Finleyâ€™s complaint regarding the striking by the State of three male jurors during jury selection.Â  This issue, too, is not preserved.Â  See State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 120-21, 481 S.E.2d 118, 123 (1997) (â€œAn issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
8.Â Â Finleyâ€™s claim that his counsel provided him ineffective assistance cannot be reviewed at this time and must await an application for post-conviction relief.Â  See State v. Felder, 290 S.C. 521, 351 S.E.2d 852 (1986).
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â Moreover, we note the trial court employed the language of the statute, section 16-17-720, when instructing the jury regarding the offense.Â  A charge that employs the language of the statute suffices.Â  Keel v. Seaboard Air Line Ry., 108 S.C. 390, 393, 95 S.E. 64, 65 (1918); 75B Am. Jur. 2d Trial Â§ 1246 (1992); see City of Columbia v. Dovan Enters., 280 S.C. 134, 137, 311 S.E.2d 920, 921 (1983) (holding the trial judge committed no error in charging the jury the entire statute and ordinance under which the defendant was charged without defining the operative terms of the statute and ordinance, including the terms â€œassignationâ€ and â€œprosecutionâ€); see also Caro v. Texas, 771 S.W.2d 610, 614 (Tex. App. 1989) (â€œWhen the courtâ€™s charge tracks the language of the applicable statutes, there is no error.â€).
