THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Brendalee Ables, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Michael Gladden, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Darlington County
Â Roger E. Henderson, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-420
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Holly Palmer Beeson, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Newton I. Howle, Jr., of Darlington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action for reimbursement of child-related expenses, Brendalee Ables (Wife) appeals the family courtâ€™s order denying her claims for the reimbursement of medical expenses, health insurance premiums, work-related child care expenses, educational expenses, and retroactive child support.Â  Further, Wife claims the family court miscalculated its award of $300 to Wife based on improper credits previously given to Michael Gladden (Husband).Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
In 1992, Wife and Husband divorced by order of the Tokyo Family Court, Hachiohji Chapter (divorce decree).Â  The divorce decree awarded Wife sole custody of the minor child and ordered Husband to pay child support in the amount of $842 per month from June 1992 until August 1992; $667 per month from September 1992 until Husband separated from the military; and $378 per month after Husband separated from the military. Â By 1993, Husband and Wife returned to the United States.Â  Upon return, Husband moved to North Carolina, and Wife moved to South Carolina.Â  Once in South Carolina, Wife enrolled the child in private school where she remained until graduating in 2004. Â Â 
In 1994, the North Carolina General Court of Justice issued an order to modify the divorce decree.Â  This order provided that Husband pay $46 per month in child support and provide health insurance coverage for the child â€œwhen it is available at a reasonable cost.â€Â  The order further stated that â€œ[h]ealth insurance is defined to be reasonable in cost if it is employment related or other group insurance.â€Â  In addition, the order provided that Husband will be liable for any medical expenses incurred if he fails to obtain or maintain health insurance coverage as specified.Â  
Prior to 1997, Husband moved to South Carolina.Â  In 1997, Wife sent a certified letter to Husband requesting payment for medical expenses, daycare expenses, and educational expenses. Â Husband signed for the letter but did not respond.Â  
On December 17, 1998, the South Carolina Department of Social Services, on behalf of Wife, filed a Notice of Registration of the Japanese Divorce Decree in the South Carolina family court, but the court held the 1994 North Carolina Order was the proper order to register in South Carolina.Â  The court also ordered Husband to pay arrears for failure to make regular payments.Â  Between the end of 1998 and 2005, the family court issued several orders relating to the payment and enforcement of child support. 
In 2005, Husband filed a motion to terminate ongoing support.Â  At the March 30, 2005 hearing, Wife raised issues regarding reimbursement for medical expenses, daycare expenses, and health insurance coverage.Â  The court found the issues were not properly before it but reserved the resolution of those issues for a future hearing.Â  The court terminated ongoing child support as of March 29, 2005 due to the child turning eighteen and ordered Husband to pay arrears until paid in full.Â  
On June 22, 2005, Wife filed a complaint against Husband requesting a retroactive increase in child support for the period of time from 1994 until 2002, increased child support from 2003 through 2005 based on an alleged improper credit given to Husband, and reimbursement for medical expenses, health insurance premiums, work-related daycare expenses, and education expenses.Â  The family court: (1) denied as untimely the request for a retroactive child support increase and reimbursement for medical expenses, health insurance premiums, and work-related daycare expenses; (2) denied the request for reimbursement for education tuition as untimely because Wife failed to prove â€œextremely unusual circumstances;â€ and (3) awarded Wife $300 reimbursement for the sixty weeks Husband received improper credit for health insurance premiums.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn an action on appeal from the family court, the appellate court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Engle v. Engle, 343 S.C. 444, 448, 539 S.E.2d 712, 714 (Ct. App. 2000) (citation omitted).Â  â€œ[T]he appellate court is not, however, required to ignore the fact that the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 367 (1999) (citation omitted).Â  
In general, child support awards are within the sound discretion of the trial judge, and absent an abuse of discretion, the awards will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  Mitchell v. Mitchell, 283 S.C. 87, 92, 320 S.E.2d 706, 710 (1984).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of fact, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 485, 477 S.E.2d 727, 729 (Ct. App. 1996) (citations omitted).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Medical Expenses, Health Insurance Premiums, Child Care Expenses, Private School Tuition Payments, and Retroactive Child Support 
Wife contends the family court erred in finding her claims for $8,035.14 in medical expenses and health insurance premiums, $4,502.25 in work-related child care expenses, $14,458.00 in educational expenses, and retroactive child support for the period between 1994 and 2002 were untimely.Â  We disagree.Â  
A claim or right may be barred as untimely when the equitable doctrine of laches applies.Â  Terry v. Lee, 314 S.C. 420, 426-27, 445 S.E.2d 435, 438 (1994).Â  Laches is defined as â€œ[n]eglect for an unreasonable and unexplained length of time, under circumstances affording opportunity for diligence, to do what in law should have been done.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. on Behalf of State of Tex. v. Holden, 319 S.C. 72, 75, 459 S.E.2d 846, 848 (1995).Â  â€œWhether a claim is barred by laches is to be determined in light of the facts of each case, taking into consideration whether the delay has worked injury, prejudice, or disadvantage to the other party; delay alone in assertion of a right does not constitute laches.â€Â  Id.Â  
â€œThe party seeking to establish laches must show (1) delay, (2) unreasonable delay, and (3) prejudice.â€Â  Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 215, 603 S.E.2d 598, 602 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Generally, the inquiry into the applicability of laches is highly fact-specific; thus, the determination of whether a party has established laches is largely within the discretion of the trial court. Â Id. at 216, 603 S.E.2d at 602.
We hold the record supports the family courtâ€™s decision that laches bars Wifeâ€™s claims.Â  First, the evidence demonstrates that Wife delayed in asserting her rights.Â  Wife failed to bring any formal adjudicatory proceeding against Husband until 2005, despite believing Husband was responsible for expenses and support since 1994.Â  See Hallums v. Hallums, 296 S.C. 195, 199, 371 S.E.2d 525, 528 (1988) (finding delay when mother had sixteen years during which she could have enforced her right to have the father support their child).Â  
Second, Wifeâ€™s delay was unreasonable.Â  Despite Wifeâ€™s contention that Husband was difficult to locate, the evidence shows Husband was readily accessible.Â  For example, Wife sent Husband a certified letter in 1997, indicating her knowledge of his residence. Â Furthermore, Wife and Husband were involved in multiple court proceedings between 1999 and 2005 regarding issues surrounding Husbandâ€™s child support payments.Â  See id. (finding delay unreasonable when mother was afforded numerous earlier opportunities to enforce child support obligation).Â  
Finally, the evidence shows Husband would be prejudiced by the unreasonable delay.Â  Wife is claiming reimbursement for expenses totaling $26,995.39 in addition to retroactive child support for 1994 through 2002.Â  In this situation, the substantial burden of paying such a large amount would prejudice Husband.Â  See id. at 200, 371 S.E.2d at 528 (finding prejudice when husband may be subjected to burden of paying large sum).Â  Therefore, we find the family court did not err in holding laches bars Wifeâ€™s claim for reimbursements for expenses and a retroactive child support increase.
We note prejudice may not always arise when one owes a large sum to another.Â  See, e.g., Holden, 319 S.C. at 76, 459 S.E.2d at 848 (holding no prejudice shown when court ordered father to repay the arrearages at the modest rate of $25 per month, rather than in a lump sum).Â  However, we reiterate the fact-specific nature of the application of laches.Â  Emery, 361 S.C. at 216, 603 S.E.2d at 602.Â  While the appellate courtâ€™s deference to the family court is not absolute, under the facts of this case, the family courtâ€™s findings are entitled to deference by this Court.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
II.   Calculation of Credit
Wife asserts the family court erred by considering an improper credit Husband received for health insurance premiums he never paid.Â  Specifically, Wife argues she is entitled to an award in the amount of $660 as opposed to $300 the family court awarded Wife.Â  We disagree.Â  
In computing health insurance coverage for children in a child support award, the family court should reference the South Carolina Child Support Guidelines (the Guidelines).Â  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 114-4710(A), 114-4720(G) (Supp. 2005).Â  
In this case, Wife requested that she be paid $660.Â  This amount represents what Husband would have actually paid for the health insurance without reference to either the Guidelines or the pro rata responsibility of the parties in making the calculation.Â  To determine what Husband should pay Wife, the family court calculated child support without including the cost of insurance pursuant to the Guidelines, which resulted in a weekly child support amount of $67.Â  Because the family courtâ€™s original weekly child support order of $62 included the cost of insurance pursuant to the Guidelines, Husband underpaid Wife $5 per week over sixty weeks.Â  As such, the family court correctly ordered the $5 difference to be reimbursed to Wife for the sixty weeks that Husband underpaid the support, which amounted to a total of $300.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we hold the family court did not err in determining that laches bars Wifeâ€™s claims for medical expenses, health insurance premiums, work-related child care expenses, educational expenses, and retroactive child support.Â  We further hold the family court did not err in calculating Wifeâ€™s award for the improper credit Husband received.Â  The family courtâ€™s decision is accordingly 
AFFIRMED.[1]
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        James Herbert Holliday, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Tiffiny M. Holliday, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens CountyÂ 
Billy A. Tunstall, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-421
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Joseph M. Ramseur, Jr. of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Tiffiny M. Holliday, of Green Cove Springs, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: James Holliday appeals a family court custody order denying that a sufficient change of circumstances resulted from Tiffiny and Justin Hollidayâ€™s relocation to Florida.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
James (Father) and Tiffiny (Mother) Holliday married on May 10, 1997.Â  They have one son together, Justin (Child), who was born February 5, 1998.Â  Father and Mother separated on April 1, 2000 and entered into a custody agreement, which the family court approved on August 9, 2001. Â That order provided that Father and Mother would share joint custody, with Child living with Mother and Father receiving â€œstandard visitation.â€ Â Father and Mother divorced on June 12, 2003.Â  The divorce order incorporated the prior custody order. 
On June 2, 2004, Mother and Child moved from their home in Gray Court, South Carolina, to Greencove Springs, Florida. Â On August 5, 2004, in response to Motherâ€™s relocation, Father filed a motion for temporary custody. Â The South Carolina Family Court heard the motion, and on November 3, 2004, the court filed an order granting Father temporary custody of Child.Â  
After the final hearing, the family court issued its final custody order on July 13, 2005.Â  In that order, the family court found Father failed to show a change in circumstances that would warrant the courtâ€™s alteration of custody from the original agreement. Â Consequently, both parents retained joint custody with Child living with Mother in Florida.Â  
Thereafter, Father filed a motion to reconsider, which the court denied.Â  Father timely filed a notice to appeal.Â  Later, Father filed a Rule 60(b)(2) SCRCP Â motion, asking for a new trial based on newly discovered evidence. Â At the hearing, Father attempted to show that Mother began living with a man to whom she was not married and had exposed Child to the man on an overnight basis.Â  Father also claimed Child was left at home with the man, and even left at home alone without adult supervision, while mother went to work.Â  The family court denied that motion on November 22, 2005.Â  By order dated January 3, 2006, Fatherâ€™s appeals were consolidated.Â  Father now appeals both the final custody order from July 13, 2005 and the November 22, 2005 order denying a new trial.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When a family court order is appealed, we have jurisdiction to find facts based on our own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Â We are not required to disregard the findings of the trial judge who saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate their credibility. Â Strout v. Strout, 284 S.C. 429, 327 S.E.2d 74 (1985). Â This degree of deference is especially true in cases involving the welfare and best interests of the child. Dixon v. Dixon, 336 S.C. 260, 263, 519 S.E.2d 357, 359 (Ct. App. 1999). Â Our broad scope of review does not relieve the appealing party of the burden of showing the family court committed error. Â Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 252 S.E.2d 891 (1979).
DISCUSSION
    I. Custody
Father argues the family court erred in finding Motherâ€™s relocation to Florida with Child was not a substantial change of circumstances when Father and Mother shared joint custody and Father objected to the relocation.Â  Father also claims error in the family courtâ€™s finding that the relocation was in Childâ€™s best interests.Â  We disagree.

  The change of circumstances relied on for a change of custody must be such as would substantially affect the interests and welfare of the child. Â Because the best interest[s] of the child is the overriding concern in all child custody matters, when a non-custodial parent seeks a change in custody, the non-custodial parent must establish the following: (1) there has been a substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the child and (2) a change in custody is in the overall best interests of the child. 

Latimer v. Farmer, 360 S.C. 375, 381, 602 S.E.2d 32, 35 (2004).Â  
The South Carolina Supreme Court declined to hold relocation in itself is a substantial change in circumstance affecting the welfare of a child. Â Relocation is one factor in considering a change in circumstances but is not alone a sufficient change in circumstances. Â One location may not necessarily affect the best interests of the child as would another. Â The effect of relocation on the childâ€™s best interests is highly fact specific. Â It should not be assumed that merely relocating and potentially burdening the non-custodial parentâ€™s visitation rights always negatively affects the childâ€™s best interests.Â  Id.
Father cites Section 20-7-100 of the South Carolina Code (1976) to support his position.Â  This section states that the mother and father â€œare equally charged with the welfare and education of their minor children[,] . . . and neither parent has any right paramount to the right of the other concerning . . . any . . . matter affecting the minor.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-100.Â  There is abundant case law affirming the custodial parentâ€™s right to move to another state against the wishes of the non-custodial parent.Â  Â­See, eg, Hollar v. Hollar, 342 S.C. 463, 536 S.E.2d 883 (Ct. App. 2000).
Here, the court realized that relocation cases are highly fact specific and considered the following factors in determining whether Childâ€™s best interests were served by the move: (a) the potential advantages of the move; (b) the likelihood the move will improve the quality of life for Mother and Child; (c) that the move was not the result of a whim; (d) the integrity of the motives of both parents in seeking the move or seeking to prevent it; and (e) the availability of realistic visitation arrangements that will adequately foster an ongoing relationship between Father and Child.Â  Upon a review of the record, we find that the family courtâ€™s decision was supported by a preponderance of the evidence, and Father has not met his burden of showing otherwise.
II. New Trial Motion
Father argues the family court erred in refusing to grant a new trial based on newly discovered evidence of Motherâ€™s exposing Child to Motherâ€™s boyfriend overnight.Â  We disagree.
To obtain a new trial based on newly discovered evidence, the moving party must establish the new evidence: (a) will probably change the result if a new trial is granted; (b) has been discovered since the trial; (c) could not have been discovered before the trial; (d) is material to the issue; and (e) is not merely cumulative or impeaching.Â  Lanier v. Lanier, 364 S.C. 211, 217, 612 S.E.2d 456, 459 (Ct. App. 2005).
The family court denied Fatherâ€™s motion for a new trial, in part because Father conceded there was no evidence presented to prove that the boyfriend was living with Mother at the time of the hearing. Â Also, Father conceded if the boyfriend was living with Mother prior to the hearing, Father could have discovered this fact at that time. Â The family court further stated that even if the court took Fatherâ€™s allegations as true, Father did not provide the court with evidence to show that a new trial would probably result in a different outcome. Â Upon a review of the record, we find the family courtâ€™s ruling is supported by a preponderance of the evidence.Â  
Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.[1]
HEARN, C.J., WILLIAMS, J., and CURETON A.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Cathryn G. Gaither, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        William C. Gaither, III, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â H. E. Bonnoitt, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-422
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“Filed December 19, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Russell Patrick Brehn, of Conway, for Appellant.
        Thomas D. Guest, Jr., of Murrels Inlet, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this domestic relations action, William C. Gaither, III (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s order concerning the identification of certain real property as marital property and the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Cathryn G. Gaither (Wife).Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. [1]
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married on May 8, 1999, in Gatlinburg, Tennessee and resided in Horry County, South Carolina.Â  The parties separated on May 15, 2003.Â  After the separation, Husband relocated to Cashiers, North Carolina, while the Wife remained in Horry County. 
On May 16, 2003, Wife filed for divorce on the ground of adultery.Â  Pursuant to her complaint and amended complaint, Wife sought a divorce, separate support and maintenance, alimony, equitable division of the marital assets and debts, discovery, restraining orders, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Husband filed an answer and counterclaim, seeking separate support and maintenance, equitable division of the marital assets and debts, restraining orders, discovery, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Â Â 
After a hearing, during which Husband appeared pro se, the family court issued its order in which it:Â  (1) denied Wifeâ€™s request for a divorce on the ground of adultery; (2) denied Wifeâ€™s request for alimony; (3) equitably apportioned the marital property; and (4) awarded Wife partial attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $16,000. Â The court specifically found that neither party had any nonmarital property of any significant value.Â  In terms of the real property comprising part of the marital estate, the court found the total equity to be valued at $882,000.Â  This valuation consisted of five pieces of real estate, which included property in Myrtle Beach located at 400 and 402 29th Avenue North and 5405 North Ocean Boulevard.Â  In determining each partyâ€™s percentage of the real property, the court found the â€œmajority of the real property was acquired through [Husbandâ€™s] inherited funds; and, thus, the property shall be divided on a 67/33% basis with the [Husband] receiving 67% and the [Wife] receiving 33%.â€Â  As a result, the court valued Wifeâ€™s share to be $291,060.Â  To effectuate this division, the court awarded Wife a lot on Lake Keowee, which was valued at $12,000, and ordered Husband to pay $279,060 to Wife within six months of the date of the order.Â  Husband filed a motion and an amended motion to reconsider pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  After the court denied the motion, Husband filed this appeal.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996). Â However, â€œ[b]ecause the family court is in a superior position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity, its findings should be given broad discretion.â€Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Equitable Apportionment
Husband argues the family court erred in including in the marital estate the Myrtle Beach property located at 400 and 402 29th Avenue North and 5405 North Ocean Boulevard.Â  He contends, as will more fully be discussed, this property constituted nonmarital property.Â  
 In making an equitable distribution of marital property, the court must (1) identify the marital property, both real and personal, to be divided between the parties; (2) determine the fair market value of the identified property; (3) apportion the marital estate according to the contributions, both direct and indirect, of each party to the acquisition of the property during the marriage, their respective assets and incomes, and any special equities they may have in marital assets; and (4) provide for an equitable division of the marital estate, including the manner in which the distribution is to take place.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 293, 372 S.E.2d 107, 110 (Ct. App. 1988). 
Marital property is defined as â€œall real and personal property acquired by the parties during the marriage which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of the marital litigation, regardless of how legal title is held.â€Â  Johnson, 296 S.C. at 294, 372 S.E.2d at 110; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2005).Â  Property acquired prior to the marriage is generally considered nonmarital. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(2) (Supp. 2005); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(1) (Supp. 2005) (stating property is considered nonmarital if it is acquired by gift or inheritance). Â â€œProperty acquired during the marriage in exchange for property acquired before the marriage is also nonmarital property.Â  Likewise, any increase in the value of nonmarital property during the marriage is nonmarital property, except to the extent the increase resulted directly or indirectly from the efforts of the other spouse during the marriage.â€Â  Johnson, 296 S.C. at 294, 372 S.E.2d at 110 (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(3), (5) (1976)).Â  
â€œ[N]onmarital property may be transmuted into marital property if: (1) it becomes so commingled with marital property as to be untraceable; (2) it is jointly titled; or (3) it is utilized by the parties in support of the marriage or in some other manner so as to evidence an intent by the parties to make it marital property.â€Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 98, 545 S.E.2d 531, 537 (Ct. App. 2001). Â â€œTransmutation is a matter of intent to be gleaned from the facts of each case.â€ Id. Â The burden is on the spouse claiming transmutation to produce objective evidence that the parties considered the property to be marital during the marriage. Id.Â  The spouse claiming an equitable interest in property upon dissolution of the marriage has the burden of proving that the property is part of the marital estate. Â If the spouse carries this burden, he or she establishes a prima facie case that the property is marital property. Â If the opposing spouse then wishes to claim the property so identified is not part of the marital estate, he or she has the burden of presenting evidence to establish its nonmarital character. Â Johnson, 296 S.C. at 294, 372 S.E.2d at 110.
A.
Turning to the facts of the instant case, we initially note that Husband does not challenge the percentage of the marital estate awarded to him.Â  Instead, he only asserts the court erred in including certain real property in the marital estate.Â  Thus, we confine our analysis to determine whether the family court properly identified this real estate as constituting marital property.
Because the Myrtle Beach property located at 400 and 402 29th Avenue North was purchased by Husband prior to the marriage, Husband argues it constituted nonmarital property given there was no evidence the property had been transmuted to marital property.Â  Specifically, he asserts Wife did not â€œhelp preserve and appreciate the property.â€Â  Even if the property appreciated in value and provided income for the parties during the marriage, Husband claims these facts alone were not sufficient to transmute the property to marital property.Â  Essentially, Husband argues Wife failed to present any evidence to establish that the parties intended to transmute the property.Â  We agree with Husband.
Husband consistently maintained that this property was nonmarital and retained its separate, nonmarital nature throughout the marriage.Â  Through his testimony and submitted documentation, Husband established that he and his father purchased this property in June of 1997, prior to the marriage, and that he inherited his fatherâ€™s interest when he passed away in September of 1999.Â  At trial, Wife also acknowledged that Husband purchased the property prior to the marriage. Â Therefore, it was incumbent upon Wife to establish the property was transmuted.Â  We find she failed to meet this burden.
Although on direct examination Wife claimed to have helped manage and maintain the apartments located on 400 and 402 29th Avenue North, she admitted during cross-examination that she: (1) did not sign any of the loan applications used to finance the renovations of the apartments; (2) was not involved in designing the renovations; and (3) did not contribute any physical labor to the addition of the apartments to the property.Â  Furthermore, we find unpersuasive Wifeâ€™s claim that the parties evidenced an intent to transmute the property given the apartments located on the property â€œwere an integral part of the business of the marriage, buying[,] building, renovating and selling property.â€ Â We do not believe Wifeâ€™s mere assertion constitutes sufficient objective evidence that the parties considered the property to be marital during the marriage.Â  Moreover, the partiesâ€™ use of the income derived from the property during their relatively short-term marriage did not transmute it to marital property.Â  See Peterkin v. Peterkin, 293 S.C. 311, 313, 360 S.E.2d 311, 313 (1987) (â€œMerely using the income derived from [non-marital assets] in support of the marriage does not transmute them into marital property.â€); Brooks v. Brooks, 289 S.C. 352, 355, 345 S.E.2d 510, 512 (Ct. App. 1986) (holding inherited property did not lose its separate nature because a portion of the inheritance was used in furtherance of the marriage).
Finally, we find Wifeâ€™s reliance on this courtâ€™s decision in Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 545 S.E.2d 531 (Ct. App. 2001), to be misplaced.Â  In Jenkins, Husband challenged several rulings of the family court, including the courtâ€™s finding that a farm and rental home that he had acquired from his mother were marital property subject to equitable distribution.Â  In reaching this decision, the family court found the parties used the farm as a second home and planned to make the farm their primary residence after Husband retired.Â  Through Husbandâ€™s direct financial contributions, the parties spent a significant amount of money making improvements on the property.Â  Wife was primarily responsible for the general care and maintenance of the property for approximately eight years. Â Additionally, Husband executed a will in which he left all of his property, including the farm and rental home to Wife.Â  Unlike the parties in Jenkins, the parties in the instant action did not affirmatively express an intention to transmute the property to marital property.Â  Although Wife may have contributed to the maintenance of the property, she did not present evidence of any significant personal or financial contribution.Â  Moreover, Husband did not jointly title the property or execute any documents indicating his intention to establish it as a marital asset.Â  Accordingly, we find the family court erred in including the property located at 400 and 402 29th Avenue North as part of the marital estate. Â Â Â Â Â Â 
B.
Additionally, Husband challenges the courtâ€™s decision to include property located at 5405 North Ocean Boulevard in the marital estate.Â  Husband acknowledges the property was purchased during the marriage, and thus â€œby strict definitionâ€ was marital property.Â  He contends, however, it constituted a nonmarital asset because it was purchased by Husband with loan proceeds derived from equity in a home he inherited from his father.Â  Husband in essence characterizes this transaction as simply a substitution of one nonmarital asset for another.Â  Â 
Although Husband is correct that property acquired during the marriage in exchange for property acquired before the marriage is nonmarital property, we find Husband failed to produce evidence establishing such with respect to 5405 North Ocean Boulevard.Â  Given the property was purchased during the marriage, Wife, in claiming an interest in the property, established a prima facie case that the property was marital.Â  Thus, the burden was on Husband to present evidence to establish its nonmarital character.Â  Johnson, 296 S.C. at 294, 372 S.E.2d at 110.Â  
Based on our review of the record, we find Husband failed to carry his burden.Â  At trial, Husband testified that he purchased the property at issue by using as collateral a piece of inherited property located at 318 Wild Wood Dunes in Myrtle Beach.Â  Through his cross-examination of Husband, Wifeâ€™s counsel asserted that the 5405 North Ocean Boulevard property was in fact the collateral for the property purchase.Â  In support of this assertion, counsel indicated that the United States Housing and Urban Development (HUD) statement reflected that 5405 North Ocean Boulevard was valued at $295,000 and Husband used the purchase property as collateral for the $300,000 property loan. Â Counsel attempted to establish that Husband did not use â€œoutsideâ€ or nonmarital, inherited funds to purchase the property.Â  Husband disputed this assertion.Â  Husband, however, was unable to substantiate his claim because he had failed to submit the necessary documents during pre-trial discovery.Â  We would also note there is no indication in the record that Husband attempted to proffer these documents nor does Husband raise any argument regarding the denial of a proffer.Â  Thus, our determination of this issue is limited by the record before us.Â  Besides Husbandâ€™s testimony and his financial declaration, there is no other evidence in the record to support Husbandâ€™s contention.Â  Accordingly, we conclude Husbandâ€™s testimony was not sufficient to establish the property in question was nonmarital.Â  
Because Husband failed to produce evidence to rebut the prima facie case that 5405 North Ocean Boulevard was marital, we hold the family court did not err by including this piece of property in the marital estate.Â  Therefore, we affirm the family courtâ€™s finding that 5405 North Ocean Boulevard was a marital asset subject to equitable division.Â  See Fuller v. Fuller, No. 4150, 2006 WL 2623194, at *7 (S.C. Ct. App. Sept. 11, 2006)(affirming family courtâ€™s finding that company started during the partiesâ€™ marriage constituted marital property where Husband did not produce evidence to rebut presumption that it was marital).
II. Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband contends the family court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife in the amount of $16,000 given: Â (1) the court failed to make specific findings in support of the award pursuant to Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 403 S.E.2d 313 (1991); (2) Wife did not achieve sufficient beneficial results to be entitled to an award; and (3) the amount of the award was excessive.Â  
The family court may order payment of attorneyâ€™s fees to a party pursuant to statute. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(H) (Supp. 2005).Â  An award of attorneyâ€™s fees lies within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion. Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004).
In deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider: Â (1) each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees; (2) the beneficial results obtained by counsel; (3) the respective financial condition of each party; and (4) the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  Upchurch v. Upchurch, 367 S.C. 16, 28, 624 S.E.2d 643, 648-49 (2006).Â  Â Â When determining the reasonable amount of fees to award, the court must consider the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered, the time necessarily devoted to the case, counselâ€™s professional standing, the contingency of compensation, the beneficial results obtained, and the customary legal fees for similar services. Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).
In view of our decision to reverse a substantive result achieved by wife regarding the identification of marital property, we also reverse the award of attorneyâ€™s fees and remand this issue for reconsideration.Â  See Sexton v. Sexton, 310 S.C. 501, 503, 427 S.E.2d 665, 666 (1993) (reversing and remanding issue of attorneyâ€™s fees for reconsideration where the substantive results achieved by trial counsel were reversed on appeal).
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we affirm the decision of the family court with respect to the inclusion of 5405 North Ocean Boulevard in the marital estate.Â  We reverse, however, the family courtâ€™s finding that the property located at 400 and 402 29th Avenue North was marital property.Â  In light of our disposition, we reverse and remand for the family court to redetermine the valuation of the marital estate and to reconsider Wifeâ€™s entitlement to attorneyâ€™s fees.
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND Â Â Â Â Â  REMANDED.
BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        South Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Henry Kennedy, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens County
Â Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-423
Heard September 14, 2006 â€“ Filed December 19, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Karl Stephen Brehmer, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Eric H. Philpot, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â Â Â  In this declaratory judgment action, South Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company (Farm Bureau) sought a determination as to whether Henry Kennedy is entitled to underinsured motorist (UIM) coverage under his employerâ€™s insurance policy.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment to Kennedy, and Farm Bureau appeals.Â  Farm Bureau argues there is a genuine issue of material fact, or in the alternative, the trial court erred in its interpretation of the policy.Â  We reverse.Â Â  
FACTS
In October 2002, Kennedy was employed with Irons Poultry Farm.Â  At the direction of his employer, Kennedy drove a company manure truck to Wise Barbeque on October 23 to inform Jimmy Wise, the owner of Wise Barbeque, that he could pick up some contaminated chicken feed at his convenience.Â  Kennedy completed his errand and then went to speak with his half-brother, Teddy Robinson, who was employed with Wise Barbeque.Â  Kennedy and Robinson spoke for a few minutes and then walked to the parking lot.Â  Kennedy and Robinson stopped near the rear of the manure truck and briefly continued their conversation.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Moments later, on an adjacent highway, an accident occurred between a pickup truck driven by George Counts and another pickup truck. Â The impact from the collision caused Countsâ€™ truck to careen into Wiseâ€™s parking lot.Â  Kennedy and Robinson were both struck by Countsâ€™ truck.Â  
As a result of the accident, Kennedy sustained damages in excess of $64,000.Â  Kennedy settled with Countsâ€™ liability carrier for $50,000 on a Covenant Not to Execute.Â  Kennedy then made a demand for the full amount of UIM coverage available on the manure truckâ€™s insurance policy.Â  The manure truck was owned by Irons Poultry Farm and insured by Farm Bureau with UIM coverage in the amount of $50,000 per individual and $100,000 per occurrence.Â  The Farm Bureau policy provides, in relevant part: 

  [Farm Bureau] will pay damages for bodily injury or property damage a covered person is legally entitled to collect from the owner or operator of an underinsured motor vehicle.Â  The bodily injury or property damage must be caused by an accident arising out of the operation or ownership of the underinsured motor vehicle.Â  

A â€œcovered personâ€ includes a â€œperson occupying [the insuredâ€™s] covered auto.â€Â  â€œOccupyingâ€ is defined as â€œhaving actual physical contact with an auto while in, upon, entering, or alighting from it.â€Â Â  
Farm Bureau denied coverage and filed a declaratory judgment action asking the court to determine whether UIM coverage was available to Kennedy under the terms of the insurance policy.Â  Kennedy subsequently filed a motion for summary judgment.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
At the hearing, the parties submitted affidavits, deposition testimony, and other evidence to support their respective positions.Â  Kennedy argued he was entitled to coverage because the evidence conclusively proves he was pinned between the manure truck and Countsâ€™ truck, and therefore, established he was â€œuponâ€ the truck.Â  Farm Bureau alleged a factual dispute exists as to whether Kennedy was actually pinned and, alternatively, that being pinned does not qualify as â€œuponâ€ in South Carolina. Â Â Â 
The trial court found Farm Bureau â€œpresented no evidence to dispute the fact [Kennedy] was pinned against the manure truck and . . . did not meet the scintilla of the evidence burden to make this a genuine issue of material fact.â€ Â The trial court then held Kennedy was â€œuponâ€ the manure truck based on the current law in South Carolina and, thus qualifies as an insured.Â  This appeal followed. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Farm Bureau asserts the trial court erred in granting Kennedyâ€™s motion for summary judgment because there is a genuine issue of fact as to whether Kennedy was knocked or pinned against the manure truck.Â  We agree.
When reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard applied by the trial court.Â  Redwend, Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 467, 581 S.E.2d 496, 500-01 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œSummary judgment is appropriate when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material fact and that the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Jackson v. Swordfish Invs., L.L.C., 365 S.C. 608, 611, 620 S.E.2d 54, 55 (2005).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Cunningham v. Helping Hands, Inc., 352 S.C. 485, 491, 575 S.E.2d 549, 552 (2003).Â Â  Â Â Â 
â€œThe party seeking summary judgment has the burden of clearly establishing the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.â€ Â Mulherin-Howell v. Cobb, 362 S.C. 588, 596, 608 S.E.2d 587, 592 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Â â€œOnce the party moving for summary judgment meets the initial burden of showing an absence of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, the opponent cannot simply rest on mere allegations or denials contained in the pleadings.â€Â  Wogan v. Kunze, 366 S.C. 583, 591, 623 S.E.2d 107, 112 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  â€œRather, the nonmoving party must come forward with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial.â€Â  Id.
At the summary judgment hearing, Kennedy presented affidavits and deposition testimony from numerous people indicating Kennedy was either pinned or knocked against the manure truck.Â  Ronald Long witnessed the accident, and his affidavit provides that â€œKennedy was pinned between the red truck and the rear driverâ€™s side of the dump truck.â€ Â James Wise also observed the accident; his affidavit states Countsâ€™ truck â€œknocked [Kennedy] into the back of the manure truck, pinning him between Mr. Countsâ€™ truck and the manure truck,â€ and then â€œCountsâ€™ truck bounced back and [Kennedy] fell to the ground several feet behind the manure truck.â€Â  Kennedy testified he â€œgot pinnedâ€ between the two trucks, and Countsâ€™ truck stopped far â€œenough for me to free my leg.â€ 
On the other hand, Farm Bureau presented sufficient evidence to raise a genuine issue of fact as to whether Kennedy was either pinned or knocked against the manure truck from the testimony of Robinson, Counts, and the investigating officer, Earl Gentry.Â  Robinson testified that immediately following the accident, he observed Kennedy on the ground next to where Robinson came to rest and was unable to say if Kennedy was pinned.Â  Additionally, Counts testified that immediately after his truck came to rest, Kennedy and Robinson â€œwere both laying right there on the ground.â€Â  Counts also stated he had no knowledge as to whether Kennedy was pinned to the manure truck.Â  Lastly, in direct opposition to Kennedyâ€™s claim that he was pinned to the manure truck by the passenger side of Countsâ€™ vehicle, Counts testified that he could not â€œsee how the passenger side could have [pinned Kennedy], because it was coming around the opposite way. . . .â€ 
Moreover, Gentryâ€™s testimony also disputed the fact Kennedy was pinned to the truck.Â  Importantly, Gentry testified no one at the scene told him the manure truck had anything to do with the accident or that Kennedy hit the manure truck.Â  Gentry also testified that based on the fact he observed no physical damage to the manure truck he saw no evidence that the manure truck was involved in the accident.Â  Lastly, Kennedy was on the ground â€œprobably ten to fifteenâ€ feet from the manure truck when he arrived on the scene.[1]Â  As a result, Gentry did not include the manure truck in the accident report.Â  Thus, Gentryâ€™s testimony provided reasonable inferences that Kennedy was not pinned or knocked against the truck.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, when viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Farm Bureau, we find the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom create a genuine issue of fact as to whether Kennedy was pinned or knocked against the manure truck.Â  Therefore, the order of the trial court granting summary judgment is hereby
REVERSED.[2]
STILWELL and HUFF, JJ., concur.

[1] Â The picture of the scene taken by the Newberry Observer supports Gentryâ€™s testimony.Â  The picture, which was admitted at the hearing, shows Kennedy injured on the ground some distance from both the manure truck and Countsâ€™ vehicle. 
[2] Â In light of our reversal of the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment, we need not address Farm Bureauâ€™s remaining arguments.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (stating the appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of a prior issue is dispositive).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Hattie O. Gordon, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        William R. Tillman, Dan L. Tillman & Sons, Inc. Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Chesterfield County
Â Brooks P. Goldsmith, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-424
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 19, 2006Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Marvin P. Jackson, of Florence, for Appellant.
        John S. Wilkerson and M. Scott Taylor, both of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â The trial court granted William R. Tillman, Dan L. Tillman & Sons Inc.â€™s (collectively â€œTillmanâ€) motion for a directed verdict on Hattie Gordonâ€™s (â€œGordonâ€) cause of action for fraud and deceit in connection with the sale and purchase of Gordonâ€™s home.Â  The trial court also excluded Gordonâ€™s testimony relating to rent she paid after vacating her home.Â  Gordon now appeals the trial courtâ€™s rulings.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In March 2002, approximately one year after moving to Wallace, South Carolina, Gordon decided to purchase a house.Â  She contacted three real estate agents, but only Tillman had an available listing in the area.Â  After looking at the house on her own, Gordon met Tillman at the house to conduct a formal walk-through. 
Gordon testified that during the walk-through, she told Tillman she wanted the â€œhome inspectedâ€ but admitted that she did not explicitly request a formal inspection from Tillman.Â  In response to her statements at the walk-through, Gordon testified Tillman told her a house inspection was part of the loan process and was a prerequisite to close the loan.Â  Further, Gordon said Tillman told her the house was a â€œfine home,â€ and nothing was wrong with the house.Â  Despite Gordonâ€™s testimony, a written phone message indicated that Gordon called Tillmanâ€™s office after the walk-through to request a key because she â€œha[d] someone to do a home inspection.â€Â  
On March 22, 2002, Gordon placed an offer on the house.Â  Before closing, Tillman told Gordon he was exclusively the sellerâ€™s agent and presented Gordon with a form entitled â€œAcknowledgement of Relationship Disclosure,â€ which she signed.Â  The disclosure stated she understood the terms and agreed to be self-represented, and at no time would Tillman act as a dual agent between Gordon and the seller.Â Â  
After negotiations on the price, both seller and Gordon signed a purchase contract for $62,000, which placed the responsibility to inspect the house on Gordon and required her to notify the seller of any necessary repairs within fourteen days of both parties signing the purchase contract.Â  Specifically, the contract stated:

  (B) Buyer at Buyerâ€™s expense shall have the privilege and responsibility of inspecting the structure, square footage, environmental concerns including but not limited to radon gas, wetlands study, appurtenant buildings, heating, air conditioning, electrical and plumbing systems as well as built-in appurtenant equipment or appliances prior to the day of closing or possession.Â  In the event repairs are necessary to place the heating system, air conditioning, plumbing, electrical system, and any appliances to be conveyed in operative condition and to make the roof free of leaks and the dwelling structurally sound, the Seller shall be notified within 14 days after both parties have signed this Agreement. 

(emphasis added).Â  Gordon admitted that she both read and understood this provision.Â  In addition, Gordon acknowledged that the seller did not charge her for a home inspection on the settlement statement.Â  
Besides placing the responsibility on the buyer to inspect the home for defects, the contract also included a disclaimer provision.

  DISCLAIMER BY BROKERS AND AGENTS: The parties acknowledge that the Listing and Cooperating Broker(s) and their Agent(s): (1) Give no guaranty or warranty of any kind, express or implied, as to the physical condition of the property or as to the condition of or existence of improvement services or systems, thereto, included but not limited to termite damage, roof, basement, appliances, heating and air conditioning systems, plumbing, sewage, electric systems, and to the structure; (2) give no warranty, express or implied, as to the merchantability of fitness for a particular purpose as to the property or such improvements thereto and any implied warranty hereby disclaimed; . . . (4) Give no guaranty or warranty concerning (a) any certification or inspection concerning the condition of the property . . . . 

Despite this disclaimer provision, Gordon claimed from her prior conversations with Tillman, she believed a home inspection would be conducted on her behalf.Â  While no inspection was arranged explicitly for Gordon, Orkin Pest Control did conduct an inspection to issue the CL-100 termite and moisture report on the house pursuant to the terms of the purchase contract.[1]Â  Gordon maintains the closing attorney presented her only the first page of the report at the closing and claims her signature on the second page of the termite report is a forgery. 
After moving into the house, Gordon testified to a litany of problems, the majority of which she denied discovering before purchasing the house.Â  Furthermore, many of these problems, which Gordon included in her damages testimony, were also items she conceded would not be within the scope of a home inspection (i.e. lack of insulation in walls; lack of sub-flooring; cracks in ceilings and walls that developed post-purchase; and replacement of dirty carpet). 
While Gordon attempted to undertake some minor repairs, by January of 2004, she contacted R.T. Teal to remodel the house.Â  Teal estimated it would cost approximately $60,000 to repair the house, but Teal included no specific itemizations to explain how he arrived at the $60,000 figure. 
Furthermore, Tealâ€™s estimate encompasses a complete and total renovation of the house.Â  The estimate includes, inter alia, replacing all plumbing because the pipes were rusty; tearing down an addition and rear deck; installing new concrete footings for foundational support; replacing the stove range hood, kitchen cabinets, and counter tops; upgrading the electrical panel box; and replacing the baseboard heater with a new unit because of its increased efficiency.Â  Gordon apparently never hired Teal to complete these renovations.Â  By April of 2004, Gordon permanently vacated her house claiming the heat was not working properly. 
Gordon subsequently filed suit against several parties, including Tillman, but only Tillmanâ€™s case failed to settle.Â  Prior to trial, the circuit court heard Tillmanâ€™s motion for summary judgment and granted Tillmanâ€™s motion as to all causes of action except Gordonâ€™s claim for fraud.Â  Gordon did not appeal the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment.Â  After Gordonâ€™s presentation of evidence, Tillman moved for a directed verdict on the fraud claim.Â  The circuit court granted Tillmanâ€™s motion for directed verdict.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When ruling on directed verdict or JNOV motions, the circuit court must view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sabb v. S.C. State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  If the evidence as a whole is susceptible to more than one reasonable inference, a jury issue is created, and the motion should be denied.Â  Adams v. G.J. Creel & Sons, Inc., 320 S.C. 274, 277, 465 S.E.2d 84, 85 (1995); Bailey v. Segars, 346 S.C. 359, 365, 550 S.E.2d 910, 913 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  However, this rule does not authorize submission of speculative, theoretical, and hypothetical views to the jury.Â  Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 149, 485 S.E.2d 903, 908 (1997).Â  
In reviewing a grant of a directed verdict, the appellate court should not ignore facts unfavorable to the opposing party.Â  Collins v. Bisson Moving & Storage, Inc., 332 S.C. 290, 296, 504 S.E.2d 347, 350 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  In essence, the court must determine whether a verdict for the opposing party would be reasonably possible under the facts as liberally construed in the partyâ€™s favor.Â  Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 309, 566 S.E.2d 529, 532 (2002).Â  The appellate court will reverse the circuit courtâ€™s ruling on a directed verdict or JNOV motion only when there is no evidence to support the ruling or when the ruling is controlled by an error of law.Â  Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434-35, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006); McMillan v. Oconee Memâ€™l Hosp., Inc., 367 S.C. 559, 564, 626 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2006).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Initially, we note that the circuit court granted Tillmanâ€™s motion for a directed verdict based on several independent sustaining grounds, namely: (1) Gordon failed to prove by clear and convincing evidence that Tillman committed fraud; (2) Tillman owed no duty to Gordon; (3) Gordonâ€™s reliance on Tillmanâ€™s statements was unreasonable; (4) any damages claimed by Gordon were speculative in nature; (5) a substantial portion of the alleged damages would not have been revealed by a home inspection; and (6) Gordon presented no evidence that Tillman misled Gordon in relation to the CL-100 termite letter signed at closing.Â  
Because Gordon addressed only the issue of fraud on appeal, we address the remaining alternative sustaining grounds only as they relate to Gordonâ€™s failure to prove fraud.Â  See State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 694 (2003) (â€œNo point will be considered which is not set forth in the statement of issues on appeal.â€) (citing Rule 208(b)(1)(B), SCACR).Â  In view of our disposition on the issue of fraud, we need not separately address the remaining alternative sustaining grounds or Gordonâ€™s argument regarding the trial courtâ€™s exclusion of rental testimony.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (â€œ[An] appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issue is dispositive.â€) (internal citation omitted). Â Â 
I.   Directed Verdict on Fraud Cause of Action
Gordon claims the circuit court erred in granting a directed verdict on her cause of action for fraud against Tillman because she presented sufficient evidence to submit her claim to the jury.Â  We disagree.
Gordon testified that Tillman made several fraudulent representations, which induced her to purchase the house and subsequently incur damages.Â  First, she testified Tillman told her the house would be inspected prior to closing. Â Second, Gordon stated Tillman told her the house was a â€œfine house.â€ Â Further, she contends that Tillman never presented her with the full termite inspection report, and his failure to do so constituted a misrepresentation regarding the condition of the house.Â  
In South Carolina, to establish a claim for fraud, the complaining party must show by clear and convincing evidence: (1) a representation; (2) falsity of representation; (3) materiality of representation; (4) speakerâ€™s knowledge of its falsity or a reckless disregard for its truth or falsity; (5) intent that the hearer act upon the representation; (6) the hearerâ€™s ignorance of its falsity; (7) the hearerâ€™s reliance on its truth; (8) the hearerâ€™s right to rely thereon; and (9) the hearerâ€™s consequent and proximate injury.Â  Schnellman v. Roettger, 368 S.C. 17, 22-23, 627 S.E.2d 742, 745 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Furthermore, proof of every element is required to succeed on this claim.Â  See Oâ€™Shields v. S. Fountain Mobile Homes, Inc., 262 S.C. 276, 281, 204 S.E.2d 50, 52 (1974) (â€œFailure to prove any of the . . . elements [of fraud] is fatal to recovery.â€) (internal citation omitted).Â Â  
a. Tillmanâ€™s statements regarding the home inspection
Gordon argues Tillmanâ€™s statement that a home inspection was part of the home purchasing process was a fraudulent misrepresentation on which she detrimentally relied.Â  We disagree.
First, we recognize that a sellerâ€™s agent typically owes no fiduciary duty to the buyer in a real estate transaction.Â  See Harrington v. Mikell, 321 S.C. 518, 522, 469 S.E.2d 627, 629 (Ct. App. 1996) (holding that defendant, as agent of seller, owed no fiduciary duty to buyer when agent disclosed to buyer that he was the listing agent of the seller, and thus defendant was not liable for negligent misrepresentation); see also Lengel v. Tom Jenkins Realty, Inc., 286 S.C. 515, 518, 334 S.E.2d 834, 836 n.1 (Ct. App. 1985) (recognizing a real estate agent employed by a seller to sell his home is ordinarily the sellerâ€™s agent, and generally, no fiduciary duty exists between sellerâ€™s agent and buyer);Â  S.C. Code Â§ 40-57-137(F) (Supp. 2005) (â€œA sellerâ€™s agent is not obligated to discover latent defects in property or to advise the agentâ€™s clients on matters outside the scope of the agentâ€™s real estate expertise.â€).Â  
In this case, Tillman was exclusively the sellerâ€™s agent, which he fully disclosed to Gordon before she signed the purchase contract, both orally and in writing.Â  As sellerâ€™s agent, Tillman owed no special duty to Gordon; thus, Gordon had no right to rely on Gordonâ€™s representations.
Second, a cause of action for fraud will not lie when a person fails to exercise reasonable diligence in protecting that personâ€™s own interests.Â  J.B. Colt Co. v. Britt, 129 S.C. 226, 233, 123 S.E. 845, 848 (1924); see also Watts v. Monarch Builders, Inc., 272 S.C. 517, 519-20, 252 S.E.2d 889, 891 (1979) (in denying buyersâ€™ claim for fraud against sellers, court held buyers â€œchose to shut their eyesâ€ by failing to examine property as closely as they should have and failing to request a metes and bounds description of the property).Â  
Gordon never requested a home inspection report from Tillman at any time during the negotiation process, even though she claims she would not have closed on the house without a home inspection.Â  We find it difficult to imagine that if Gordon felt so strongly about a home inspection, she would not have been more adamant about seeing the appropriate documentation before or during closing.Â  We believe a reasonable home buyer in her position who was fully aware that the broker only represented the seller and was operating under the assumption an inspection was done would have insisted upon a home inspection report pre-closing.Â  See Harrington, 321 S.C. at 522, 469 S.E.2d at 629 (â€œAs part of [a fraud] case, plaintiff must show that the reliance on the misrepresentation was reasonable.â€).
Third, if a contracting party is in a position to learn the contents of a contract and thus be fully protected by reading it, that party is bound by its terms and cannot later cry fraud.Â  Britt, 129 S.C. at 233, 123 S.E. at 848.Â  In Dukes v. Life Ins. Co. of Virginia, 184 S.C. 500, 193 S.E. 36 (1937), the court held the plaintiff had no right to rely on an insurerâ€™s oral representations when plaintiff read the contract and had ample opportunity to discover the discrepancy between the contract and the insurerâ€™s misrepresentations.Â  While recognizing the action was one in tort, not in contract, the court stated: â€œWhen the parties have reduced their contract to writing, the court can look only to the terms in which the parties have expressed their intention . . . .â€ Dukes, 184 S.C. at 507, 193 S.E. at 39.Â  The court noted this quotation serves as â€œan additional warning to those who would avoid a written contact on the ground that it does not express the terms of an oral agreement . . . if the failure to discover the difference is due to the negligence of the plaintiff in acquainting himself with the contents of the instrument . . . .â€ Id.Â  
The purchase contract between the parties, which Gordon read and signed, stated that Gordon was responsible for conducting a home inspection.Â  Gordon had ample opportunity to read the contract and question Tillman on any discrepancies between their prior conversations and the contract signed by Gordon at closing.Â  Given the facts and her failure to acquaint herself with the contract, Gordon had no right to rely on any statements by Tillman.Â Â  
b. Tillmanâ€™s statements regarding the quality of the house 
Gordon next argues that Tillman fraudulently misrepresented the condition of the house when he told her the house was a â€œfine house.â€Â  We disagree.
In deciding whether a statement is fraudulent, our courts have determined that â€œ[n]ot every statement made in the course of a commercial dealing is actionable at law.â€Â  Bishop Logging Co. v. John Deed Indus. Equip. Co., 317 S.C. 520, 526, 455 S.E.2d 183, 187 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  For a representation to be actionable, it must be â€œpredicated on misstatements of fact rather than misstatements of opinion . . . [if a matter is] susceptible of exact knowledge when the statement was made, [it] is usually considered to be a matter of fact.â€ Â Gilbert v. Mid-South Mach. Co., Inc., 267 S.C. 211, 220-21, 227 S.E.2d 189, 193 (1976); see also Fields v. Melrose Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 312 S.C. 102, 439 S.E.2d 283 (Ct. App. 1993) (holding statements that membership prices in resort club would reach a certain level were not fraudulent because â€œpuffingâ€ or sales talk is permitted by law and did not on its face constitute unfair trade practices).Â  Furthermore, to be fraudulent, â€œthe false representation must be predicated upon misstatements of fact rather than upon an expression of opinion, an expression of intention or an expression of confidence that a bargain will be satisfactory.â€Â  Bishop Logging Co., 317 S.C. at 527, 455 S.E.2d at 187 (internal citations omitted) (emphasis added). 
Tillmanâ€™s statement to Gordon that the house was a â€œfine houseâ€ does not rise to the level of a fraudulent representation because expressions of opinion are permissible in a commercial dealing in South Carolina.Â  While the house was not a â€œfine houseâ€ by Gordonâ€™s standards, Tillmanâ€™s statement was nothing more than a subjective expression of confidence in the transaction.Â  Tillmanâ€™s statement was based neither on pre-existing facts nor was it susceptible of exact knowledge; therefore, it does not rise to the level of fraudulent representation.
c.     CL-100 Termite Inspection Report
Gordonâ€™s final claim is that Tillman defrauded her when he never presented her with the second page of the CL-100 termite report, which she stated disclosed â€œsignificant damage.â€Â  In addition, Gordon claims the signature on the second page of the termite letter is a forgery.Â  We disagree.
Here, Gordon has failed to meet her burden to convince this Court that the circuit court erred in its factual findings.Â  See Blackmon v. United Ins. Co., 235 S.C. 335, 341, 111 S.E.2d 552, 555 (1959) (In holding the record was void of any evidence of bad faith, the court stated â€œfraud is provable by circumstantial evidence, but it is never presumed, and evidence of it must be clear, cogent, and convincing.â€) (internal citations omitted).Â  The circuit court held that Gordon presented no evidence that Tillman defrauded her.Â  Similarly, we find no evidence of record to support Gordonâ€™s assertion that Tillman actively concealed part of the termite report or was involved in forging her signature.Â  Because Gordonâ€™s conclusory assertions are unsupported by the record, we find this argument to be without merit.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.[2]
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] The purchase contract states in pertinent part: â€œSeller shall, at [her] expense, have the property inspected and shall obtain a Wood Infestation Report (CL100) from a licensed and bonded pest control operator . . . .â€ 
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
