THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Christopher Reid Bowyer, Respondent/Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Kristi C. Bowyer, Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Wesley L. Brown, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-425
Heard December 4, 2006 â€“ Filed December 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Richard H. Rhodes, of Spartanburg, for Appellant-Respondent.
        William G. Rhoden, of Gaffney, for Respondent-Appellant.
        David M. Collins, Jr., of Spartanburg, Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is a cross-appeal from a divorce decree.Â  Kristi C. Bowyer (Wife) appeals the provisions in the decree concerning the grounds for the divorce and custody of the partiesâ€™ children.Â  Christopher Reid Bowyer (Husband) appeals the provisions concerning alimony, attorney fees, and marital debt.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Husband and Wife married on December 6, 1997.Â  They have a daughter born in 1999 and a son born in 2002.Â  The couple separated around March 28, 2004, when Husband left the marital home.Â  On April 14, 2004, Husband filed a complaint for a decree of separate maintenance from Wife and requested custody of the children.Â  On June 4, 2004, Wife filed an answer and counterclaim seeking custody, child support, alimony, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  After an emergency hearing on July 6, 2004, the family court issued an order granting Husband temporary custody of the children with visitation to Wife.
On October 25, 2004, Wife filed an amended answer and counterclaim alleging Husband was having an adulterous affair.Â  Husband filed a reply denying he was having an affair but admitting he had developed an emotional relationship with a third party, Jody Hayes, and been alone with Hayes.Â  On August 31, 2005, Husband filed an amended complaint requesting a decree of divorce on the ground of separation for more than one year. 
On November 15, 2005, the family court granted the parties a divorce on the ground of separation for more than one year.Â  The family court found Wife suffered from depression and eating disorders before and during the marriage and had a drug overdose early in the marriage.Â  A clinical psychologist who examined both parties found both had some emotional problems but either could function as a custodial parent.Â  The family court awarded the parties joint custody with primary custody to Husband during the school year and primary custody to Wife during the summer.Â  Wife was to pay Husband child support of $298.00 permonth.
Regarding the divorce, the family court found â€œthere was no clear or justifiable cause for [Husband]â€™s leaving the marriageâ€ and â€œhis leaving [was] the cause of the breakup of the marriage.â€Â  Notwithstanding this finding and Husbandâ€™s admission that he had opportunity to commit adultery, the family court found â€œthere was no creditable testimony to establish inclination.â€Â  The family court therefore denied Wifeâ€™s request for a divorce based on adultery. 
Based on numerous factors, the family court awarded Wife alimony in the amount of $350.00 per month.Â  The family court also determined the parties had marital debt in the amount of $56,377.38 but noted that Husband had paid $7,892.79 towards the debt since the separation.Â  The family court ordered Husband to pay 60 per cent of the marital debt and Wife to pay the remaining 40 per cent.Â  Specifically, the family court required the parties to pay $500.00 per month towards their debt, with Wife paying her $200.00 to Husband and Husband making the monthly payments until the debt was paid off.Â  The family court found there was no nonmarital property at issue and only nominal marital property consisting of furnishings and a van.Â  The family court ordered that each party would keep whatever assets were currently in his or her possession.Â  Because Wife had possession of the van and most of the furnishings, she received the bulk of the marital estate.
In determining attorney fees, the family court took into consideration that Husband had already paid $500.00 in attorney fees to Wife under the temporary order and Wife had not paid any child support under the temporary order, which together provided a benefit to Wife of more than $6,000.00.Â  The family court also concluded Husband was in a better position financially and Wife obtained some beneficial results in the divorce proceeding.Â  Based on these findings, the family court ordered Husband to pay Wifeâ€™s attorney $4,000.00. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from a family court order, this court has authority to correct errors of law and find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.[1]Â  Where evidence is disputed, this court may adhere to the family courtâ€™s findings.[2] Â â€œBecause the family court is in a superior position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity, its findings should be given broad discretion.â€[3]Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Wife argues the family court erred in failing to find Husband had committed adultery.Â  We reject this argument.
Any error the family court may have committed in declining to make such a finding did not inure to Wifeâ€™s prejudice.Â  A divorce on the ground of adultery would not make Wife any more divorced than she currently is.[4]
We further disagree with Wifeâ€™s contention that a finding that Husband committed adultery would have impacted the family courtâ€™s decision regarding custody of the minor children.Â  â€œThe morality of a parent is a proper factor for consideration but is limited in its force to what relevancy it has, either directly or indirectly, to the welfare of the child. Â Custody of a child is not granted a party as a reward or withheld as a punishmentâ€[5]Â  Assuming without deciding that the evidence warranted a finding that Husband had committed adultery, Wife did not show the alleged adultery had an adverse impact on the children.Â  Nor has she demonstrated that Husbandâ€™s alleged misconduct was of such a â€œflagrantâ€ nature that it would â€œinevitably affect the welfare of the child[ren].â€[6]Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
2.Â  Wife contends the grant to Husband of primary custody of the children during most of the year is improper because: (1) Husband allegedly committed adultery; (2) the family court found Husband was at fault in the ending of the marriage; (3) it was in the best interests of the children for Wife to have custody; (4) Wife allegedly was the primary caregiver; and (5) the family court placed improper significance on the temporary custody order.Â  We disagree with these arguments.
In any child custody case, the controlling consideration is the best interests of the children involved.[7]Â  Furthermore, as the supreme court has stated:

  The family court considers several factors in determining the best interest of the child, including: who has been the primary caretaker; the conduct, attributes, and fitness of the parents; the opinions of third parties (including [the guardian ad litem], expert witnesses, and the children); and the age, health, and sex of the children.[8] 

â€œ[T]he appellate court should be reluctant to substitute its own evaluation of the evidence on child custody for that of the [family] court.â€[9] â€œThis is especially true in cases involving the welfare and best interests of children.â€[10] Â 
As we have noted earlier in this opinion, the evidence presented in this case did not warrant a finding that Husbandâ€™s alleged adultery had harmed the children.Â  Furthermore, notwithstanding the family courtâ€™s findings that â€œthere was no clear or justifiable cause for [Husbandâ€™s] leaving the marriageâ€ and that â€œhis leaving is the cause of the breakup of the marriage,â€ we found no evidence that Husbandâ€™s actions in ending the marriage adversely affected the children.Â  Absent such evidence, we hold the family court committed no abuse of discretion in refusing to assign greater weight to Husbandâ€™s misconduct as a factor in determining who should have primary custody of the children. 
The family court found the childrenâ€™s current living arrangement to be in their best interests.Â  Although the family court noted both parties had made improvements since their separation and both were fit parents,[11] it also found the childrenâ€™s present situation with Husband as primary custodian during most of the year provided them a stable and protected environment.Â  The family court also noted granting primary custody to Wife would most likely necessitate a change in schools, which would be detrimental to the older child.Â  Finally, Wife has not directed our attention to anything in the record to suggest the children were not doing well in Husbandâ€™s care.
We further disagree with Wifeâ€™s argument that the family court failed to give appropriate consideration to the fact that she had been the childrenâ€™s primary caregiver before the partiesâ€™ separation as well as with her contention that the family court placed undue emphasis on the temporary order, under which Husband received primary custody of the children.[12]Â  In the appealed order, the family court gives numerous reasons besides the fact that Husband has been the primary custodian of the children since the temporary hearing to support its decision.Â  These reasons include (1) the children are thriving in their present environment; (2) both Husband and Wife had contributed substantially in caring for the children; and (3) Wife had exhibited emotional instability, as evidenced by her eating disorders and one incident of a drug overdose. Â Although we are not unsympathetic to Wifeâ€™s complaint that the custody arrangement under the temporary order may have given Husband an advantage in presenting himself as the better custodial parent, we cannot allow a perceived need to level the playing field thwart the central consideration of a child custody dispute, namely, that of serving the best interests of the children involved. Â As this court noted in Pountain v. Pountain, another case in which the appellant alleged the family court gave prejudicial effect to the temporary custody order, â€œthe child[ren]â€™s sense of security and stability are proper considerations in determining [their] best interest.â€[13]Â  Â Â 
3.Â  Contrary to Husbandâ€™s arguments, we find no abuse of discretion in either the grant of alimony to Wife or in the amount awarded. 
The amount to be awarded for alimony, as well as a determination of whether the spouse is entitled to alimony, is within the sound discretion of the family court.[14]Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the decision is controlled by some error of law or is based on findings of fact that are without evidentiary support.â€[15] Â The purpose of alimony is to place the supported spouse, as close as is practical, in the same position of support as during the marriage.[16]Â  If the claim for alimony is well founded, the family court has the duty of making â€œan alimony award that is fit, equitable, and just.â€[17] Â 
South Carolina Code section 20-3-130(C) lists the factors the family court is to consider in awarding alimony: 

  (1) the duration of the marriage together with the ages of the parties at the time of the marriage and at the time of the divorce or separate maintenance action between the parties; (2) the physical and emotional condition of each spouse; (3) the educational background of each spouse, together with need of each spouse for additional training or education in order to achieve that spouseâ€™s income potential; (4) the employment history and earning potential of each spouse; (5) the standard of living established during the marriage; (6) the current and reasonably anticipated earnings of both spouses; (7) the current and reasonably anticipated expenses and needs of both spouses; (8) the marital and nonmarital properties of the parties, including those apportioned to him or her in the divorce or separate maintenance action; (9) custody of the children, particularly where conditions or circumstances render it appropriate that the custodian not be required to seek employment outside the home, or where the employment must be of a limited nature; (10) marital misconduct or fault of either or both parties, whether or not used as a basis for a divorce or separate maintenance decree if the misconduct affects or has affected the economic circumstances of the parties, or contributed to the breakup of the marriage, except that no evidence of personal conduct which may otherwise be relevant and material for the purpose of this subsection may be considered with regard to this subsection if the conduct took place subsequent to the happening of the earliest of (a) the formal signing of a written property or marital settlement agreement or (b) entry of a permanent order of separate maintenance and support or of a permanent order approving a property or marital settlement agreement between the parties; (11) the tax consequences to each party as a result of the particular form of support awarded; (12) the existence and extent of any support obligation from a prior marriage or for any other reason of either party; and (13) such other factors the court considers relevant.[18]

In addition, the South Carolina Supreme Court has held â€œ[t]hree important factors in awarding periodic alimony are (1) the duration of the marriage; (2) the overall financial situation of the parties, especially the ability of the supporting spouse to pay; and (3) whether either spouse was more at fault than the other.â€[19] Â 
In determining whether to award alimony, the family court considered the following: (1) Wife was thirty-two years old and Husband was thirty-years old; (2) the couple was married for over six years before they separated; (3) Wife has had eating disorders in the past but both parties appeared to be healthy at the present time; (4) both parties have possible emotional issues; (5) Husband graduated from high school, attended Presbyterian College, and ultimately graduated from North Greenville College, and Wife only graduated from high school and received no other education or training; (6) Husband was the primary wage earner during the marriage and Wife did not work; (7) Husband is currently a youth minister at a church and Wife works in the office of a small business; (8) the parties have substantial marital debt; (9) neither of their earnings are expected to increase without additional training or education; (10) the parties have no nonmarital property and nominal marital property; (11) the parties have joint custody of the children with split placement; (12) Husband is primarily at fault in the break up of the marriage although he has not been proven guilty of adultery; (13) no tax consequences are anticipated as a result of this action; and (14) neither of the parties have any prior support obligation. 
The family court found Husband had a gross monthly income of $3,606.17 and a net monthly income of $2,537.74.Â  Husband also paid for the childrenâ€™s medical insurance and daycare.Â  Furthermore, the family court found Wifeâ€™s gross monthly income was $1,386.56 and her net monthly income was $1,006.07.Â  Additionally, the family court determined that both parties contributed substantially to caring for the children before the separation, but Husband has been the primary caregiver since the temporary order.Â  Based on these findings, which are supported by the evidence, we hold the family court considered the statutory factors in determining Wifeâ€™s alimony and its decision in awarding alimony is consistent with those factors.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not abuse its discretion in awarding Wife alimony.
4.Â  Husband maintains the family court erred in awarding Wife attorney fees because Wifeâ€™s results were largely unbeneficial and neither party has the ability to pay substantial fees.Â  We disagree.
The South Carolina General Assembly has authorized the family court to award attorney fees.[20]Â  In making the determination, the family court â€œshould consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fee; the beneficial results obtained by the attorney; the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.â€[21]Â  â€œAn award of attorneysâ€™ fees and costs is a discretionary matter not to be overturned absent abuse by the trial court.â€[22] Â Beneficial results alone are not dispositive of whether a party is entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.[23] 
Because the family court awarded her alimony, we hold Wife did receive some beneficial results.Â  Moreover, in deciding the issue of attorney fees, the family court expressly referenced Glasscock v. Glasscock[24] and stated it considered the issue of fault, the partiesâ€™ ability to pay counsel fees and their disproportionate incomes, the impact the fees would have on the party ordered to pay them, Husbandâ€™s payment of $500.00 toward Wifeâ€™s attorney fees pursuant to the temporary order, and the fact that Wife did not pay child support following the temporary order.Â  Significantly, the family court noted Husband earns significantly more than Wife and has more education.Â  We hold the family court considered all the relevant factors in awarding Wife attorney fees, and because that award is supported by the evidence, the family court did not abuse its discretion.
5.Â  Husband argues the appealed order is ambiguous regarding the repayment of marital debts.Â  Husband contends the family court did not give him credit for the $7,892.79 he had paid towards the marital debt prior to the divorce decree but after the separation because it required Husband to make payments of $300.00 per month until the debt was extinguished.Â  We decline to address this argument because it was not raised at trial and is therefore not preserved for appeal.[25] Â Indeed, as Husband himself concedes in his brief, he should have filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion requesting the family court to address this issue.Â  
6.Â  Husband argues that if we find joint custody is not in the best interests of the children, he should be granted sole custody.Â  Because we affirm the award of custody, we need not address this issue.[26]
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 473, 415 S.E.2d 812, 814 (1992).Â  
[2]Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  
[3]Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).Â  
[4]Â  See Miles v. Miles, 303 S.C. 33, 35-36, 397 S.E.2d 790, 791-92 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œ[T]he ground on which a divorce is granted cannot possibly make any difference where the divorce is a â€˜no-faultâ€™ divorce.â€); Â Smith v. Smith, 294 S.C. 194, 197, 363 S.E.2d 404, 406 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œBecause the granting of a divorce to the husband on the ground of adultery would not have dissolved the marriage any more completely, we need not consider the husbandâ€™s contention that he should have been awarded a divorce on his counterclaim.â€).
[5]Â  Davenport v. Davenport, 265 S.C. 524, 527, 220 S.E.2d 228, 230 (1975).
[6]Â  Boykin v. Boykin, 296 S.C. 100, 102, 370 S.E.2d 884, 886 (Ct. App. 1988).
[7]Â  Davis v. Davis, 356 S.C. 132, 135, 588 S.E.2d 102, 103-04 (2003).
[8]Â  Patel v. Patel, 347 S.C. 281, 285, 555 S.E.2d 386, 388 (2001).
[9]Â  Woodall, 322 S.C. at 10, 471 S.E.2d at 157; see also Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 330, 536 S.E.2d 427, 430 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œCustody decisions are matters left largely to the discretion of the [family] court.â€).
[10] Dixon v. Dixon, 336 S.C. 260, 263, 519 S.E.2d 357, 359 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
[11] The guardian ad litem found both parties to be suitable and did not recommend one party over the other.
[12] Wife also maintains on appeal that, at the temporary hearing, Husband submitted numerous purported affidavits that were not in fact properly executed.Â  There is, however, nothing in the record to indicate that Wife objected to these affidavits when they were submitted; therefore, we do not address this issue on appeal.
[13] Pountain v. Pountain, 332 S.C. 130, 137-38, 503 S.E.2d 757, 761 (Ct. App. 1998).
[14] Smith v. Smith, 264 S.C. 624, 628, 216 S.E.2d 541, 543 (1975); see also Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 529, 599 S.E.2d 114, 121 (2004) (Patel II) (â€œThe amount of alimony is within the [family] courtâ€™s sound discretion and should not be disturbed on appeal unless an abuse of discretion is shown.â€).
[15] Bryson v. Bryson, 347 S.C. 221, 224, 553 S.e.2d 493, 495 (Ct. App. 2001). Â 
[16] Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988). Â 
[17] Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 184, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 2001).
[18] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2005).
[19] Patel II, 359 S.C. at 529, 599 S.E.2d at 121.Â  
[20] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(A)(38) (Supp. 2005).
[21] Patel II, 359 S.C. at 533, 599 S.E.2d at 123.Â  
[22] Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748 (1989).Â  
[23] Mazzone v. Miles, 341 S.C. 203, 214, 532 S.E.2d 890, 895 (Ct. App. 2000).
[24] 304 S.C. 158, 403 S.E.2d 313 (1991).Â  
[25] In re Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In order to preserve an issue for appeal, it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€).Â  
[26] See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling that, when the determination of a prior issue is dispositive of the appeal, the appellate court need not review the remaining issues).Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Delores Brown Byrd Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        James Byrd, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â R. Kinard Johnson, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-426
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Delores Brown Byrd, of Spartanburg, pro se, for Appellant.
        Fletcher N. Smith, Jr., of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The family court ordered James Byrd (Husband) to pay Delores Brown Byrd (Wife) $50 per week in alimony.Â  Wife appeals the family courtâ€™s decision, claiming no substantial change in circumstances occurred to merit a reduction in the previous alimony award.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Husband and Wife divorced in July 1994. Â The Final Order and Decree of Divorce, dated July 19, 1994, awarded Wife $90 in weekly alimony. Â In the family courtâ€™s order, the Husband could petition the court for a reduction of alimony if: â€œthe wife returns to work; or if the wife receives an award of disability through her [then] pending disability claim . . . .â€ 
In September 1997, Husband requested the family court terminate alimony because Wife was receiving Social Security disability benefits, which Husband averred was sufficient to establish a substantial change in circumstances.Â  In its temporary order, the family court granted Husbandâ€™s requests, finding Wifeâ€™s reception of disability benefits was a substantial change in circumstances warranting termination of alimony at that time.Â  
On November 4, 2002, Wife petitioned the family court to restore the partiesâ€™ 1997 case and to hold a hearing on the issue of alimony.Â  Wife claimed the sale of the marital home in 2001 and Husbandâ€™s increased income amounted to a substantial change in circumstances, which entitled her to alimony.Â  The family court denied Wifeâ€™s motion to restore the case to active docket on the grounds that â€œit would be unjust to revive [the case] after such an extended period of lack of prosecution.â€Â  
Wife appealed to this Court, which remanded the case to family court for a final hearing. Â Specifically, this Court held the Wife demonstrated good cause to support her petition to have the case restored to active docket. (Byrd v. Byrd, Op. No. 2005-UP-141 (S.C. Ct. App. filed March 1, 2005 (unpublished opinion))).Â  
On remand, the family court determined that a substantial change in circumstances existed to merit a reduction[1] in alimony. Consequently, the family courtâ€™s order, dated November 7, 2005, required Husband to pay Wife $50 per week or alternatively $100 every two weeks in alimony.Â Â Â  
Wife asserts the family courtâ€™s November 2005 order was in error because Husband did not establish a substantial change in circumstances, which would merit a reduction in the amount of alimony previously awarded to Wife.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The determination â€œof whether to increase or decrease support based on a finding of changed circumstances is a matter committed to the sound discretion of the family court.â€ Â Thornton v. Thornton, 328 S.C. 96, 111, 492 S.E.2d 86, 94 (1997) (internal citation omitted).Â  To justify modification, the changes in circumstances must be substantial or material. Â Id.Â  The family courtâ€™s determination to modify support will not be disturbed on appeal unless the party claiming error makes a clear showing of an abuse of discretion.Â  Brunner v. Brunner, 296 S.C. 60, 64, 370 S.E.2d 614, 617 (Ct. App. 1988). Â An abuse of discretion occurs when the court is controlled by some error of law or when the order, based upon factual findings, is without evidentiary support. Â Â Hailey v. Hailey, 357 S.C. 18, 23, 590 S.E.2d 495, 497 (Ct. App. 2003). Â 
However, in appeals from the family court, this Court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).Â  This broad scope of review does not require this Court to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302, 307, 608 S.E.2d 147, 150 (Ct. App. 2005). Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Wife argues the family court erred in reducing her alimony award because no substantial change in circumstances existed to warrant a reduction.Â  We disagree.Â  
South Carolina law allows a spouse to request modification of alimony upon the occurrence of a change in circumstances.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-170 (1976 & Supp. 2005).Â  Once both parties are given the opportunity to be heard and present evidence at a hearing, the family court may â€œmake such order and judgment as justice and equity shall require, with due regard to the changed circumstances and the financial ability of the supporting spouse, decreasing or increasing or confirming the amount of alimony provided for in such original judgment or terminating such payments.â€Â  Id. Â 
Wife argues Husband did not establish a substantial change in circumstances.Â  In the 1994 divorce decree, the family court specifically stated that if Wife received an award of disability, the â€œhusband would have the ability to claim a material change in circumstances and . . . petition th[e] [c]ourt for a reduction of alimony.â€Â  Neither party appealed this order.Â  Although Wife receiving disability benefits does not automatically qualify Husband for a reduction in alimony, this occurrence allows the family court to revisit the issue of alimony. Â 
The family court properly considered the partiesâ€™ testimony and financial declarations in determining whether the change in circumstances was sufficiently material to alter the alimony award.Â  As set forth in South Carolina Code Section 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2005), the family court reviewed and considered each partyâ€™s income, expenses, and assets at the time of divorce and at the time of this hearing.Â  
In 1994, Husbandâ€™s net monthly income was $1,224,[2] and Wife claimed no monthly income. Â In 2005, Husbandâ€™s net monthly income was $1,762, and Wifeâ€™s net monthly income, including food stamps, was $701.Â  The family court considered the increase in income of both parties and their monthly expenses.Â  The court properly used its discretion in refusing to terminate alimony.Â  In declining to terminate alimony, the court appropriately reduced Wifeâ€™s alimony to $50 per week.Â  
While Wife claims her expenses have increased since the date of divorce, her income has also increased.Â  Wife alleges that without more alimony, she cannot â€œmak[e] ends meet.â€ Â Despite this claim, Wife has apparently managed to incur no debt according to her financial declaration. Â Wifeâ€™s lack of debt, without further explanation, weakens her claim that without more alimony she cannot pay her expenses. Â Husband, on the other hand, has incurred debt, and his expenses have increased since the date of divorce.Â  It appears the family court appropriately considered all the changes in circumstances of the parties.Â  As such, we cannot say that the family court clearly abused its discretion in reducing Wifeâ€™s alimony. 
Because modification of an alimony award is committed to the sound discretion of the family court, and sufficient facts exist in the record to support the family courtâ€™s reduction of alimony, we find the family courtâ€™s ruling was proper.Â  See Thornton, 328 S.C. at 111, 492 S.E.2d at 94. Â 
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the family courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.[3]
Anderson, Huff, and Williams, J.J., concur.

[1] On remand, the family court ordered a reduction as to its original 1994 order, which awarded Wife $90 in alimony.Â  The 1997 order that terminated alimony was only a temporary order, and as such, the family court had the ability to reinstate and reduce the alimony from the original order.Â  Â 
[2] In discussing Husband and Wifeâ€™s income, the family court and parties reference Husbandâ€™s gross monthly income of $1,880 in 1994, but in 2005 refer to his net income of $1,762. Â For the ease of comparison, we reference Husbandâ€™s net monthly income of $1,224 in 1994 as compared with his net monthly income of $1,762 in 2005.Â  
[3] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Randall D. Collins and Ann Shalley Collins, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Barbara Griffin, individually and as Trustee of the Griffin Living Trust, 
          Joe Ann Knox as Trustee of the Knox Living Trust, and Oconee County, Defendants,
        Of Whom Barbara Griffin, individually and as Trustee of the Griffin Living Trust and Oconee County are the Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Â Ellis B. Drew, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2006-UP-427
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 19, 2006

 AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Earle G. Prevost and Sean Gray Tzouvelekas, both of Greenville, for Appellants. 
        Bradley A. Norton, of Walhalla, John S. Nichols, of Columbia and Julian L. Stoudemire, ofÂ  Seneca, for Respondents. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Randall Collins and Ann Collins (collectively the Collinses) appeal the trial courtâ€™s ruling that a thirty-seven and one half foot easement existed over their property.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
The Collinses brought an action against Barbara Griffin, individually and as Trustee of the Griffin Living Trust (Griffin), Jo Ann Knox as Trustee of the Knox Living Trust (Knox), and Oconee County.Â  
The Collinses sought relief on three grounds.Â  They requested: (1) a declaratory judgment regarding the partiesâ€™ rights in real property located in Oconee County; (2) an order from the trial court requiring Oconee County to deed the real property at issue to them; and (3) actual and punitive damages along with injunctive relief based on a nuisance and trespass action against Griffin.Â Â  
In response, Knox executed and delivered a quitclaim deed conveying any interest she may have held in the real property to the Collinses.Â  Consequently, Knox was dismissed from the action.Â  Oconee County did not actively engage in the litigation and agreed to abide by the trial courtâ€™s order or the partiesâ€™ agreement.Â  Griffin denied liability for nuisance and trespass, and denied the Collinses were entitled to the relief sought in the declaratory action.Â  The case was tried before the Oconee County Master-in-Equity.Â  
At trial, the Collinses decided they no longer wished to seek damages for nuisance and trespass but would proceed solely on the action for declaratory relief.Â  Therefore, the case focused on the partiesâ€™ rights in the real property.Â  
The real property at issue is located on Lake Keowee in Oconee County.Â  The property extends from the mainland in a southern direction to form a point on Lake Keowee.Â  Therefore, water surrounds the property to the east, south, and west.Â  The property is bordered on the western part by a road running north to south called S 37-589.[1]Â  
This road was placed next to the property pursuant to a seventy-five foot right-of-way.Â  Road S 37-589 divided the seventy-five foot right-of-way, which meant thirty-seven and one half feet of right-of-way existed on each side of the center line of S 37-589.Â  
In the early 1970â€™s, the State abandoned a portion of S 37-589.[2]Â  Consequently, title to the abandoned portion of S 37-589 reverted to Oconee County.Â  In turn, Oconee County abandoned this portion of S 37-589 and transferred the right-of-way back to the adjacent property owners.[3]Â  
The land on the eastern part of Windsong Way, owned by Crescent Land & Timber Corporation (Crescent), was divided into two parcels, A and B.Â  Crescent transferred Parcel B to Mac and Sybil Evatt and Parcel A to Barbara Griffin as Trustee for the Griffin Living Trust.Â  Shortly after acquiring Parcel B, the Evatts granted two easements in favor of the Griffin Living Trust.Â  The deed granted: Â 

   1.  a non-exclusive easement for ingress and egress over the existing roadbed from the northernmost boundary of Parcel A to that point where Petty Road is maintained by State; and
  2.  a non-exclusive easement along the existing water line located on or adjacent to an existing roadbed including that roadbed as shown on plat prepared by Gregory Blake Sosebee, PLS #14878, dated October 28, 1997 which is both maintained and not maintained, for maintenance and improvement of water lines.Â  

A few months later, the Evatts transferred Parcel B to the Collinses.Â  They conveyed the parcel subject to the â€œright-of-way for S.C. Highway S-37-589 (Petty Road) and Windsong Way (Old S-37-589) as shown on the [Cooper Plat].â€ Furthermore, the Collinsesâ€™ property rights were encumbered by â€œany and all easements or right-of-ways granted by the Grantor(s) herein or any predecessor in title, as may appear of public record or upon the premises.â€Â  
The dispute between the parties concerns the scope, specifically the width, of the easements given to the Griffin Trust by the Evatts.Â  The parties disagree regarding the meaning of the terms â€œexisting roadbedâ€ and â€œmaintenance and improvementâ€ as used in the easements granted to the Griffin Trust from the Evatts.Â  The Collinses contend the term â€œroadbedâ€ means the paved road.Â  Conversely, Griffin argues the term means at least thirty-seven and one half feet from the center of S 37-589.Â  The Collinses also argue the term â€œmaintenance and improvementâ€ does not entitle Griffin to relocate her water lines from the western side of Windsong Way over to the eastern side.Â  The Master disagreed with the Collinses.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
As noted, above the Collinses decided to proceed solely on the action for declaratory relief.Â  Because declaratory judgment actions are neither legal nor equitable, the standard of review depends on the nature of the primary issues.Â  Campbell v. Marion County Hosp. Dist., 354 S.C. 274, 279, 580 S.E.2d 163, 165 (Ct. App. 2003).Â Â Â  
Whether an easement exists is a question of fact in a law action and is subject to the any evidence standard.Â  Tupper v. Dorchester Cty., 326 S.C. 318, 323, 487 S.E.2d 187, 190 (1997).Â  However, the determination of the scope of an easement is an equitable matter, in which an appellate court may take its own view of the evidence.Â  Id.Â  Similarly, if an action mandates interpreting a deed, it is an equitable matter, and an appellate court may take its own view of the evidence.Â  Slear v. Hanna, 329 S.C. 407, 410-11, 496 S.E.2d 633, 635 (1998).
In the case sub judice, the Master determined the scope of an easement, which necessarily required the Master to interpret deeds.Â  Therefore, we may take our own view of the evidence.Â  However, we are mindful that this scope of review does not require us to disregard the Masterâ€™s factual findings because the Master saw and heard witnesses and was in a better position to judge their credibility and demeanor.Â  Godfrey v. Heller, 311 S.C. 516, 518, 429 S.E.2d 859, 860 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Additionally, if we choose to find facts in accordance with our view of the evidence, we must state such findings of fact and our reasoning for those findings.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
â€œAn easement is a right which one person has to use the land of another for a specific purpose.â€Â  Steele v. Williams, 204 S.C. 124, 132, 28 S.E.2d 644, 647 (1944).Â  The character of an easement is determined by the nature of the right and the intentions of the parties who created the easement.Â  Smith v. Commâ€™rs of Pub. Works of City of Charleston, 312 S.C. 460, 467, 441 S.E.2d 331, 336 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  To determine the purpose of an easement, the intention of the parties must be ascertained.Â  Lighthouse Tennis Club Village Horizontal Prop. Regime LXVI v. S. Island Pub. Serv. Dist., 355 S.C. 529, 534, 586 S.E.2d 146, 148 (Ct. App. 2003).
To determine intent, â€œclear and unambiguous language in grants of easements must be construed according to terms which parties have used, taken, and understood in their plain, ordinary, and popular sense.â€ Id. (internal quotations omitted).Â  However, if the language of the easement is not clear and creates ambiguity in any respect, all surrounding circumstances, including the construction which the parties have placed on the language, may be inquired into and taken into consideration.Â  Smith, 312 S.C. at 466, 441 S.E.2d at 335.Â  
A. Ambiguity of the term â€œroadbedâ€ 
As noted above, the easement granted to the Griffin Trust provides â€œa non-exclusive easement for ingress and egress over the existing roadbed from the northernmost boundary of Parcel A to that point where Petty Road is maintained by State.â€Â  Initially, we must determine whether the term â€œroadbedâ€ is ambiguous.Â  
We note â€œroadbedâ€ was not defined in the easement granted to the Griffin Trust by the Evatts.Â  Additionally, a thorough search of South Carolina law has failed to reveal a clear answer as to the meaning of â€œroadbedâ€.Â  Long Motor Lines v. Home Fire & Marine Ins. Co. of Cal., 220 S.C. 335, 339, 67 S.E.2d 512, 514 (1951) (roadbed includes that portion of the road which is used for travel) (emphasis added); Bates v. Legette, 239 S.C. 25, 32, 121 S.E.2d 289, 292 (1961) (roadway is the portion of highway designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel).Â  
We hold â€œroadbedâ€ is an ambiguous term as used in the easement granted to the Griffin Trust, because the parties did not define the term, and its meaning is not clearly defined in South Carolina law.Â  Having determined an ambiguity exists, we must ascertain what the term â€œroadbedâ€ means in this context. 
B. The meaning of the term â€œroadbedâ€
As noted above, the deed from the Evatts to the Collinses makes reference not only to the right-of-way for Petty Road and Windsong Way, but it also refers to all easements that are part of the public record.Â  This would include the easement granted by the Evatts as well as the deed used by Oconee County when it transferred the right-of-way back to the adjacent property owners.Â  McDonald v. Welborn, 220 S.C. 10, 16, 66 S.E.2d 327, 330 (1951) (â€œThe law imputes to a purchaser of real estate notice of the recitals contained in the written instruments forming his chain of title . . . and charges him with the duty of making such reasonable inquiry and investigation as is suggested by the recitals and references therein contained.â€) (internal citations omitted).
 The deed in pertinent part reads, â€œOconee County, South Carolina, has abandoned some 625 feet of roadbed which was part of the County public road and way known and designated as Road S-16 . . . .â€Â  (internal quotations omitted) (emphasis added).Â  The deed transfers â€œ[a]ll the Grantorâ€™s right, title and interest in and to all that portion of Road S-16 . . . which abuts upon and adjoins other lands of the Grantee.â€Â  The Oconee grant would necessarily include the seventy-five feet because all of the Countyâ€™s rights in the abandoned right-of-way encompass the seventy-five feet. Â Â 
The Evatts provided the Griffin Trust an easement over the â€œexisting roadbed from the northernmost boundary of Parcel A to that point where Petty Road is maintained by State.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  The Evatts chose the same language as Oconee County when the latter transferred all of its rights to the adjoining property owners.Â  Namely, the Evatts used the term â€œroadbed.â€Â  If the Evatts intended to confer an easement solely over the paved portion of the road, they would have used language such as â€œpaved roadâ€ or â€œroadway.â€ 
Additionally, if the language in a deed is ambiguous, the ambiguity is construed against the grantor.Â  Ward v. Woodward, 287 S.C. 343, 345, 338 S.E.2d 347, 348 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  The Evatts were the grantors of the easement to the Griffin Trust.Â  In that grant, an ambiguity arose regarding the meaning of â€œroadbed.â€Â  Thus, we construe roadbed as including at least thirty-seven and one half feet from the center line of Windsong Way over the property of the Collinses. 
C. Waterline easement
The Collinses next argue the Master erred in concluding Griffin had an easement for the purpose of maintaining an existing waterline over the Collinsesâ€™ property of thirty-seven and one half feet from the center line of Windsong Way.Â  We disagree. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
As noted above, the Evatt easement provided â€œa non-exclusive easement along the existing water line located on or adjacent to an existing roadbed including that roadbed as shown on plat prepared by Gregory Blake Sosebee, PLS #14878, dated October 28, 1997 which is both maintained and not maintained, for maintenance and improvement of water lines.â€Â  
This easement also uses the term â€œroadbed.â€Â  As explained supra the term roadbed, as used in the Evatt easement, is more than the paved road.Â  It includes at least thirty-seven and one half feet from the center line of Windsong Way over the property of the Collinses.Â  Thus, the easement would permit Griffin to put waterlines within that boundary. 
Nonetheless, the Collinses argue the easement refers to an â€œexisting water line.â€Â  The Collinses contend when the Evatt easement was recorded, the â€œexisting water lineâ€ was on the western side of S 37-589.Â  As such, the easement does not allow Griffin to put any waterlines on the eastern side of S 37-589.Â  
However, the Collinses fail to observe the easement allows for â€œmaintenance and improvementâ€ of waterlines, without specifying where such maintenance or improvement is to be restricted.Â  As mentioned above, ambiguity is construed against the grantor.Â  Consequently, we hold Griffin had an easement for the purpose of maintaining an existing waterline over the Collinsesâ€™ property of thirty-seven and one half feet from the center line of Windsong Way. 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED. [4]Â  
ANDERSON, HUFF, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Road S 37-589 was at one time known as S 37-16; however, we will refer to it under its current designation.
[2]Â  The portion of S 37-589 that the State still maintains is known as Petty Road.Â  The abandoned portion is known as Windsong Way.Â  
[3] The deed in pertinent part reads: â€œOconee County, South Carolina, has abandoned some 625 feet of roadbed which was part of the County public road and way known and designated as Road S-16 . . . .â€Â  (internal quotations omitted) The deed transfers â€œ[a]ll the Grantorâ€™s right, title and interest in and to all that portion of Road S-16 . . . which abuts upon and adjoins other lands of the Grantee.â€Â  
[4] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Scott v. SCDMV
text:
The South Carolina Court of Appeals


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Traci Denise Scott, Appellant,
v.
South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-428
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 20, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James Emerson Smith, Jr. and Jonathan McKey Milling, both of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
Frank L. Valenta, Jr. and Kelli Gregg Maddox, both of Blythewood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Traci Denise Scott appeals the 90-day suspension of her driverâ€™s license, imposed because of her refusal to submit to a breathalyzer test.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Scott was arrested by State Highway Patrol Trooper B. M. Hamm for driving under the influence.Â  Once at the Greenwood County Detention Center, Trooper Hamm provided Scott with her implied consent rights and, after twenty minutes, offered her a breathalyzer test.Â  Scott declined the test.Â  Trooper Hamm documented Scottâ€™s refusal and confiscated her driverâ€™s license.Â  The South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles suspended her license pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2951(A) (Rev. 2006), which provides that the DMV â€œmust suspend the driverâ€™s license . . . [of] a person who drives a motor vehicle and refuses to submit to a test provided for in Section 56-5-2950.â€Â  Scott appealed the suspension arguing that she did not refuse the breathalyzer because she was never offered the test as proscribed in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950(a) (Rev. 2006). Â This section provides that the breath test â€œmust be administered by a person trained and certified by the Department of Public Safety, pursuant to SLED policies.â€ Â Id.Â  Trooper Hammâ€™s certification had expired prior to Scottâ€™s arrest.Â  Scott appealed, and the DMV hearing officer upheld her suspension.Â  Scott then appealed to the circuit court, which affirmed the hearing officerâ€™s ruling that Trooper Hammâ€™s lack of current certification was irrelevant, because Scott had refused to take the test.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Although neither party addresses the appropriate scope of review in their briefs, we believe the Administrative Procedures Act governs.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380 (Supp. 2005).Â  Considering the questions presented in this case, the APA would allow an appellate court to reverse or modify the agencyâ€™s decision if the decision was affected by an error of law or was clearly erroneous in light of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the record as a whole.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5)(d)-(e) (Supp. 2005).Â 
Otherwise, the appellate court would be required to affirm the judgment.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Scott correctly asserts that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950(a) requires a breath test to be administered by a certified individual.Â  She would have us interpret the term â€œadministerâ€ as inclusive of or equivalent to â€œoffer.â€Â  However, a plain reading of the entire statute reveals no such intent on the part of the legislature.Â  The statute contains no certification requirement for a person offering the test.Â  It simply states: Â â€œAt the direction of the arresting officer, the [arrestee] must first be offered a breath test to determine the personâ€™s alcohol concentration.â€ Â Id.Â  If a statuteâ€™s language is plain and unambiguous, and conveys a clear and definite meaning, there is no need to employ rules of statutory interpretation, and the court has no right to look for or impose another meaning.Â  Paschal v. State Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 436, 454 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1995).Â  Had the legislature intended to require that a certified person offer the test, it could have expressly included that condition just as it expressly provided for a certified person to administer the test. 
Furthermore, this issue has been discussed by our supreme court in State v. Jansen, 305 S.C. 320, 408 S.E.2d 235 (1991).Â  In Jansen, the court held that the officerâ€™s failure to observe certain procedural safeguards intended to ensure the validity of the breath test results did not render the refusal to take the test inadmissible.Â  

The only evidence offered was the defendantâ€™s refusal to submit to the test, not the results of such a test. Â The Parker precautions[2] do not apply in this situation as there were no test results which required protection from improper testing procedures. Â Therefore, the evidence of defendantâ€™s refusal to submit to the breathalyzer test should not have been suppressed.Â  

Jansen at 323, 408 S.E.2d at 237.
Likewise, the requirement of a certified breath test administrator is to ensure the validity and accuracy of test results.Â  In this case as in Parker, there are no results that require protection from improper testing procedures, and the admission of Scottâ€™s refusal was proper.
Scott further contends that her notice of suspension was invalid, because it was not signed by a certified DataMaster operator.Â  This issue was neither raised to nor ruled upon by the trial court and is therefore not preserved for our review.Â  See State v. Baker, 310 S.C. 510, 513, 427 S.E.2d 670, 672 (1993) (stating an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review). 
We conclude the hearing officerâ€™s disposition of Scottâ€™s appeal was proper, and the decision of the trial court is Â 
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] To admit breath test results, the State may be required to show that (1) the machine was in proper working order at the time of the test; (2) the correct chemicals had been used; (3) the accused was not allowed to put anything in his mouth for twenty minutes prior to the test; and (4) the test was administered by a qualified person in the proper manner.Â  See State v. Parker, 271 S.C. 159, 163, 245 S.E.2d 904, 906 (1978).Â

title: State v. Mays
text:
The South Carolina Court of Appeals


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Terry Mays, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Barnwell County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-429
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 20, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Herman Edward Smith, of Barnwell, for Appellant.Â  
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Terry Mays appeals the denial of his motion for directed verdict.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Mays and his cousin, Antwan Donaldson, were arrested for robbing the Modern Dry Cleaners in Blackville. Â At trial, Cheryl Smoak, the manager of Modern Dry Cleaners, testified that two armed, black males entered the store at approximately 12:12 p.m. and demanded the money from the cash register.Â  She could not identify the two men, because they were wearing masks.Â  Smoak indicated the robbers got away with $166, composed of ones, fives, and one twenty dollar bill.Â  
Blackville Police Officer Johnny Fulmer testified he had seen Mays and Donaldson walking together on Sol Blatt Avenue, a main street in Blackville, in the direction of the cleaners at approximately 11:00 a.m. Â Another witness, Jamie Jones, testified he had also seen the men together in that vicinity approximately thirty minutes before the robbery.Â  Jones further testified that as he was riding by the cleaners later that morning, he witnessed two men run out of the cleaners wearing masks.Â  One of the men took off his mask, and Jones recognized him as Donaldson.Â  Jones and Smoak provided information to police regarding the identification and description of the suspects.Â  
Maysâ€™ and Donaldsonâ€™s cousin, Tiffany Vice, testified that the two men arrived at her house around 12:30 p.m. and stayed with her on the porch for approximately thirty minutes.Â  They arrived â€œbreathing hardâ€ and â€œhad dust on them.â€Â  Captain Steven Griffith of the Barnwell County Sheriffâ€™s Department was one of the officers involved in the search for suspects.Â  He saw Mays and Donaldson in the Oak Street Cemetery, an area interlaced with paths and shortcuts allowing people to travel from one part of town to another.Â  Captain Griffith drew his gun and ordered the men to raise their hands.Â  Mays complied, but Donaldson ran.Â  Donaldson was shortly discovered hiding in a nearby shed. Â Upon his arrest Mays had $45 in fives and ones and a new pack of cigarettes.Â  On the roof of the shed where Donaldson was apprehended, police found $117 made up of one twenty dollar bill, fives, and ones.Â  
Mays moved for a directed verdict at the close of the Stateâ€™s case and again at the conclusion of the trial, arguing that the case against Mays was based entirely on circumstantial evidence and raised only the suspicion of guilt. Â Those motions were denied, and Mays appeals. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the denial of a directed verdict, this court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. James, 362 S.C. 557, 561, 608 S.E.2d 455, 457 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  When the State relies exclusively on circumstantial evidence and a motion for directed verdict is made, the court is concerned with the existence of evidence, not its weight.Â 
State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 594, 606 S.E.2d 475, 478 (2004). Â â€œ[I]t is the trial judgeâ€™s â€˜duty to submit the case to the jury if there be any substantial evidence which reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused, or from which his guilt may be fairly and logically deduced.â€™â€ Â Id. Â (quoting State v. Edwards, 298 S.C. 272, 275, 379 S.E.2d 888, 889 (1989)).Â  The court should grant a directed verdict motion when the evidence presented merely raises a suspicion of guilt.Â  State v. Lollis, 343 S.C. 580, 584, 541 S.E.2d 254, 256 (2001).Â  â€œâ€˜Suspicionâ€™ implies a belief or opinion as to guilt based upon facts or circumstances which do not amount to proof.â€Â  Id. Â â€œHowever,
a trial judge is not required to find that the evidence infers guilt to the exclusion of any other reasonable hypothesis.â€ Â Cherry at 594, 606 S.E.2d at 478 (emphasis omitted).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mays correctly argues that he is linked to the robbery through circumstantial evidence.Â  However, when viewed in the light most favorable to the State, we agree there is evidence from which his guilt can be fairly and logically deduced.Â  Mays was clearly seen with Donaldson, who was identified at the crime scene, in the time immediately preceding the robbery.Â  Immediately following the robbery, the two men arrived at their cousinâ€™s home breathing heavily and covered in dust, which could suggest the two had been fleeing the scene of the crime.Â  Additionally, the amounts and denominations of money found on Mays and Donaldson, coupled with the cost of a pack of cigarettes, are consistent with what was stolen from the cleaners. Â It can be logically deduced that the two men went to the cleaners, committed the robbery, fled to their cousinâ€™s house, and were caught together with the spoils of their crime.Â  Because evidence exists sufficient to submit the question of guilt or innocence to the jury, the decision of the trial court is 
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: SCDSS v. Emmanuel O.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
v.
Emmanuel O., Dion M. O., and John Doe, In Re:Â  Vanessa P. O.: Â DOB: 12/10/1996 and Theresa E. O.:Â  DOB: 12/31/1997, Minor Children,
Defendants,
of whom Emmanuel O. is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Jamie Lee Murdock, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-430
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed December 20, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Emmanuel O., of Charlotte, North Carolina, pro se Appellant.Â  
Princess F. H. Hodges, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Emmanuel O. (Father) appeals the termination of his parental rights to his two minor children.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
In March of 1997, Father and Mother threatened to kill each other while in court on a domestic violence issue.Â  At the time, Mother and Father had one infant child.Â  The family court placed that child and three of Motherâ€™s other children into foster care.Â  A safety plan was instituted, and the minor child was returned to Mother within three days.Â  The safety plan was violated, and the child returned to foster care where she has remained since 1997.Â  Father and Mother had another child in December of 1997.Â  When that child was a few months old, Mother delivered the child to the South Carolina Department of Social Services, reporting she could not care for the child.Â  Both remain in the custody of DSS and have been placed together in foster care.Â  
DSS ordered treatment plans for Mother and Father.Â  Father was ordered to: Â 1) undergo a psychological evaluation; 2) pay child support; 3) submit to random drug screens; 4) visit with the children; and 5) attend and successfully complete individual counseling, family counseling, and parenting skills classes.Â  DSS contends Father did not complete his treatment plan, other than visiting with the children.Â  Further, DSS presented evidence that Father tested positive for drugs in ten out of eleven screenings.Â  Father submitted evidence he completed anger management counseling and individual counseling and satisfactorily completed parenting classes.Â  Although Father has paid a few lump sum payments in child support[2] and sometimes provided toys and gifts during visitations, he has failed to pay all of his child support.Â  Father also has criminal convictions for possession of schedule controlled substances and failure to stop for a blue light.Â  
DSS filed this action in July of 2002.Â  The matter was continued several times. Â At a hearing on June of 2004, the case was scheduled for two days in September.Â  The family court judge stated that the case could not be continued for any reason.Â  When the case was called on September 20, 2004, Father was not present.[3]Â  The case proceeded in Fatherâ€™s absence.Â  At the end of DSSâ€™s case, Fatherâ€™s counsel moved to continue the case to allow Father to testify.Â  The family court denied the motion but allowed counsel to reserve the right to reopen the case should Father appear.Â  
The following day, court reconvened and Father attended, moving to reopen the case based on his belief the hearing was scheduled for September 21.Â  In six letters, written between June 22, 2002 and August 31, 2004, Fatherâ€™s counsel incorrectly informed Father the hearing was scheduled for September 21 rather than September 20.Â  
The family court denied the motion to reopen the case finding that despite the misinformation, Father should have known the date because the family court judge announced the date during the June 2004 hearing.Â  The court also found Fatherâ€™s counsel made a good faith and appropriate effort to notify Father of his mistake.Â  
The family court found grounds existed for terminating the parental rights of Mother and Father. Â Specifically, the family court found termination warranted based on the following statutory grounds:Â  1) the minor children lived outside the home for a period of time in excess of six consecutive months and Father failed to remedy the conditions existing at the time of the childrenâ€™s removal; 2) Father willfully failed to support the minor children; and 3) the children were in foster care for fifteen of the preceding twenty-two months.Â  The family court also found termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights in the best interest of the children.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Father contends the family court erred in failing to reopen the case.[4]Â  We find no reversible error.Â  
A trial courtâ€™s decision on a motion to reopen a case is discretionary and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  Lites v. Taylor, 284 S.C. 316, 319, 326 S.E.2d 173, 175 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  â€œAn
abuse of discretion occurs either when a court is controlled by some error of law, or where the order is based upon findings of fact lacking evidentiary support.â€ Â Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 529, 599 S.E.2d 114, 121 (2004). 
Regardless of the propriety of the family courtâ€™s ruling on Fatherâ€™s motion to reopen, we find termination appropriate.[5]Â  Though Fatherâ€™s testimony may have shown he did not willfully fail to support the children, and he met some of the treatment plan goals, there is no dispute regarding the childrenâ€™s placement in foster care for fifteen out of twenty-two months.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8) (Supp. 2005) (providing a ground for termination where a child â€œhas been in foster care under the responsibility of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two monthsâ€).Â  Both children have been in foster care for over eight years.Â  During this time, Father has failed to remedy all of the conditions existing at the time of removal.Â  
While it is clear grounds exist for the termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights, we must still determine if such a termination is in the best interest of the children.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005) (providing family court can terminate parental rights if it finds at least one of the statutory grounds for termination has been met and the termination is in the best interest in of the child).Â  In a TPR action, the best interest of the child is the paramount consideration.Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Before parental rights can be terminated, the alleged grounds for the termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Richberg v. Dawson, 278 S.C. 356, 357, 296 S.E.2d 338, 339 (1982).Â  On appeal, this court may review the record and make its own determination whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Despite this broad scope of review, we do not disregard the findings of the family court judge who was in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony. Â Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).
The DSS caseworker, Melissa Mathis, testified Father visited the children twice a month and generally behaved appropriately during the visits.Â  She also testified the children have a loving relationship with Father and enjoy spending time with him.Â  However, Mathis recommended termination due to the childrenâ€™s ages, their need for a stable environment, and Fatherâ€™s failure to complete his treatment objectives.Â  
Although a previous guardian recommended Fatherâ€™s rights not be terminated, the childrenâ€™s most recent guardian, Carrie E. Adkins, concluded Fatherâ€™s parental rights should be terminated.Â  She testified Father acted erratically and espoused conspiracy theories about the termination of his rights.Â  Adkins believed the children felt conflicted about their status and wanted only one set of parents.Â  Adkins admitted she did not evaluate the children interacting with Father, and the children have never stated that they wanted to sever ties with Father.Â  
We find termination of Fatherâ€™s rights is appropriate in this case.Â  The children have been in foster care for over eight years, have expressed a desire for only one set of parents, and have bonded with their foster parents.Â  Father has failed to complete the treatment plan and has a history of drug abuse and incarceration.Â  We accordingly agree it is in the best interest of the children that Fatherâ€™s parental rights be terminated.Â  
AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
[2] Father made four payments:Â  1) March 2004â€”$666.67; 2) 1998â€”$1359.20; 3) 1998â€”$291.26; and 4) 1997â€”$97.09. 
[3] Mother did not attend and is believed to be incarcerated in Georgia. 
[4] Father raises numerous other arguments concerning ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  We incorporate these issues in our address of the primary issue.Â  
[5] We recognize that parents facing termination of parental rights warrant protection under the law and due process mandates a fair procedure.Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cochran, 364 S.C. 621, 626, 614 S.E.2d 642, 645 (2005).Â  However, we find no violation of Fatherâ€™s right to notice.Â  The family court notified all present at the June 2004 hearing, including Father, of the date of the hearing.Â  In addition, the family court found that Fatherâ€™s counsel, upon realizing his mistake, made a good faith and appropriate effort to notify Father of the correct date.Â  Finally, Father appeared on the second day thirty minutes late and at his attorneyâ€™s office rather than at the courthouse.
